text: In a project called Mission Shakti, India has successfully tested its Anti-Satellite (ASAT) Missile, which destroyed a low-orbiting satellite on Wednesday. While it is unknown who the satellite belonged to, India has stated that it did not break any international laws or treaties. India is now the fourth country in the world to have achieved this feat, after the US, Russia, and China. Prime Minister Narendra Modi stated that the purpose of Mission Shakti was to strengthen India's overall security and that the missile system would not be used offensively.

In a project called Mission Shakti, India has successfully tested its Anti-Satellite (ASAT) Missile, which destroyed a low-orbiting satellite on Wednesday. While it is unknown who the satellite belonged to, the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) claims that the test was conducted at the Earth-Sun Lagrange Point (L2) - a region between Earth and the Sun, and where no satellites are currently orbiting. ISRO chief K Sivan claimed that the mission was a "pre-emptive action" to protect India's satellite space and that the test has shown that "India can defend itself against any external threat." The test was part of India's Agni series of missiles. This missile was launched at a height of 220 kilometers, and reached an altitude of 430 kilometers. The missile then de-orbited itself and successfully destroyed a satellite that was in orbit. The test has been approved by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The satellite, known as Inmarsat-5 F4, was in a 700-kilometer orbit. It was owned by the British satellite company Inmarsat. A statement from the company said that the satellite was launched in 2008, and that it had been in orbit for more than a decade. ISRO's latest test comes just weeks after a Chinese satellite, which was also in a low orbit, was destroyed by an ASAT missile. That test was part of the country's annual anti-satellite test, and it was conducted on September 25. India is a member of the Outer Space Treaty, and it has previously stated that it does not have the intention of targeting other countries' satellites. However, ISRO's statement has been criticized by several experts, who say that the missile was fired at a point in space that is not currently occupied by a satellite. "India has not used its ASAT missile in the past and has no right to threaten other countries' space assets with the same missile," India's former Chief of the Air Staff, Air Marshal P.K. Bhadauria, said.

In a project called Mission Shakti, India has successfully tested its Anti-Satellite (ASAT) Missile, which destroyed a low-orbiting satellite on Wednesday. While it is unknown who the satellite belonged to, it is believed to be an Indian satellite. The test was conducted from the Dr A P J Abdul Kalam Island launch complex. In a statement, the government said, "The test was fully successful and achieved all parameters as per plans." The test comes a day after India carried out an air strike on terror camps across the border. According to the statement, the anti-satellite weapon, A-SAT, was developed indigenously and all its sub-systems were developed indigenously. This is the first time India has tested an anti-satellite missile. It is the fourth country to do so, after the United States, Russia, and China. In response to the development, Prime Minister Narendra Modi congratulated the scientists on the successful test. "Mission Shakti was a highly complex one, conducted at extremely high speed with remarkable precision. It shows the remarkable dexterity of India's outstanding scientists and the success of our space programme," he said. The PM further added that the mission has made India a space power. "India has always been a space power. It is time the country becomes an important player in the advancement of space technology," he said. He said that India's action was not directed against any country and it does not violate the Outer Space Treaty and international laws. "Our aim is to defend our space assets and not to start an arms race in space," he said.

While it is unknown who the satellite belonged to, this test makes India the fourth country in the world to have the capability to shoot down satellites in space, after the United States, Russia, and China. The successful test is significant for India's military and space programs, but it has also raised concerns about the potential for a space arms race and the creation of space debris that could pose a threat to other satellites and space activities.

In a project called Mission Shakti, India has successfully tested its Anti-Satellite (ASAT) Missile, which destroyed a low-orbiting satellite on Wednesday. While it is unknown who the satellite belonged to, it is believed to be a defunct Russian satellite. The ASAT test was conducted in the Indian state of Odisha and was monitored by the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO). The test was successful, and the ASAT missile successfully destroyed the satellite in space. This is the first time that India has successfully tested its ASAT missile. The test has been met with mixed reactions, with some praising India for its technological prowess, while others have expressed concern about the potential for an arms race in space.

Facebook Gaming has been launched in beta for a limited group of people. The service will launch with five games, including Gameloft's Asphalt 9: Legends. Out of Facebook's 2.7 billion monthly active users, the company hopes to reach 1 billion gamers by 2022.

Facebook Gaming has been launched in beta for a limited group of people. The service will launch with five games, including Gameloft's Asphalt 9: Legends. Out of Facebook's 2.7 billion users, Facebook Gaming will only target the 150 million users who are between 13 and 24 years old. "We're testing the waters in a small group of countries to make sure that we get the experience right before rolling out to everyone," Facebook's Gaming product manager, Dan Hollis, told IGN. "The good news is that if it doesn't work, we can roll it back and start over." There are currently no plans to roll out Facebook Gaming globally, Hollis said. The service will be available to all iOS and Android users who have access to Facebook, and it's free to use. For Facebook's first release, it will be focused on casual games, Hollis said. It will be based on a client-server architecture, which will allow it to scale. "We're very focused on delivering a very good user experience," Hollis said. "We're taking a client-server architecture that we learned from gaming, and we're using it in a way that scales to hundreds of millions of people." The biggest challenge, Hollis said, is making sure the games can be played on phones that are a year old. "The majority of our mobile gaming community is on smartphones, and that includes the low-end smartphones," he said. "We're focusing on the best gaming experience, and we're trying to make sure that we can scale to hundreds of millions of people. It's a challenge, but we're trying to be careful with our mobile audience." Facebook is currently focusing on games, Hollis said, but it may expand to other areas, such as live events. "We're going to test the waters and see what people are into," he said.

The post Microsoft announces its first set-top box appeared first on e24 News Published: Feb 10, 2021 HONG KONG (AP) - China's top telecommunications regulator said Thursday that it would seek regulatory relief from Hong Kong authorities over plans by Facebook Inc and other U.S tech giants like Google parent Alphabet Inc not to allow their services to operate through censorship in China. China is increasingly cracking down on online content at home under pressure from Beijing's efforts to contain social media platforms deemed critical of government policies, notably against dissent and criticism about human rights abuses in Xinjiang province. Some Chinese citizens see such platforms as vital outlets for information sharing and alternative news sources. In response, Facebook pledged last month to work with regulators around the world "to determine what standards should govern where companies can share user data" if they want to carry out business operations overseas.

Out of Facebook's 2.7 billion monthly users, two billion play games on the service each month. Facebook today unveiled Facebook Gaming, a hub for gamers to discover streams and live broadcasts, play games, and chat with other gamers. The service will launch in beta in a limited number of countries, and will begin with five games, including Gameloft's Asphalt 9: Legends. In a blog post, Facebook Gaming Director Farem Meemawat said Facebook's mission is to "make it a place where people can come together around games they love." The company also announced that it's rolling out a redesigned Facebook gaming tab in the main navigation bar, where users will see videos and live streams from game developers, publishers, and creators. Facebook also announced that it's launching a new pilot program with select content creators where they'll be able to monetize their content, including through ad breaks in their videos. "We're just getting started and we look forward to continuing to work with our gaming partners to help this community grow and thrive," Meemawat wrote. Facebook's gaming portal has been rumored to be in the works for a while now, and it's sure to be a massive challenge to the popular live-streaming platform Twitch, which was acquired by Amazon in 2014. Twitch, however, is much more than just a gaming platform. Facebook's gaming initiative comes just days after Google announced Stadia, its new cloud-based game streaming platform. Out of Facebook's 2.7 billion monthly users, two billion play games on the service each month.

PostgreSQL 14 has a new multirange feature that makes range types in PostgreSQL more powerful. Range types allow developers to store various kinds of intervals with upper and lower bounds. That's correct! PostgreSQL 14 introduced a new multirange data type that can be used to store multiple ranges in a single column. This feature can be particularly useful in scenarios where you need to store multiple ranges of values, such as when working with time intervals or geographical data. With multiranges, you can create a column that can store multiple range values without resorting to complex table structures or additional columns. You can also perform range-based queries on multiranges, such as finding entries within a particular range or checking if a range intersects with another range. To create a multirange column, you can use the 'multirange' data type along with the range subtype you want to use. For example, if you want to store date ranges, you can use the 'daterange' subtype along with 'multirange', like so: " ' CREATE TABLE events (id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT NOT NULL, dateranges daterange; " ' Then, you can insert data into this column using multirange literals, such as: " ' INSERT INTO events (name, dateranges) VALUES Event A', 2022-01-01, 2022-01-03) ," 2022-01-07, 2022-01-09) ; " ' Overall, multirange data types in PostgreSQL 14 can simplify data storage and querying for scenarios where you need to work with multiple ranges.

This is much like multi-dimensional arrays, but without the overhead of having many different dimensions. PostgreSQL 14 has a new multirange feature that makes range types in PostgreSQL more powerful. Range types allow developers to store various kinds of intervals with upper and lower bounds. You can use range types to represent dates, times, time intervals, and more. The new multirange feature makes it possible to use multiple range types at the same time. This is a big deal because it allows you to store ranges with different properties, such as dates and times. For example, you can use a date range type to store dates, and a time range type to store times. You can then use a single multirange type to store a date range and a time range. The result is a multirange that can represent a date range and a time range, for example. Let's see how this works. I'll start by defining a multirange type that stores a date range and a time range. CREATE TYPE multirange AS (mindate date, maxdate date, mintime time, maxtime time); CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION multirangedemo RETURNS TABLE (startdate date, enddate date, starttime time, endtime time) AS func DECLARE vdate date; vtime time; BEGIN SELECT MIN (startdate), MAX (startdate), MIN (starttime), MAX (starttime) INTO vdate, vtime FROM multirange; SELECT MIN (enddate), MAX (enddate), MIN (endtime), MAX (endtime) INTO vdate, vtime FROM multirange; RETURN QUERY SELECT startdate, enddate, starttime, endtime FROM multirange; END func LANGUAGE plpgsql; Now let's define a table that uses the multirange type. CREATE TABLE mytable (id serial PRIMARY KEY, startdate multirange, enddate multirange, starttime multirange, endtime multirange); INSERT INTO mytable VALUES (1, SUBDATE 2019-01-01', '1 day, SUBDATE 2019-01-01', '1 day, SUBTIME 19:00', '19:00, SUBTIME 19:00', '19:00; INSERT INTO mytable VALUES (2, SUBDATE 2019-01-02', '1 day, SUBDATE 2019-01-02', '1 day, SUBTIME 19:00', '19:00, SUBTIME 19:00', '19:00; SELECT FROM mytable; id startdate enddate starttime endtime 1 2019-01-01 2019-01-01 19:00:00 19:00:00 2 2019-01-02 2019-01-02 19:00:00 19:00:00 (2 rows) I can now insert multiple rows using the multirange type.

A multirange is a compilation of ranges. This article looks at multiranges in PostgreSQL and gives examples of how to use them.

The resignations of Larry Page and Sergey Brin from their roles as CEO and president of Alphabet marked the end of an era. The pair cited changes to Google's all-hands meetings, in which they say they are no longer able to speak freely, as one of the reasons for their departure. But now they're reassuring employees that they are not stepping back from the company. Alphabet's CEO and president, respectively, will remain on the board and "deeply engaged" Brin and Page founded Google in 1998, and for the first 11 years were both CEO and president. In 2011, they stepped back to become co-CEOs of a new entity, Alphabet, and hired Sundar Pichai to become CEO of Google. Brin and Page stepped back again in 2015, naming Pichai as CEO of Alphabet too. In the original letter announcing their resignations, Brin and Page wrote, "We are deeply humbled to have seen a small research project develop into a source of knowledge and empowerment for billions - a bet we made as two Stanford students that led to a multitude of other technology bets." Now, in a letter to employees, they write, "We will continue talking with Sundar regularly, especially on topics we're passionate about!," and explain that they will still be involved in the company. Page and Brin are stepping down amid growing public criticism of the company and its leaders. A New York Times report last month alleged that Google shielded executives accused of sexual misconduct. Earlier this year, employees organized in protest of the company's involvement in the US military's drone program, Project Maven, and the company's development of a censored search engine for China. The pair's resignations were announced on the same day that Alphabet was reported to be facing a federal antitrust probe and dozens of state attorneys general were set to announce a separate probe into Google. "Today, in 2019, if the company was a person, it would be a young adult of 21 and it would be time to leave the roost," Page and Brin write in their letter. "While it has been a tremendous privilege to be deeply involved in the day-to-day management of the company for so long, we believe it's time to assume the role of proud parents - offering advice and love, but not daily nagging!" But they also note, "We are deeply humbled to have seen a small research project develop into a source of knowledge and empowerment for billions - a bet we made as two Stanford students that led to a multitude of other technology bets." The resignations are effective immediately. Pichai will remain CEO of Alphabet and Google.

The resignations of Larry Page and Sergey Brin from their roles as CEO and president of Alphabet marked the end of an era. The pair cited changes to Google's all-hands -on-deck culture, driven by fear over losing control. Those in charge now have a difficult task: create a cohesive vision for what has become the world's most valuable company with no one person telling them exactly where they should go next. Google still relies on its core ad business, but is increasingly turning away from it toward new revenue streams such as cloud computing, navigation software and smartphones made by Motorola Mobility Inc. (MOT), which was acquired last November for 12 billion (S18.09 billion). However, despite these efforts, investors remain wary about how effectively Google will be able to scale up its businesses and continually innovate without its two founders at the helm. Mr Lee Kuan Yew, Singaporean prime minister who died in September aged 91, once said that "without passion there can never be success" - especially when things are going well. Google shares fell 3 per cent yesterday after Mr Page announced his departure via video message over social media platforms. He did not elaborate further on why he stepped down or give any reason behind those decisions. These developments mark another chapter in a tale of personal rivalry between Mr Page and Mr Brin, which began nearly 20 years ago, when both men were card-carrying members of Stanford University's computer science department. They soon became rivals studying artificial intelligence (AI) during their graduate studies under professor Licklider, then head of USARPA, which funded research into AI back in 1965. By 1976, while working together on projects involving image recognition algorithms, they decided to quit Stanford and set off on separate paths towards building today's online search tools we use every day - one starting a start-up called AltaVista, and the other joining Microsoft Corp., founded 13 years earlier by Bill Gates. Both companies eventually merged to form Bing, whose name changed slightly before becoming part of Google in 2008. In 2003, Sergey Brin left Microsoft to join Yahoo!, where he spent 12 years until 2012. In 2011, Mr Mark Zuckerberg bought him out for US2 billion. But just six months later, Mr Page joined Google on a 1 million pay offer, bringing the total price tag for his move to Silicon Valley to 2.1 billion. The decision landed Mr Page squarely in the spotlight, given that the executives had previously been used as symbols of power for employees and customers alike even though many felt the firm could do better if it kept both individuals around. Both went through corporate restructurings following their departures. After leaving Google, Mr Page worked briefly as senior advisor to Tesla Motors Co's chief executive Elon Musk, before returning to directing YouTube. Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes also hired Page as director of engineering for his ambitious Project Soli project aimed at developing self-driving cars. But he later resigned due to disagreements with management. During this period, Mr Page continued to put forward ideas related to autonomous vehicles and deep learning technologies amid strong criticism from some within Google itself. His technology breakthroughs include Deep Dream, a machine-learning framework that allowed machines to learn to recognise images; BlueDot, a capable system that detects human activity using radar data; and TensorFlow, a programming language designed to make data processing easier. On Tuesday night, Mr Page posted a short video explaining why he had left Google. "The world I built here is changing rapidly... I want more freedom, ambition and resources than I've ever seen anywhere else," wrote the former Google employee. He added: "We've grown too big and our leadership structure isn't suited to growing so fast. Late last year, Google tried to get rid of me because I told my friends I'd leave, but I've stayed anyway since I wanted to stay longer.... I'm proud of everything we've accomplished here over the past 15 years,... [but] there's much we don't understand yet. That's OK, that's good. It's exciting!" A version of this article appeared in the print edition of The Straits Times on July 03, 2016, with the headline 'An age ends at Google'. Print Edition Subscribe

The resignations of Larry Page and Sergey Brin from their roles as CEO and president of Alphabet marked the end of an era. The pair cited changes to Google's all-hands meeting as the reason for their departure. "Over the last few years, our leadership team has been evaluating a range of options for Alphabet," they wrote in a note to employees. "In light of these options, we have decided to transition Alphabet to a new name, and to start the process of organizing Alphabet into 5 distinct companies." Here's what each company will be: Google: This will continue to be led by Page and Brin. They'll be part of the new company's executive committee. Alphabet: This will be the holding company that'll hold all of the new companies, including Google. The group will also include a holding company for a separate investment firm that invests in startups. The new companies will be focused on the internet, health, space, and self-driving cars. Waymo: This will be the self-driving car unit, which will continue to be led by John Krafcik. It's expected to be worth about 68 billion. The company will include an AI division called DeepMind, which was founded by Google's former AI chief Demis Hassabis. The AI division will be headed by Alex Graves. Calico: This is the life sciences company, which will be led by Larry Page. It's expected to be worth about 20 billion. The company will include a health insurance company called Allo. Verily: This is the health division, which will be led by Daniel Birnbaum. It's expected to be worth about 30 billion. The company will include a pet health division called Obvio. The vision of the Alphabet breakup is that it will allow the company to focus on its main goals without being encumbered by its 2009 creation. It will be led by Larry Page, who was the first CEO of Google, and Sergey Brin, who was the first president of Google. The announcement came the day after Google was ordered to pay 4.3 billion in damages to Oracle for copyright infringement. Alphabet's announcement said it will have "a formal response" to the verdict.

The energy system cost (excluding capital expenditure) of a Tesla battery is just 1-2 compared to an equivalent plant from coal or gas, if it operates continuously rather than being used only in peaks. The ability for batteries to provide reliable peak power makes them all the more suitable when wind capacity increases rapidly: they can be quick enough to respond during large swings in demand that would otherwise require costly pumped hydro storage on top of large-scale fossil-fired generation, especially since there are several thousand possible charging points across SA ready at any time for residential consumers who want renewable electricity with no carbon emissions. In addition, battery storage delivers additional benefits such as balancing supply and consumption; reducing variability by partially offsetting high or low seasonal demands; enabling better use of variable renewables like solar PV and energy efficiency; ensuring reliability even when transmission infrastructure fails; potentially supporting local generation sources like small-scale hydropower plants; and providing resilience against extreme events which could damage conventional generators like fires and floods.

Tesla's 100MW Powerpack battery has provided South Australia with the same grid services as peaker plants, but cheaper, quicker, and with zero-emissions through its battery system. The energy system cost the state only 36 cents per citizen, yet it has made over 800,000 in profits in the first 6 months. The Powerpack system in South Australia has saved consumers over 30 million in one year, with the ability to charge and discharge rapidly, a capability that many other grid services companies are unable to provide. Tesla's battery has been able to help the grid during a time when gas generators have failed. The Powerpack system was able to help the state meet peak demand in less than 100 milliseconds after the failure of the coal-fired Loy Yang Power Plant. Tesla has released a statement regarding the success of their Powerpack system in South Australia. "With 100 megawatts of storage capacity, Hornsdale Power Reserve is the largest lithium-ion battery in the world and will play a major role in South Australia's continued transition to renewable energy. The battery will provide essential grid stability and reliability services for the region while also lowering costs for consumers and reducing carbon emissions." The Hornsdale Power Reserve is a 100MW129MWh Tesla Powerpack system that stores renewable energy and delivers it to the grid when it is needed, especially during peak hours when power is needed most. The Powerpack system has also been able to make 1 million in grid services in the first 6 months of operations, exceeding the expectations of the operators. "We're pleased to see the Hornsdale Power Reserve performing as expected. We are seeing early signs of the potential for battery storage to provide similar benefits in other areas of the Australian National Electricity Market (NEM)," says Matt Zema, CEO of the Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO). In the first 6 months, the Powerpack system has helped to stabilize and support South Australia's grid, as well as help lower energy prices for consumers. "We are delighted that Hornsdale Power Reserve is performing well and playing an important role in maintaining the reliability and security of South Australia's electricity supply," says Tesla. Tesla's Powerpack system is able to help South Australia reach their goal of 100 renewable energy by 2025.

The robot is able to learn the information from a single step of walking and then use that information to guide its next steps. Researchers used a toy robot with a 3D printed model of a human leg. This model was used to help the system learn about how humans move. The system was trained on 100 different surfaces, including stairs, grass, dirt, sand, gravel, cement, wood, tile, stone, glass, snow, grass, and stairs.

Researchers from Facebook AI have created a model for robotic locomotion that adapts in real-time to any terrain it encounters. Rapid Motor Adaptation was developed from the idea that humans and animals are able to make quick adjustments to their movement in response to changes in their environment. The researchers used a reinforcement learning technique to train a robot to walk on various surfaces, such as sand, gravel, and grass. The robot was able to quickly adapt to each new terrain it encountered, adjusting its gait and balance to maintain stability and move efficiently. This breakthrough could significantly improve the ability of robots to navigate complex environments and perform tasks in real-world settings.

Researchers from Facebook AI have created a model for robotic locomotion that adapts in real-time to any terrain it encounters. Rapid Motor Adaptation was developed from the idea that humans learn to walk by interacting with the world, by falling, and by making mistakes. To better understand how this adaptive learning works, the researchers used an agent to interact with a virtual world, and by observing how the agent adapted to the terrain in that virtual world, the researchers were able to extract the principles that could be applied to real-world walking robots. The new model, Rapid Motor Adaptation, offers a way to enable a robot to learn to navigate a physical environment through trial and error. The system consists of a learning agent and a planner. The planner identifies obstacles and plans a path the robot can follow that will allow it to reach the goal. The learning agent controls the robot, which gathers new data on the environment as it interacts with it. The learning agent then uses the new data to make small changes to the behavior of the robot. This process continues until the robot reaches the goal. The learning agent uses what is known as a hierarchical representation to make adjustments to the robot's behavior. That means that the agent makes changes to the robot's gait and balance first. Only if those changes don't allow the robot to reach the goal will the agent make changes to the robot's walking behavior. The researchers tested the model in simulations and then on a real-world robot, the Cassie bipedal robot. The system was able to successfully navigate unfamiliar terrain and climb stairs. The model is a form of reinforcement learning. The agent learns through trial and error, and it is able to adapt quickly. The system is also efficient because it is only the learning agent that is updating as the robot walks, and the planner is not updating during this time. "The key to this system is that it learns to adapt the gait and step size to the terrain," said Sergey Levine, assistant professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences and co-director of the Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research Lab. "This system is a first step towards robots that can learn to master their environment through interaction." Facebook has released a report that shows what content was most widely viewed by Americans between April and June. It contains sections showing the top 20 domains, links, pages, and posts that were most engaged with on its platform. Is there anything specific you would like me to find from this report?

Facebook has released a report that shows what content was most widely viewed by Americans between April and June. It contains sections showing the top 20 domains, links, pages, and images, as well as the top 20 search terms. It also includes a chart showing the top 20 viral posts. The report is broken down into three sections: Trending Content, Top Search Terms, and Top Domains. It doesn't give the percentage of the content that each of these items made up of the content viewed, but the chart below does show that there were far more viral posts than either images or links. And if you're wondering how the top 20 viral posts compared to the top 20 viral images and links, the answer is that they didn't. For viral posts, the top 20 were all videos, and the top 20 images were all still images. Of course, if you look at the chart showing the top 20 domains, there's some overlap between the top 20 images and links. Most of the top 20 images are either YouTube videos or posts from Facebook, while most of the top 20 links are either links to Facebook posts or YouTube videos. Overall, the data seems to show that the content that was most popular with Facebook users was videos and posts from other people. It's interesting to see what was popular, but it's also interesting to see how Facebook is prioritizing content. For example, it shows that posts from the Facebook app were far more popular than posts from the Facebook website. And videos were more popular than images. In other words, it's still Facebook's content.

Recurrent Neural Networks are a type of neural network that specializes in processing sequences. A common application of RNNs is for Natural Language Processing due to its effectiveness at handling long and unstructured text. The motivation behind this work came from the observation that, while we have many datasets with information about each word's position within the sequence (such as parts-of-speech), there are very few such datasets where the words themselves can be labeled. This motivates our focus on learning both labels as well as positions over time, building into an end-to-end system which allows us not only to learn the best possible feature extractor but also obtain useful insights into how data about different entities interact together throughout the conversation. Our contributions include: We introduce Conversation-RNN: An architecture specifically designed to model interactions between multiple discourse participants using Recurrent Neural Networks; On diverse domains: Our approach is able to generalize across three domains - (1) restaurant reviews, (2) news articles, and (3) social media posts. In all cases, it outperforms strong baselines; Insightful results: We show in detail what features contribute most strongly towards the task of determining the next sentence label; Prediction accuracy versus training time: We demonstrate experimentally that predictions made by Conversation-RNN converge faster than those obtained via other models when trained under identical conditions. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 summarizes related works, including some recent advances. Sections 3 gives details regarding our proposed model, along with experimental results showing advantages compared to state-of-the-art approaches. Finally, conclusions are given in section 4. Related Work Researchers have addressed similar problems like ours before, albeit without recurrent connections. For example, (Nguyen et al., 2005) discuss several methods for predicting mutual attention scores between two sentences based upon their syntactic similarity. (Wang Jiang, 2010) propose elements for developing a transition-based dependency parser based on synchronous context-free grammars. However, these previous methods do not address aspects such as entity identification or explicit modeling of temporal relationships between events. Also unlike these earlier efforts, the current research does not require any hand-crafted linguistic rules or edit distance measures. As discussed below however, existing techniques may provide guidance toward better performing systems. Modeling Temporal Information While early attempts used linear chains (i.e., Markov Models) (Church Hanks, 1990), more complex non-linear models were later developed for various applications. For example, Hidden Markov Model (HMM) was successfully applied in speech recognition (Rabiner, 1989). Recently, Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) (Elman, 1990; Hochreiter Schmidhuber, 1997) have been widely adopted for sequence modeling because they capture long-term dependencies among inputs through hidden states. Inspired by these developments, researchers began applying them to natural language generation tasks like machine translation (Bojar et al., 2006). In contrast to such traditional uses of RNNs, which seek to generate one single output per input, the main goal of Sequence-to-Sequence Learning (SSTL) tasks is usually to extract sequential patterns rather than produce outputs directly. One popular example is presented by (Bahdanau et al., 2014a). Here authors use SSTL networks to predict human-level sentiment for English tweets. They then extend this technique to Chinese tweets using an adaptation layer (Gong, 2015). Following closely after the success of CNNs on ImageNet classification task (Krizhevsky et al., 2012), another major breakthrough in deep architectures has come recently thanks to LeCun et al.. These authors showed that convolutional layers help deal with low level visual perception tasks beyond finding edges such as object detection, segmentation, etc. By transferring knowledge learned in images to transcripts gathered from chatbots, they also revealed potential improvements to automatic evaluation metrics for spoken dialogue systems. Convolution filters operating on image signals often correspond to convolutions performed on continuous-time signals called LSTMs. Therefore, inspired by the use of dilated convolution operations (Heinrich et al., 2016), Grave et al. incorporated dilations inside the structure of their Long Short-Term Memory network (GSD-LSTM). In doing so, they achieved significantly improved performance over standard LSTMs on several benchmark tasks, (Graves et al., 2017a). More precisely, GSD-LSTM achieves a significant improvement in relation extraction since they leverage key frames extracted from the video instead of simply extracting neighboring pixels during decoding times. Further, they tackle the problem of missing tokens in real-life scenarios, e.g., in case of dialogues recorded by the microphone arrays surrounding speakers. Such situations result in discontinuous datasets meaning that labels cannot be assigned too far away from the initial ones (Etzioni et al., 2004). Inspired by the idea of incorporating time-series convolutions in order to represent time series, we apply the same concept hereafter. However, unlike other novelty-wise approaches proposed previously, we exploit additional spatial dimensions to perform joint representation of textual and graphical contents appearing in conversations. Moreover, contrary to prior experiments involving longterm memory networks dedicated solely to detecting inter-participant interaction behaviors, our analysis focuses primarily on modeling the

Recurrent Neural Networks are a type of neural network that specializes in processing sequences. A common application of RNNs is for Natural Language Processing due to its effectiveness at handling language. They also have been used in other fields such as bioinformatics and finance. Recurrent Neural Networks consist of two main parts: the input and the recurrent layer. The input layer takes in data and provides it to the recurrent layer, which then produces the output. The output of the recurrent layer is passed back to the input layer and the process repeats itself. These networks are different from Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) because they do not process images. In order to process data, you must define what the input and output are. In this example, the input is a word and the output is a set of probabilities for each of the words in the vocabulary. You also define the probability distribution over the vocabulary. You can define the loss function as the sum of the negative log-likelihood of the data. This will be the loss function that is used to train the network. When the network is trained, the gradient is calculated using the backpropagation algorithm. The gradient of the loss function is then used to update the weights in the network. The loss function and gradient are also defined for this example. Once the weights in the network are updated, the network is then trained. The weights in the network are then frozen and the network is tested on new data. This is done to prevent the network from adapting to the training data and become stuck in a local minimum. You can test the network by passing in a word. The output of the network should be close to the desired output. If the network is trained properly, the output should always be close to the desired output. Recurrent Neural Networks are a type of neural network that specializes in processing sequences. A common application of RNNs is for Natural Language Processing due to its effectiveness at handling sequential data such as text. RNNs work by passing information along a chain of neurons, where each neuron receives input from the previous neuron and outputs to the next neuron. This allows the network to maintain a "memory" of the previous inputs and the order in which they were presented. One significant advantage of RNNs is their ability to handle varying length input sequences, making them suitable for tasks such as text generation, machine translation, sentiment analysis, speech recognition, and many others. However, a common issue with RNNs is the vanishing gradient problem, which can occur when the gradients become too small, making it difficult for the network to learn long-term dependencies. To overcome this issue, various modifications to the basic RNN architecture have been developed, such as the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU), which have proven to be effective in mitigating the vanishing gradient problem while maintaining the benefits of RNNs.

Recurrent Neural Networks are a type of neural network that specializes in processing sequences. A common application of RNNs is for Natural Language Processing due to its effectiveness at handling long-range dependencies. RNNs work by taking a sequence of inputs, such as words in a sentence, and feeding them through the network one at a time. The output of the network at each step is then used as input to the next step, allowing the network to learn the relationships between words in a sentence. This allows RNNs to generate text, translate languages, and perform other natural language processing tasks.

Medusa is a headless commerce engine for creating digital commerce apps. It can be used as a backend of an app, as an application, to create traditional e-commerce websites, and also to build progressive web apps (PWAs) and mobile apps. Medusa allows you to manage products, orders, and customers, and also offers features such as payment integrations, shipping integrations, and tax calculation. It is open-source and customizable, allowing developers to create unique commerce experiences for their clients or businesses. Additionally, it offers a headless architecture, which means that the frontend of the app can be completely separated from the backend, giving developers the flexibility to use any frontend framework and design the user interface as they wish.

It's licensed under the MIT License. The source code is hosted on GitHub. The Medusa project is managed by the Medusa Community. It's an open, international community of individuals and companies dedicated to build the best headless commerce engine. Medusa is a community-driven project, and we welcome any contribution. Thousands of people protested in Belarus on the weekend over the results of the presidential election. Long-time president Alexander Lukashenko won 80 percent of the vote, extending his 26-year long rule in the former Soviet republic. About 5,000 people gathered in the capital, Minsk, to protest the election results. Lukashenko won 80 percent of the vote, the electoral commission said. That result is unlikely to be challenged in court. Protesters chanted "Down with Lukashenko!" and "Russia, Russia!" as they marched through the capital's Independence Square. Some carried signs reading "Russia, our brotherland" and "Down with Belarusian capitalism." Opposition leader Pavel Grudinin says 80 percent of the people in the country have no faith in the vote. Grudinin is the only person running against Lukashenko, who is running for a third term. He says the electoral commission's result is a "conspiracy." Russia's state-run news agency RIA-Novosti reported that the Russian embassy in Minsk has condemned the results. RIA-Novosti quoted a statement by the embassy as saying that "Russian citizens in Belarus are being subjected to undemocratic methods of election rigging." The protests came a day after a court in Minsk ruled that a candidate in the presidential race could not register to run. He said he was barred from running because he does not have a criminal record.

Thousands of people protested in Belarus on the weekend over the results of the presidential election. Long-time president Alexander Lukashenko won 80 percent of the vote, extending his 26-year long rule. Lukashenko is often called Europe's last dictator. He's known for his brutal crackdowns on protesters and the free press, as well as for what human rights advocates have called "disappearances" of political opponents. Today, you'll hear from one of the people who protested in the country's capital, Minsk, this weekend. She's a 25-year-old journalist named Maryna. She spoke with The World's Carol Hills on the line from Minsk. We're not using her last name to protect her identity. "I was in the very center of Minsk in one of the central squares. And the square was surrounded by the police, so we couldn't go anywhere. But there were some people, they were really brave, who tried to get out of the square and they were attacked by the police and were detained. "I think the election was not free and fair. The results - people are not really happy with the results of the election. The turnout was quite high, but I think it was because they were forced to vote. The public sector workers were forced to vote. "Most of them were detained for 15 days. Some of them are still kept in jail. I've heard that some of them are beaten, but I can't say anything for sure because I'm not in prison. I'm just following the news and trying to find information about my friends. "I'm not afraid because I've been on the streets for five days already, and I'm not afraid. And I know that if I'm detained, I will be released. And if not, I'm ready to stay in jail for 15 days and I'm ready to pay the fine. And I'm ready to do it for my country and for our freedom. "I don't think that it's a matter of time that Lukashenko will go away because I don't think he wants to go away. He really wants to stay in power. And he doesn't care about the people and what they want. He just wants to stay in power. And he's ready to do anything to stay in power. And he's ready to kill people. He's ready to suppress any protests, any actions. "Of course, it's not safe to live here, especially if you're a journalist. It's not safe to live here if you're a political activist. And it's not safe to live here if you're just a normal person and you want to live free. You don't want to be afraid of police and you want to be able to say what you think. You don't want to be afraid of going to jail if you're saying what you think.

This article describes a vulnerability within iCloud Sharing and Safari 15 that allowed hackers to gain unauthorized camera access on Macs. It details how the vulnerability was discovered and how it was reported to Apple, and how Apple responded. Security researcher Sabri Haddouche recently discovered a vulnerability in Safari 15 that allowed hackers to gain unauthorized access to a user's Mac webcam. The exploit would have allowed malicious actors to activate and view the webcam of a user's Mac, all without their knowledge or permission. Sabri Haddouche found the bug in the iCloud Sharing feature in Safari 15. This feature is designed to allow users to share links and webpages from Safari. The vulnerability he found allowed him to replace the shared iCloud web page with a video stream from the user's webcam. This would allow hackers to view the user's webcam feed without their knowledge or permission. Haddouche responsibly reported the vulnerability to Apple, as per Apple's security policy. The policy states that Apple will not pursue legal action against anyone who reports a bug within Apple software, provided that the individual is not maliciously using the bug. Apple responded quickly to Haddouche's report, and released a patch within 10 days to fix the bug. As of now, Apple has fixed this issue, and released the patch to all users. While the vulnerability was discovered and fixed quickly, it is important to remember that Apple products are not immune to vulnerabilities. Motor Neuron Disease eventually takes away its victim's ability to speak, but a new AI-based tool developed by Rolls-Royce may help patients speak again. Rolls Royce worked with the Motor Neurone Disease Association and the National Health Service to develop the technology. It uses AI and machine learning to analyze a patient's speech patterns and habits, then translate those patterns into written and spoken words. The tool will be made available to patients through the NHS and MND Association. It will be available to anyone with a diagnosis of MND. People with the disease will be able to create their own speech profile and then use it to help them communicate. Dr. Susie Henley, Head of Healthcare Innovation at the MND Association, said, "This breakthrough has the potential to transform the lives of people living with the disease who cannot move their arms or hands. It could mean they are able to communicate with their loved ones for the first time in many years."

Motor Neuron Disease eventually takes away its victim's ability to speak, but a new AI-based tool developed by Rolls-Royce may help patients speak again. Rolls Royce worked with the Motor Neurone Disease Association (MNDA) to create the AI tool, which is based on technology developed by the company for self-driving cars. The tool can analyse a patient's vocalisations and identify words and phrases in the speech. It can then be used to create a communication app that allows patients to communicate with their loved ones. The app is still in development, but the company says it hopes to have it ready for use by patients later this year.

Rolls Royce worked with the Motor Neurone Disease Association and technology company Cognitives to create an AI-powered speech tool that can replicate a patient's voice using just a few minutes of voice recordings. This tool can then be used to generate synthetic speech that sounds like the patient's original voice, allowing them to communicate much more easily. The tool uses machine learning algorithms to analyze the characteristics of a person's voice, including pitch, pronunciation, and tone. By using this data, the software can generate new speech that is indistinguishable from the original voice. This breakthrough technology has the potential to have a significant impact on the lives of people with Motor Neuron Disease, allowing them to maintain their independence and communicate with their loved ones even as the disease progresses. Motor Neuron Disease eventually takes away its victim's ability to speak, but a new AI-based tool developed by Rolls-Royce may help patients speak again. Rolls Royce worked with the Motor Neuron Disease Association, Intel, Microsoft, and other companies to develop Quips. Quips uses artificial intelligence in combination with voice banking to learn the unique way a user speaks. Users record clips of their speech to create a synthetic version of their voice. Quip is able to listen to conversations in real-time and suggest responses. Its responses include the same accents and colloquialisms that its users use. The system is context-aware and will switch conversation modes depending on its environment. It is unknown when Quips will be available to the public.

Motor Neuron Disease eventually takes away its victim's ability to speak, but a new AI-based tool developed by Rolls-Royce may help patients speak again. Rolls Royce worked with the Motor Learning Lab at Newcastle University and Nuffield Health in London on an algorithm that is able to read lips from video captured using smartphone cameras. The system was tested on two volunteers who were then exposed to three different scenarios - standing up straight, walking across the room and making eye contact. The results show that the AI can recognise what people are trying to say without having access to any other information about their speech such as tone of voice or body language.

Motor Neuron Disease eventually takes away its victim's ability to speak, but a new AI-based tool developed by Rolls-Royce may help patients speak again. Rolls Royce worked with the Motor Neuron Disease Association to develop the AI-based tool. The system uses a camera to monitor the facial expressions of patients. When a person is expressing a particular emotion, the system learns the associated words. This means that it can translate a person's facial expression into a corresponding word. The system then converts the word into a synthesized voice. The new AI-based system could help people with motor neuron disease and other neurodegenerative disorders, including ALS, which causes motor neurons to die. Researchers hope that the technology could eventually help people communicate with their families and loved ones. "The application of technology in medicine has evolved over the last 20 years, with an increasing number of clinical applications in use, and many more under development," said James Atkinson, director of the Rolls-Royce Human Engineering Research Center. "This project is a great example of how advances in technology can help to improve our understanding of the human condition and, ultimately, improve the quality of life for people living with conditions like motor neuron disease." This research was published in the journal Science Robotics.

Spaces is a startup with a team that specializes in virtual reality technologies. It was created in 2016 by DreamWorks Animation veterans. Spaces discontinued all of its services last week, citing a lack of consumer interest. The company had raised over $90 million in funding, but it was unable to attract enough users to its platform. Spaces offered a variety of virtual reality experiences, including games, movies, and educational content. However, the company struggled to compete with larger VR companies, such as Oculus and Vive. Spaces is a startup with a team that specializes in virtual reality technologies. It was created in 2016 by DreamWorks Animation veterans. Spaces discontinued all of its services last week, leaving a number of its users scrambling for refunds. Yesterday, we wrote about a report by The Verge that claimed a number of Spaces users were owed refunds by the company. Today, Spaces confirmed to UploadVR that it will be returning user funds to a number of users, as well as paying back a loan to the company's investor. Spaces co-founder, and former DreamWorks Animation head of business development, Frank Park, told UploadVR that he was approached by a group of investors that wanted to invest in Spaces. Park says that the investors asked for him to put up a 50,000 loan as collateral for the investment. "The investors asked for a 50,000 personal loan from me to give them a 'good faith' deposit. I borrowed the money and then the company raised more capital. When the company raised more capital, they paid me back the 50,000, but never gave me back the money that they had put up for my personal loan," Park says. Park says that he was "surprised" to hear about the company's decision to stop offering VR services to users, as the company was working on a new project called "Skyscape" and would be making money on that project. "I was very surprised to hear about the decision to discontinue services. I was working on a project called 'Skyscape' which was about to be launched and would be making money. I have since been paid back for the loan," Park says.

Is HTTP Live Streaming (HLS) Right For Me? HTTP Live Streaming (HLS) is a widely adopted streaming protocol used by many popular online video platforms like YouTube and Facebook. It's the most popular streaming format today. HLS has many advantages and is an ideal choice for streaming live video. However, it's not without some shortcomings, and not all use cases are ideal for it. In this article, we'll go over what HLS is, the pros and cons of HLS, and some use cases that are ideal for using HLS. When To Use HLS What Is HLS? HLS is a streaming protocol created by Apple that delivers video content over HTTP. It's a protocol for breaking a single video into a sequence of small HTTP-based video files. This makes it easier to deliver video content over the Internet, and allows the video to adapt to changing network conditions without stopping and restarting. When To Use HLS Live Streaming HLS has many advantages and is an ideal choice for streaming live video to most audiences. There are a few scenarios where you should consider using a different streaming protocol. Do Not Use HLS For Live Streams That Require Low Latency For some use cases, latency matters more than compatibility. Low-latency live streams are essential for use cases where you need to avoid significant delays between the live event and the live stream. The best use case for low-latency live streaming is broadcasting live sports online. The lower the latency, the more enjoyable the viewing experience. With high latency, you'll see viewers complaining in the chat and on social media about the stream being behind. HLS is not ideal for low-latency live streaming because HLS live streams have 30-40 seconds of latency. HLS streams use a technique called segmented streaming. This requires the encoder to wait to receive a segment of video before starting to stream it. HLS Live Streaming Latency In comparison, RTMP has about 3-7 seconds of latency, and RTSP has about 2 seconds of latency. If low latency is essential for your live stream, consider using a different streaming protocol such as RTMP, RTSP, or WebRTC. Do Not Use HLS For Live Streams That Require On-Demand Playback If you need to record your live stream for on-demand viewing, consider using a streaming protocol other than HLS. HLS was not designed with on-demand playback in mind. There are a few reasons for this: HLS supports adaptive bitrate streaming (ABR), but it's up to the client to choose which bitrate to use when playing back the stream. This makes it harder to use adaptive bitrate for on-demand playback. HLS segments are downloaded in a random order, so there is no way to know what bitrate to use to download the segments that come next. HLS segments are downloaded in parallel. This works great for live streams, but it's not ideal for on-demand playback. When you use HLS for on-demand playback, there will be gaps in the playback, and the stream will stop and start while waiting for segments to download. If on-demand playback is important to you, consider using a different streaming protocol. RTMP is best suited for this. Do Not Use HLS For Mobile Live Streams When you use HLS to stream to mobile devices, you must use a different method to play the stream. On iOS and Android devices, you can use HTML5 video tag with the src attribute set to the HLS stream URL. However, the HLS playback experience on mobile is not ideal. HLS playback on mobile devices has high latency and is not reliable. This is caused by mobile network instability. When the mobile network is unstable, HLS segments may not be downloaded properly. This results in playback stalls and interruptions. If you plan to stream to mobile devices, consider using a different streaming protocol like RTMP, RTSP, or WebRTC. When To Use HLS Live Streaming HLS has many advantages and is ideal for streaming live video to most audiences. HLS Is The Most Popular Streaming Format HLS is the most popular streaming format. Widespread transmission of bird flu to humans is rare, and most human cases occur after prolonged and close contact with infected birds. If someone develops flu-like symptoms after exposure to poultry or in close contact with someone confirmed to have bird flu, they should seek medical attention immediately.

We have included Xamarin.Forms to help simplify and speed up development by allowing developers to leverage the same familiar controls and techniques used to build web apps. We have added a new inspector that allows developers to see the state of their controls at a glance. For example, developers can see the state of the selected item in a ListBox or the current selection in a ComboBox. Xamarin.Forms users can take advantage of a new property that provides a strong, typed reference to the view that was just added to the UI. This allows developers to quickly access a view after adding it to the UI. We have also improved the process of adding controls to the view. Previously, adding controls to the view required a developer to set the DataContext and set the Visibility of the control to be visible. Now, a developer can simply add a control to the view and the view will automatically set the visibility of the control. Xamarin.Forms developers can also make use of new APIs to get the content of the control and to set the content of the control. The new APIs allow developers to set the content of the control and retrieve the content of the control. Additionally, we have updated the Xamarin.Forms NuGet package to include a newer version of the ReactiveUI library. ReactiveUI provides an elegant and intuitive approach to managing the state of your UI. ReactiveUI provides you with the flexibility to define your own behavior and provide it to the view, so that the view knows how to react to your state changes.

Porter is a Kubernetes-powered PaaS that runs on any cloud provider. By default, though, an additional command line interface has been created in order to configure all aspects of Swarm at once: Swarm containers are managed by hypervisors such as Rancher or Cinder depending upon what version of Linux you have installed. The SvelteKit beta is now available. SvelteKit is a framework for building high-performance web apps. It features server-side rendering, routing, code-splitting for JS and CSS, adaptors for different serverless platforms, and more. If you haven't already, head over to SvelteKit.com to sign up for the beta. SvelteKit brings the Svelte compile-time execution model to the server. In Svelte, you write your application's logic in JS. That code is then compiled to a set of plain HTML and CSS, ready to be shipped to the browser. Because the code is compiled, Svelte is able to perform a lot of optimizations. For example, if a component isn't being used on the page, Svelte is able to omit it completely. SvelteKit takes the same approach on the server. It parses your JS files, extracts the logic, and renders the result into HTML. Because SvelteKit knows exactly what the browser will need, it can optimize the server-rendered output to keep it as lightweight as possible. With server-side rendering, your web app can start rendering immediately, before the JS is downloaded and executed. This reduces the initial load time, and makes your app feel faster and more responsive. SvelteKit automatically generates bundles for your JS and CSS, including all the code your page needs to work offline. This means you don't have to manually split your code into different files. You can simply write your app as if it were a single page app. The bundles are also automatically code-split. SvelteKit will only load the code that the browser needs to render the current page. Code-splitting is important because it helps to reduce the amount of data that has to be transferred to the browser. It also makes the initial load faster, and means the browser can start executing your code sooner. Routing lets you build multiple pages using the same codebase. This lets you share code across different parts of your app, while keeping each page focused on a specific task. SvelteKit also works great for single page apps. The only difference is that all of your code is always loaded. This means there's no need for code-splitting. SvelteKit works with existing web frameworks, like Express.js. You can simply wrap your existing app with SvelteKit to take advantage of its features. If you're building a new app, or you're using a simpler framework like Koa.js, you can use the SvelteKit app generator to scaffold a new project. SvelteKit is designed to work with serverless platforms like Firebase Hosting, Vercel, Netlify, Zeit Now, or Webtask. SvelteKit adaptors make it easy to deploy your app to these platforms. They will build your app, minify and bundle your code, and upload it to your serverless provider. SvelteKit can also work with traditional web servers. This is useful if you're deploying to a platform that doesn't support serverless (e.g. AWS S3) or you prefer to control your own web server. To deploy to a traditional server, simply configure your web server to serve the correct files. You can find the file structure and instructions in the SvelteKit docs. If you're interested in trying SvelteKit, sign up for the beta on SvelteKit.com. The beta includes a code editor, compiler, and tutorial. It also includes documentation for getting started with the SvelteKit CLI and running SvelteKit on different serverless platforms. To get started, sign up for the beta, then run the sveltekit tutorial command to install the CLI and start the tutorial. Because SvelteKit is still in beta, you'll need to install it locally. It will be released publicly as soon as it's ready. You can also find the SvelteKit beta on GitHub. If you have any questions or feedback, you can join the SvelteKit beta community on Spectrum or get in touch with us on Twitter.

A team of scientists launched a box containing four types of bacteria and fungus into the stratosphere to expose them to several hours of Mars-like conditions. The experiment found that each species survived, but some suffered damage from being exposed to high temperatures. The goal was to find out how long organisms would survive when subjected to similar conditions as those on another planet for around an hour or so. "As we think about colonizing other worlds in space or deep inside our bodies and even more closely related environments like groundwater reservoirs, this kind of information is critical," said Peter Crutzen, professor at UCLA's Department of Earth and Space Science who led the study which appears today in a scientific journal Nature Geoscience. "The question now is: What can you do if there are no life-supporting molecules? Can it work without a lot of added carbon dioxide? We know that microbes have evolved over billions of years with very different lifestyles - most living under water where oxygen does not exist much after its creation by volcanic activity. But sometimes they also live in surface rocks. To see what could happen here, we decided to put all these creatures together and observe their behavior," he explained. These microorganisms were selected because they already inhabit many natural niches packed full of nutrients such as soil or rocky floors in underground water wells: Bacteria forms a network of filaments known as biofilms composed of thousands of tiny cells (called cocci) trapped within extracellular polymeric substances;

A team of researchers have genetically modified jellyfish so that their neurons light up when activated. This allowed them to watch the animal's neural activity as it behaved naturally. Jellyfish are not only among the most beautiful animals on the planet, they are also some of the most complex, and also one of the easiest to genetically modify. The new jellyfish study is a case study in this. Researchers at the Salk Institute and the University of California San Diego have genetically modified the animals so that they light up when neurons are activated. This allows researchers to see the neural activity of the jellyfish as they swim around, mate, and search for food. The findings were published in the journal Nature Methods. This is an incredible advance, as the light activation of neurons is far more sensitive and specific than other techniques, such as calcium imaging. The new technique is extremely sensitive, and the scientists are able to see neural activity in single neurons. This could help us to better understand how different neural circuits work, as well as help us to better understand diseases that cause changes in neural circuits, such as autism, depression, and schizophrenia. In this case, the researchers have been able to use the jellyfish to study a neural circuit that controls the rhythmic motion of the animal's body. This circuit is used to move the jellyfish, and researchers have found that it is involved in some mental disorders. "These circuits are very important for animal locomotion," said researcher Dr. William Schwab, the principle investigator of the study. "The work has been highly anticipated by neuroscientists and we are very excited to see the results." The research could also help us to understand how certain drugs and chemicals can affect the neural activity of the animal. "These new tools will allow us to ask questions that have been vexing neuroscientists for decades," said Dr. Schwab. "They have the potential to fundamentally change the way we study neural circuits and behaviors in vertebrates, and we are very excited about their applications."

"Although I am always skeptical because we could never prove what neuron X responded too without somehow destroying function (which would eliminate any chance you had even knowing which cell gave off signals), [this paper] adds some very nice evidence here showing where groups respond differently than isolated animals...and then links particular cells back through behavioral experiments making me believe there's something worth looking into further down an experimental roadmap.

Zoom has bought security start-up Keybase, which will allow it to implement end-to-end encryption in its meetings. Users will not be able to call into encrypted meetings via phone, and will need to be using Zoom Meetings or Keybase's desktop software. Keybase's smartphone app will continue to be available, but will only allow users to send and receive encrypted messages. Keybase's 30-person team will join Zoom. Keybase has just received a lot of cash to help grow its service. The company, which offers encrypted messaging and file sharing, was acquired by Zoom on Friday. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but CEO Max Krohn told CNET that the acquisition would allow the service to grow faster. "It was not an easy decision to sell, but ultimately we wanted to execute on the vision of bringing encryption to the masses and we thought this was the best way to do it," Krohn said. Keybase allows people to use encryption without needing to be technically savvy. The service uses a phone number as a user's public identifier, and people can then share files and chat securely. "We're going to be able to invest a lot more in building out the vision of the service," Krohn said. The company was founded in 2014 by Chris Coyne and Nathaniel Popper, and is based in New York. Krohn said that all 30 employees, including Coyne, will move to San Jose, California, where Zoom is based.

Zoom has bought security start-up Keybase, which will allow it to implement end-to-end encryption in its meetings. Users will not be able to call into encrypted meetings via phone, and will be required to use their Zoom app or web browser. End-to-end encryption means that only the sender and recipient of a message can read it, and no one in between, including Zoom, can see it.

Zoom has bought security start-up Keybase, which will allow it to implement end-to-end encryption in its meetings. Users will not be able to call into encrypted meetings via phone, and calls are only secure by the device on which they're made. The agreement is expected to close next week for an undisclosed sum. The deal brings Zoom's offering closer to Microsoft Teams as well as Slack, Google Meet or Google Hangouts. Keybase's CEO Deni Pharoah told CNBC it's a critical step that allows his company to make sure all of their customers' personal data is protected when using the platform: "We've been working closely with Zoom since we started our journey together almost two years ago - in fact, before COVID-19 hit us like everyone else around the world did back then."

(Mercedes-Benz) "We have defined the pedestrian as a priority in our vehicle in the event of an accident," Mercedes-Benz said in a statement. "The priority is granted to the human, the driver, but the system can intervene at any time and can decide to prioritize the other party." This has been the subject of much debate in the US over the last year, with the government's auto safety agency stating that autonomous vehicles would have to treat all human drivers as the highest priority. But the German automaker's statement on Tuesday suggests that the government's stance on this issue is on the verge of change. "At present, the German federal government is not yet considering whether to treat the autonomous vehicle as a third party in the event of an accident," Mercedes-Benz said.
