What we're learning about Coronavirus' impact on ridesharing and delivery services We asked experts about how ridesharing and delivery services are responding to the coronavirus pandemic. Here's what they had to say: Coronavirus is having a profound impact on these companies and the people who work for them, says Molly Levinson, a professor at the University of Maryland School of Business. "I think it's going to have a huge impact on these companies," Levinson says. "We're already seeing cancellations of reservations, cancellations of appointments, cancellations of orders, cancellations of deliveries, cancellations of rides. I think it's going to be a real challenge." In terms of ridesharing, she says that it's not just cancellations that are taking a toll. The surge in people trying to get rides is creating a lot of demand for drivers. "We're seeing a lot of drivers quitting," she says. "A lot of drivers are having to take on second jobs just to make ends meet." "This is going to have a huge impact on these companies." - Molly Levinson, University of Maryland School of Business Uber says it has about 25,000 drivers in the U.S. and Canada, and more than 3,000 drivers in Europe. "It's a tremendous impact on drivers," says Debra Borchardt, the senior director of communications at Uber. "We're looking at how we can support them. We're working with our drivers to ensure they are safe and healthy, that they have the right supplies, that they have the tools to continue to work. And we're also working with drivers to make sure that they're getting paid." But even as the impact on drivers is profound, there are opportunities to provide support to these workers, she says. "We're going to be focusing on a lot of different things that we can do to help our drivers," she says. "But we know that this is going to have a huge impact on these companies." "The way I think about it is that these companies are going to need to come up with a new business model," says Levinson. "They are going to need to adapt, and they're going to need to be able to think about how they can use the drivers as their asset. I think the most important thing for them to do is to make sure that drivers are safe and healthy, that they're getting paid, that they're getting the supplies they need to continue to work." What about delivery services? Delivery services like Uber Eats and DoorDash are seeing an uptick in demand for food delivery, says Jeremy Lappe, the managing director of consumer and media for Postmates. The most popular items, Lappe says, are hand sanitizer, toilet paper, and toilet paper-related products. "We're seeing an uptick in demand for food delivery." - Jeremy Lappe, managing director of consumer and media for Postmates "We're seeing an uptick in demand for food delivery, and for hand sanitizer," he says. "We're seeing demand for hand sanitizer, toilet paper, and toilet paper-related products." DoorDash says that delivery drivers are also seeing a surge in demand for food and grocery delivery. "It's a huge time of need for our community and for our drivers," says DoorDash spokesperson Chris Roberts. "We are in close communication with our team members and ensuring they have the supplies they need to keep doing their jobs safely." He says that DoorDash has also made its platform available for local governments to use to provide supplies to residents. "We have many partners in the market, and we are able to help provide those supplies," he says. "We're happy to help." Postmates says it is working with retailers to bring more goods to people's doors. "We are working with local retailers and other delivery companies to get goods delivered to people's doors," says Postmates spokesperson Jordan Zubik. "We have the ability to make a significant impact by providing delivery of grocery and other essential goods." She says that the company has not seen any significant increase in demand for food delivery.

Pulse is a logging system for Apple Platforms. It records logs locally and they never leave the device. Screenshots of Pulse running on various Apple devices are available in the attached document. This is not a tutorial on how to use Pulse, but rather a list of what features are available and how to access them. It also contains some code examples to help you get started. I have included a list of Apple's supported platforms and devices. The platform and device list is likely to change, so I recommend you use this document as a reference, rather than a hard and fast list. As a general rule, the smaller the device, the more features are supported. For example, a MacBook Pro running Mac OS X 10.7 (Lion) supports all features, while a Mac Mini running 10.6 (Snow Leopard) does not support some of the more advanced features. As of 2010, Pulse is supported on Mac OS X 10.6 (Snow Leopard) and 10.7 (Lion).

Pulse is a logging system for Apple Platforms. It records logs locally and they never leave the device. Screenshots of Pulse running on various Apple devices are available in the GitHub repository. The current implementation uses GraphQL to create RESTful endpoints that clients can use to retrieve data from different categories within the iOS logstore database, including battery usage by application type (maps or web), Wi-Fi and Bluetooth connections using mac address ranges instead of IP addresses. A diagram depicting how the app architecture works with sessions being managed at two levels - iCloud and local machine On the client side, each page has its own session context which allows it to have multiple HTTP requests per user while maintaining state between them. For example, when a user opens their browser's DevTools console, logs into our server-side login service, then opens another tab in Chrome, we don't want this extra interaction added to their browsing history if previous pages were also logged into the same account (e.g., one other Tab). This way we ensure only apps that set up sessions at level 1 will be able to access those sessions' cookies; all others must wait until after logging out before accessing any stored cookie information. At the backend there are three types of sessions: Session ID1 represents a single authentication event where you register your usernamepassword on an app or website first, receive a session token, and start getting logged-in notifications. Sessions IDs 2 3 represent additional events where you get authenticated once but no longer need to provide username password information every time you request content from a siteapp.

The Human Pangenome Project aims to gather, organize, and make accessible a representation of all genetic diversity found in people. The data could help reveal information about genetic risk for diseases and disorders. An unprecedented international effort to describe the genetic landscape of human populations could lay the groundwork for a better understanding of the genetic risk factors for diseases and disorders. In 2000, the Human Genome Project (HGP) provided the reference genome sequence for the species Homo sapiens. But this sequence, assembled from the DNA of a handful of individuals, is just one version of the human genome. In fact, every person has a unique genome, containing a distinctive set of DNA variants that help to shape their individuality. The Human Pangenome Project aims to gather, organize, and make accessible a representation of all genetic diversity found in people. The project aims to collect DNA from 200 or more different populations representing the world's ethnic and geographic groups. The aim is to capture the genetic diversity of the world's populations and enable better estimates of the frequency of variants and haplotypes. This will help researchers understand how often certain types of genetic changes occur, and which are relatively rare. The project will also attempt to identify genetic sequences that may be related to the development of common diseases. Researchers will sequence the genomes of 500 individuals from each of 200 or more different populations representing the world's ethnic and geographic groups. A preliminary list of populations has been prepared, but it is expected to change as the project evolves. The project will also attempt to identify genetic sequences that may be related to the development of common diseases. The Human Pangenome Project will be an open-access project, with its data available to researchers and the public. The Human Pangenome Project is a collaborative project that involves many scientists from around the world.

A Tesla Model S owner is suing the company because his Tesla crashed into a Ford Fiesta in the next lane "suddenly, and without any warning" at 80mph when he was attempting to change lanes. The driver, Gary Smith, claims the crash happened in November 2016 when he was driving on the A46 near Coventry, England. Smith says he was attempting to change lanes when his Tesla accelerated suddenly and without warning, causing him to lose control of the vehicle. The Tesla then collided with the Ford Fiesta, which was driving in the next lane. Smith says he was not injured in the crash, but the driver of the Ford Fiesta suffered minor injuries. Smith is suing Tesla for negligence, claiming that the company's Autopilot system was responsible for the crash. The company says that Smith was not paying attention to the road when he attempted to change lanes, and that he was driving too fast. The case is still pending.

A Tesla Model S owner is suing the company because his Tesla crashed into a Ford Fiesta in the next lane "suddenly, and without any warning" at 80mph when he was driving on the highway, according to the lawsuit. "Defendant Tesla's battery packs are prone to spontaneously ignite due to overheating andor electrical shorts," the suit states. The suit also alleges that Tesla is "well aware" of this problem, but has "refused" to address it. "Defendant Tesla was aware or should have been aware of the risk of battery fires in its vehicles and failed to take reasonable measures to protect drivers of its vehicles or to disclose the risk of battery fires andor to provide adequate warning to drivers," it states. Tesla claims that the car's Autopilot software was engaged when the crash occurred. The suit claims that Tesla's Autopilot feature "does not comply with the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards," but does not give a reason why. The lawsuit seeks monetary damages of at least 5 million. Tesla has not yet responded to Business Insider's request for comment. Cymbospondylus youngorum may have been the first giant animal that ever lived on Earth. The new type of ichthyosaur was discovered in the Augusta Mountains of Nevada with a skull measuring over 9 feet in length. With estimated total lengths of up to 50 feet, Cymbospondylus youngorum would have been an apex predator in the oceans during the Middle Triassic period (about 240 million years ago). Its large size, powerful jaws, and sharp teeth allowed it to hunt a variety of prey, including fish, squid, and smaller marine reptiles. It is fascinating to learn about the impressive creatures that roamed the Earth in the past.

The name refers to the fact that the animal lived in the "Cymbospondylus" age, which lasted about 100 million years and is followed by the "Ichthyosauria" age. The specimen is dated at about 115 million years ago. In addition to its enormous size, the species is notable for having an extremely large brain. Cymbospondylus youngorum may have been the first giant animal that ever lived on Earth. The new type of ichthyosaur was discovered in the Augusta Mountains of Nevada with a skull fragment and an almost complete body, all preserved in fossilized form - making it one of only two giant reptiles known to science. The head bones were found by geologist Richard Nixon and paleontologists Jay Haley Jr., Ian Witmer and Mary Lee Ellis at Gypsum Peak (45), while the lower jaw is from a location called Jelly Roll Canyon (28). Both sites are near Silver City, Nevada, about 110 miles southeast of Las Vegas, home to the largest casino in the country. "It's really just amazing what we've uncovered here at these localities," said David Benson, an assistant professor of vertebrate paleontology at Utah State University who helped create the rendering above along with John Clark, another graduate student there working under Dr. Witmer. "There really aren't many places like this where you can find so much material that's both well-preserved and within such a short geographic distance." Fossilization rates vary greatly depending on how quickly life changes after death - which part of the organism sticks around for longer, and what other organisms got in its way during decomposition. Some parts remain stable over thousands or even millions of years, but others decompose faster than expected due to microbes' ability to break down their organic molecules into water and carbon dioxide.

Cymbospondylus youngorum may have been the first giant animal that ever lived on Earth. The new type of ichthyosaur was discovered in the Augusta Mountains of Nevada with a skull measuring 2 meters long. It existed around 246 million years ago. Ichthyosaurs dominated the oceans for about 150 million years, with some species stretching over 20 meters long. The new ichthyosaur was not the largest of its family, but it may have been the largest animal Earth had seen up until that point. A picture of the skull, with a researcher for scale, is available in the article.

Cymbospondylus youngorum may have been the first giant animal that ever lived on Earth. The new type of ichthyosaur was discovered in the Augusta Mountains of Nevada with a skull that was 2.5 feet long and weighed more than 2,000 pounds. It is the largest ichthyosaur ever found and lived about 290 million years ago. The species is named after paleontologist Charles W. Young, who discovered it in 1902.

Cymbospondylus youngorum may have been the first giant animal that ever lived on Earth. The new type of ichthyosaur was discovered in the Augusta Mountains of Nevada with a skull that is 1.4m long (5ft). The skull is just 40cm (1ft 4in) short of the largest known ichthyosaur skull. It is still not known how long the body of the animal was but it is estimated to be as long as 7m (23ft). Ichthyosaurs were marine reptiles that lived in the Triassic and Jurassic periods between 245 million and 145 million years ago. They resembled dolphins or porpoises and were carnivores. They were the top predators of their time and diversified into a number of different species. Cymbospondylus youngorum, first discovered in 2013, is the oldest and largest of the known species of ichthyosaurs. Its remains were found in the Triassic period rock deposits that were about 245 million years old. Based on the shape of its skull, scientists think that Cymbospondylus youngorum may have been the first ichthyosaur to have developed the large teeth that all ichthyosaurs have. The teeth were used for catching and eating prey and not for breaking the shells of sea creatures. The new species was named after Shon and Judy Young, who were the owners of the land where the fossil was found. The Youngs have been supporters of the study of paleontology, a science that studies ancient life on Earth. Researchers are excited about the find since the discovery of Cymbospondylus youngorum is the earliest evidence that ichthyosaurs had evolved their unique characteristics.

Researchers have discovered a new Linux backdoor called Symbiote that uses novel evasion techniques to conceal its presence. It is able to scrub any sign of infection from the file system and run a modified version of itself. The malware was first spotted in October 2017, but researchers have not been able to pinpoint the initial infection vector. Symbiote relies on the rsync command to install itself on a system. This can be achieved through a malicious .rpm file or by exploiting a Linux system via an SSH vulnerability. The Symbiote binary then executes a set of commands to gather information about the infected system and execute additional commands. The malware is able to hide its presence on the infected system by modifying the timestamps of the etcrsyncd.conf file and by rewriting etccron.drsync-update. This allows Symbiote to operate as a legitimate cron job and avoid detection by anti-virus software. In addition, Symbiote hides itself from forensic analysis by scrubbing any traces of its presence from the file system.

Researchers have discovered a new Linux backdoor called Symbiote that uses novel evasion techniques to conceal its presence. It is able to scrub any sign of infection from the file system, not even by using sophisticated forensic analysis. The malware can be detected only in rare cases when it infiltrates an unpatched OS kernel and installs itself as driver modules with root privileges on systems running Windows 10 or Apple macOS. The researchers found such instances of Symbiote infections on Windows 7 machines running x86 (x8664) architectures. In addition to hiding their existence, the hackers also make use of subtle scripts embedded within files for users' convenience. "You would go to your favorite site like YouTube... And you see this ad pop up saying 'We are ready to help! We will send you all kinds of money and gifts ...' You click through," said one researcher. It's just annoying!" wrote another user who had installed the same version of unknown software on his computer without knowing what exactly he was doing.

Researchers have discovered a new Linux backdoor called Symbiote that uses novel evasion techniques to conceal its presence. It is able to scrub any sign of infection from the file system and its malware is encrypted to evade detection. The backdoor has been used in cyberattacks on targets in the financial industry, according to Check Point. The malware uses a two-stage process. First it creates a temporary backdoor with minimal functions that gathers information on the targeted system. "It scans the host's network configuration, creates a list of installed processes, checks if it's running on a virtual machine (VM) and sends it all back to the command and control (CC) server," Check Point researchers wrote in a blog post. The server then sends a second-stage payload, which the researchers dubbed "the Symbiote," that supports a wide range of malicious functions including keylogging, downloading and running other malware, and taking screenshots. "This second stage of the infection, Symbiote, is encrypted with a password that is unique to the victim, and is packed with a custom packer to avoid detection. Symbiote uses its own encryption scheme and doesn't download the decryption key from the CC, thus evading detection by anti-malware tools," the researchers said. The attackers also use a unique password for each target, which makes it more difficult to detect a common infection and helps it bypass antivirus. The researchers said they first discovered the malware in a targeted attack on the financial sector in Italy. The initial infection was found in a software package used by Italian companies to process salaries. "The first stage backdoor was included in a software package used for processing salaries and managing other payments for employees. The software was created by an Italian company, but it appears that it was compromised and infected with the backdoor without the knowledge of the developers," the researchers said. They said the first stage backdoor was disguised as a DLL file and was downloaded from the developer's website to the targeted computer. "The backdoor's malicious DLL file was signed with a legitimate certificate, stolen from a company called 'Innovative Solutions' from Jordan," the researchers said. They said once the DLL was installed, the backdoor would collect information on the targeted system and send it to the CC server. It then downloads the Symbiote payload from the CC. "The malware operators are using a unique password for each victim to avoid detection by anti-malware tools, and to allow the attackers to remotely control each victim separately, without the risk of accidentally running a command on all the infected machines simultaneously," the researchers said. They said the malware operators use a custom CC infrastructure that contains several IP addresses controlled by different domains, all pointing to the same server. "The attackers create a new server for each new victim, and once they've finished controlling the victim, they stop using the CC server, and abandon the IP address," the researchers said. Check Point said the malware was also used in targeted attacks on the financial sector in Japan and Hong Kong.

A Belgian research group discovered a major security flaw in the keyless entry system of the Tesla Model X. The attack uses a device built from a Raspberry Pi computer and an antenna to intercept the signal between the key and the car. The signal allows the car to be opened and driven away without a key. This method can be done at a distance of up to 20 feet. Tesla has responded to this security flaw, and has stated that they have changed the keyless entry system so that the key must be in range in order for the car to start. Tesla has patched the problematic keyless entry system with a new software update, so that the key has to be in range for the car to start.

A Belgian research group discovered a major security flaw in the keyless entry system of the Tesla Model X. The attack uses a device built from a Raspberry Pi computer to mimic the signals sent from the car's key fob, allowing an attacker to unlock and start the vehicle without the owner's knowledge. The group, called CCC Belgium, presented their findings at the Chaos Communication Congress in Leipzig, Germany, on December 28, 2018. They said that they were able to exploit a vulnerability in the Tesla's wireless keyless entry system to gain access to the vehicle. To carry out the attack, the researchers built a device that mimicked the signals sent from the car's key fob. The device was placed near the car and sent a signal to the vehicle that it was being unlocked by the owner. The car then unlocked and allowed the researchers to drive away. CCC Belgium said that the vulnerability could be exploited by anyone with access to a Raspberry Pi computer and a few electronic components. They urged Tesla to fix the vulnerability as soon as possible. Tesla has not yet responded to the researchers' findings.

A Belgian research group discovered a major security flaw in the keyless entry system of the Tesla Model X. The attack uses a device built from a Raspberry Pi computer and a USB camera to access the vehicle's on-board diagnostic port and record keystrokes and other sensitive information, researchers said. They detailed the security flaw in a paper presented at the Black Hat security conference in Las Vegas. The attack can be carried out by an attacker who's already in the vicinity of the vehicle and has access to a physical key, the researchers said. It is not possible to exploit the flaw remotely over the Internet, they added. "It is a major issue for Tesla owners," said Kevin Beaumont, an expert on vehicle security and author of the Car Hacker's Handbook. "I don't think there is any company that is immune to that." Tesla said it is working on a software update that will address the vulnerability. It is not clear when the update will be available, the company said. "Tesla is aware of a potential security issue that impacts some Model X vehicles. The company is working to resolve the issue and we are taking steps to notify affected customers," Tesla said in a statement. "Tesla is committed to the highest level of security for our vehicles and we take our responsibility to protect the safety of our customers seriously." The flaw is present in the latest Model X cars, which were delivered in the second half of 2016, Tesla said. The attack could allow an attacker to gain access to the vehicle's keyless entry system and unlock doors, start the engine and enter the vehicle, the researchers said. It is possible that the attacker could even use the same method to enter a Tesla with a driver already in the vehicle, they added. The attack can be carried out by plugging a Raspberry Pi computer into the vehicle's diagnostic port, said Kevin Dinh, a researcher at the Belgian security firm Synopsys. He used a Model X that was not his own. The Raspberry Pi then records the keystrokes, sends them to the attacker's computer and captures images sent to the vehicle's on-board camera. It can also monitor the vehicle's keyless entry system, allowing the attacker to open doors and start the engine, the researchers said. The researchers were able to do this because Tesla vehicles contain a "shadow" key fob, which is used to access the car and unlock doors. When a user taps the fob, a radio signal is sent to a vehicle. The shadow key fob is stored on a chip on the vehicle's diagnostic port, which is accessible by the Raspberry Pi. Tesla vehicles also contain a "real" key fob that can be used to start the car and unlock doors. The shadow key fob can be programmed to act like the real key fob, which is why the researchers were able to exploit it, the researchers said.

The FCC has approved Amazon's application for 3,236 low-Earth orbit satellites for its Project Kuiper broadband service. Project Kuiper aims to deliver high-speed, low-latency broadband to areas without good internet service. The satellites will orbit at altitudes of 590km, 610km, and 630km, providing much faster latencies than traditional satellite services orbiting at 35,000km. Amazon has six years to launch 50 percent of the satellites and will have to launch all approved satellites by July 30, 2029. It will offer service to customers once the first 578 satellites are launched. The service will cover customers in the US and other regions in the world.

The FCC has approved Amazon's application for 3,236 low-Earth orbit satellites for its Project Kuiper broadband service. Project Kuiper aims to deliver high-speed, low-latency broadband to areas without good internet connectivity. The service is expected to launch in 2022. Amazon has been working on Project Kuiper for several years, and the FCC approval is a major milestone for the project. The company has already launched two test satellites, and it plans to launch a constellation of 3,236 satellites in total. Project Kuiper will compete with other satellite broadband services such as SpaceX's Starlink and OneWeb. However, Amazon has a number of advantages over its competitors, including its financial resources and its experience in the e-commerce and cloud computing businesses. If successful, Project Kuiper could help to close the digital divide and provide high-speed internet access to people in remote areas around the world.

There is a gene that codes for a protein called cytochrome P450, which exists in many mammals' livers, helping them clean up toxins. Scientists spliced this gene from a rabbit's DNA into the DNA of a potato, and created the GM "New Leaf" potato, which has the ability to produce this protein. This protein cleans up the insecticide, Bt, which exists in nature, and is harmless to humans, but is toxic to insects. Since Bt is naturally occurring, it is allowed in organic farming. The GM potato produces its own Bt, which kills the insects that try to eat it. The New Leaf Potato is a type of pesticide producing potato, which produces Bt toxin, a natural occurring insecticide that is allowed in organic farming. This is not what is meant by the term "frankenfood." GM potatoes are not a part of the "frankenfood" controversy, since they aren't genetically engineered to do something that is not found in nature, and they do not affect the DNA of humans. New Leaf Potato: from this website. Labels: cytochrome P450, DNA, frankenfood, GM, GM potato, New Leaf, potato

There is a gene that codes for a protein called cytochrome P450, which exists in many mammals' livers, helping them clean up toxins. Scientists spliced this gene from a rabbit's liver into the human gene used to code for CYP2D6 and inserted it into mice. Then they created transgenic rabbits where half of their liver had been replaced with this hybrid mouse axon (and blood cells). The new animal looked like one normal rabbit but was missing its heart: it's not pumping blood because part of the heart has gone elsewhere. It also stopped producing another gene product needed by its brain for memory formation synapsin-1 so it could no longer remember anything. A: Yes The nerve tissue can divide, grow, and migrate. This isn't something only humans are capable of doing, though we have a much better understanding of how our brains work than other animals do. A neuron derived from any species (even an opossum) should be able to differentiate enough to become functional. From here on I will use "blob" as synonymous to somite-derived neurons or neurons formed through adult neurogenesis, since that's what my source says.

There is a gene that codes for a protein called cytochrome P450, which exists in many mammals' livers, helping them clean up toxins. Scientists spliced this gene from a rabbit's genome into a houseplant, and it began detoxifying the surrounding air, leaching carcinogens like chloroform and benzene out of the air. Synthetic biologist Patrick Shih says "We're still in the early stages of what we can do with engineered plants...this could be a very cool application to make the household less dangerous."

There is a gene that codes for a protein called cytochrome P450, which exists in many mammals' livers, helping them clean up toxins. Scientists spliced this gene from a rabbit's liver into a lettuce plant, creating a new genetically modified (GM) lettuce variety. The idea behind this genetic modification was to make the lettuce plants produce the same protein as rabbits and help remove toxins from the environment.

There is a gene that codes for a protein called cytochrome P450, which exists in many mammals' livers, helping them clean up toxins. Scientists spliced this gene from a rabbit's genome into mice. Mice lacking the gene for the protein are susceptible to chemically induced tumors. So, mice were bred that lacked this gene and then a chemical that causes liver cancer was given to them. The scientists found that those mice developed cancer 20 times faster than the normal mice. And the gene-spliced mice were protected from the cancer. "In the case of a gene-edited animal," says Francis Collins, director of the National Institutes of Health, "it would be critical to be sure that you could select the animals in which you've edited the gene in such a way that you have an animal that is deficient in the gene and then have an animal that is normal in that gene. And the key here is that you have to be sure that you've really eliminated the gene." That's exactly what the team at Oxford University is doing with CRISPR. They used a different gene, which codes for a protein that helps in the process of DNA repair, to prevent the animals from developing cancer. They inserted a version of the gene that would not be expressed. When they bred the mice, they found that they had developed tumors, but the tumors were significantly smaller than in the mice that did not have the gene inserted. "The fact that you can induce cancer in mice without having the gene, and then you can introduce the gene and eliminate the cancer, suggests that you can use this approach to develop safe gene-edited animals that will help in our understanding of cancer," says Collins. "We're going to learn a lot from this research." Technically Literate: Original works of short fiction with unique perspectives on tech, exclusively on CNET.

Android 10 will start rolling out to devices starting with the Pixel phones, including the Pixel 1. The update will include fully gestural navigation, full support for a dark mode, improved privacy controls, and more. Google announced the new version of its mobile operating system at its annual developer conference in May. The company said that Android 10 is the "most significant update" to the platform in years. The update includes a number of new features, including:  A new gesture-based navigation system that replaces the traditional three-button navigation bar.  A dark mode that can be enabled to reduce eye strain at night.  Improved privacy controls that allow users to more easily control how their data is used.  New features for developers, such as a new way to manage permissions and a new way to build apps for multiple devices. Android 10 is expected to be released to all compatible devices in the coming weeks.

Researchers from Columbia University have established a method for growing human hair in a dish using 3D printing without the need for implantation into human skin. The method uses a special cell culture medium that is printed on top of an agarose gel, which then allows cells to grow and form hairs. The team studied stem cells derived from adult scalp tissue - one type called keratinocytes. The researchers discovered that these cells can reproduce themselves into different types of specialized cells such as melanocyte or fibroblast within three days when they were cultured on a polycaprolactone plastic scaffold. However, if they are cultured directly onto 2D surfaces like glass or plastic dishes, their proliferation rate slows down drastically. To replicate this process, the scientists used inkjet technology to print a layered structure called hydrogel platelet construct (HPC) with two layers: a base gel and a seeding layer made up of keratinocyte-specific protein fibers. They observed several differences between the HPCs grown under standard conditions versus those grown in vitro inside tissues where there was less space available: When cultured outside an intact body organ, epidermal growth factor receptor expression increased by 20 times compared with traditional cultures;

SvgPathEditor is an in-browser SVG path editor. Users can use the controls to specify a path or create an image using the graphical interface. Paths can be easily copied to other applications as well. The application provides remote access, and allows users with local network connectivity to edit paths in real time from any computer connected to their workgroup's LAN. The suite also includes tools for manipulating images e.g., resizing and rotating them. These features make it possible to apply vector graphics easily by hand rather than via complicated software packages such as Adobe Illustrator. Image editing capabilities include cropping, scaling, exporting files to various formats including TIFF (Tagged Image File Format) and JPEG (Joint Photographic Experts Group), etc. History In 2001, Rational introduced the Vector Graphics Interface technology that enabled developers to write programs to interact directly with VML browser objects without having to translate between XML and JavaScript. In 2006 they began transitioning away from this proprietary solution toward the W3C Javascript specification of canvas elements which has been more widely adopted across browsers since then. This led to changes in version numbers on the Rational Web site; now the first two digits are changed from 0 to 1, while the third remains unchanged at 2. Rational moved its developer support forum over to StackOverflow earlier this year that will give web designers better insight into software trends. Rivian's network of Level 3 fast DC chargers will be accessible to nearly every other EV on the road. And that's just in America. Other countries are also working hard to get their infrastructure up and running - Volkswagen said today it would add more than 500 charging points across Europe, Japan and India by 2021; BMW plans to install 1 million charging points for its i3 electric cars; Audi is investing 1 billion (1.16bn) into battery storage so that customers can charge at home from a nearby power socket or public rapid-charging point. All this means it's time to think about how you might swap your conventional petrol-powered car with an electric vehicle. Here we take a look at what each makes us do differently... As well as being less noisy and having no oil-fumes scraping against our windows when we're driving, there isn't much else these vehicles make us different... but some things can't always be changed! 'Electric cars don't have exhaust pipes! I guess I'll never miss them': Another thing not many people realise about plug-in hybrids like the Nissan Leaf is that they do breathe through their wheels - in fact the noise they're making while accelerating inside town is actually louder because there's lots going on underneath those seats. But even though all hybrid models produce lower emissions thanks to regenerative braking technology, the way the engine works only allows the car to use its lithium-ion batteries if you're driving long distances quickly enough, otherwise you'll need regular gas breaks. On average this could mean choosing between needing to drive twice as far and using half as much fuel or spending two hours travelling four times faster due to reduced stopping distance - which sounds better? The Mercedes-Benz EQC has been criticised recently after one reviewer wrote: "It feels like I'm sitting on top of an airliner right now." It was another comparison driver who noticed the differences in handling, too, commenting: "The response is slower and the steering wheel needs to be used harder to turn corners. But once you've got used to it, particularly when overtaking, you find yourself enjoying its precision and maneuverability."

Rivian's network of Level 3 fast DC chargers will be accessible to nearly every other EV on the road. Rivian, the Michigan-based startup electric vehicle manufacturer that was recently awarded 350 million in investment capital from Amazon, is working with the U.S. utility Clean Energy Fuels Corp to build an "electric vehicle charging network for the masses" that will be accessible to nearly every other EV on the road. As part of the deal, Rivian will purchase some of Clean Energy's existing high-powered DC chargers, which are currently available to fuel cell-powered trucks and buses. Rivian's newly acquired chargers, which can charge batteries at more than 350 kW, will be modified to operate at speeds compatible with Rivian's planned EV offerings (the company's Rivian R1T truck is expected to have a range of 400 miles). Clean Energy, meanwhile, will continue to build and support the network, which it plans to expand into the largest network of Level 3 fast chargers across the United States, capable of supporting nearly every model of EV on the road. Clean Energy will also provide its natural gas and RNG vehicle fueling services at the stations. "We believe that the future of EV charging lies both in expanding the charging infrastructure and in partnering with other forward-thinking companies to jointly develop innovative new business models that transcend the limitations of outdated infrastructure," Rivian CEO R.J. Scaringe said in a statement. "This agreement to provide easy access to Clean Energy's network of fast chargers is another step in our journey toward enabling the widespread adoption of sustainable mobility." The new network of chargers will be located at existing Clean Energy stations, as well as at selected retail and fleet locations across the country. Stations will be installed in high-traffic corridors to provide ease of access to both retail and commercial EV drivers. Rivian, which made headlines when it debuted its R1T at the LA Auto Show last November, says it plans to begin deliveries of its electric vehicle lineup in 2020. Solid is a new decentralized internet designed by Sir Tim Berners-Lee, who is credited with inventing the original internet. As far as I can tell (I am very dumb, so you have to excuse me), it works like this. Users log into their personal accounts at pub servers using web browsers or some other interface. They then claim directories in which they live and receive access keys for that directory. When someone else wants to send them something, he sends his concern along an encrypted channel; when another user receives such a message, it becomes visible only if both of those users are within range of each other's public key. (You would probably need to be able to verify identities somehow.) This might seem complicated but it's actually quite simple. The most important part is encryption: set your publicprivate key pair on a machine somewhere - lets say on a file server accessible over HTTP protocol - and you're done. No special software needs to be installed wherever you're logging in from any more than what you'd normally install on all machines anyway. That means everyone has access to anything that's stored there, including private documents. A: Yes, absolutely. There are lots of ways to do this. One way is called Pretty Good Privacy. Another way involves making sure nobody knows your unique identifier number either through one-time passwords, or random numbers generated locally in every user's computer. Solid is a new decentralized internet designed by Sir Tim Berners-Lee, who is credited with inventing the original internet. As far as I can tell (I am very dumb, so please take a look for yourself if you're interested), the goal here is to create a new set of internet protocols that allows users to remain in control of their own data. For example, if you had a note taking app today that needed to sync data across multiple devices, a service like Google Docs or Evernote or whatever would run a central server in the cloud, and all of your devices would request data from and send data to the central cloud server when you wanted to take notes. In this new internet, you would run your own Solid POD (basically just a server I think?) and Solid would define a set of protocols for you to grant readwrite access to your Solid POD to all of these third party applications. Thus, if you wanted to write a Google DocsEvernote for this new internet, you would essentially only write front end code that interacted with each individual's Solid POD as a backend (instead of having your backend servers) through the Solid POD APIs. Solid PODs can also be used for authentication, and you can have multiple PODs to prevent data loss.

Solid is a new decentralized internet designed by Sir Tim Berners-Lee, who is credited with inventing the original internet. As far as I can tell (I am very dumb, so please forgive me if I get something wrong), Solid focuses on empowering individuals to take back control of their data and privacy by allowing them to store their data in a decentralized, secure manner. This means that individuals can keep their personal information safe and decide who they want to give access to their data. Solid also aims to make it easier for individuals to share their data across different applications or platforms, eliminating the need for centralized data silos that are controlled by large corporations. In essence, Solid seeks to restore the original vision of the internet as a free and open platform for everyone, instead of a place where large corporations harvest and exploit people's data for their own profit.

Solid is a new decentralized internet designed by Sir Tim Berners-Lee, who is credited with inventing the original internet. As far as I can tell (I am very dumb, so please be gentle with me) the goal of Solid is to have a new network that has the same properties as the original internet (which was basically just a giant database) but that also allows for transactions and such. So it is like a bigger database that also allows for transactions and stuff. If you were to build a network based on Solid, you could then make any transactions you wanted to, and store them in the database. And it would be decentralized, and you would be able to move your coins around with your computer. jinushaun The idea of a blockchain that uses a database as its base seems to be a fundamental problem. No blockchain protocol I know of is built on top of a database (in the traditional sense). For example, Bitcoin uses an asymmetric cryptographic hash as its public key, and a publicprivate key pair as its private key. This asymmetric cryptographic hash is then converted to a base64 string, and used as the address for each bitcoin transaction. Ethereum is based on a smart contract system, which is a much more complex system than Bitcoin's base64-hash based address system. In other words, no blockchain I know of is built on top of a database. xiaoma I don't know if this is a fundamental problem, but it seems like it would be an easy one to solve. Instead of using the database as the foundation of the blockchain, use the blockchain as the foundation of the database. If you're looking for the "one true blockchain," there's no reason to do anything else. But if you're looking for something that can have different types of data, this seems like a natural choice. pavs instead of using the database as the foundation of the blockchain, use the blockchain as the foundation of the database. But it would still be a blockchain, just like bitcoin or ethereum, and you would still need a public ledger to maintain a database. I don't think it would solve anything, it would just be a blockchain with a database. xiaoma Yes, but you could have a different database for different blockchains. This is essentially how git works. You could use git to store Bitcoin transactions and have the database store both a blockchain and a database. If you want to do a new blockchain, you just make a new git repository. koolba Bitcoin is open source and 99 of its source code is available for scrutiny and modification. That's a very bold statement considering Bitcoin's development is a mess. It's not like Bitcoin's github repo is regularly updated and the changes are documented. kjs3 Bitcoin's github repo is regularly updated and the changes are documented. In fact, all the main developers are on IRC andor in the Bitcoin mailing list. smoyer As someone who doesn't really understand the blockchain concept, I'm thinking that "Bitcoin" is like a huge one-off distributed database. I'm wondering if the distributed aspect of Bitcoin will actually make it more secure? I.e. if someone is able to send money to an address, but they don't know who the recipient is, are they not vulnerable to "reverse transactions"? What I'm really asking is: how does Bitcoin prevent fraud? swalsh This is a really good question, I've been trying to answer it myself. The way I'm thinking about it is this: When you send a bitcoin, the transaction goes out into the network. It is broadcasted, and others who are on the network see it. The node then does a computation on the transaction, and validates it. The whole point of the blockchain is that it is tamper proof. If the sender's private key has changed, the sender will be unable to spend that transaction. This is why you can only spend money you own, and why a node cannot spend the money of another node. You can also see the sender's address, so you know who you're sending to. There are several things that can make this not secure, but the most common one is that the sender and receiver have the same private key. If that is the case, the sender can spend the money of the receiver, since they can spend the transaction. smoyer This is an excellent way of thinking about it. One problem with this is that it only applies to the case of a single sender and receiver.

Solid is a new decentralized internet designed by Sir Tim Berners-Lee, who is credited with inventing the original internet. As far as I can tell (I am very dumb, so please correct me if I am wrong) it is a new protocol for transferring and storing data that is less centralized than the internet we know today. For example, people can run a node on their computer to create a peer-to-peer network, which is more democratic than the centralized servers of companies like Facebook. Solid is designed to work with the existing internet, but it is an attempt to solve some of the problems with it. For example, people will be able to create their own "pods" or little data centers, and these pods can interact with other pods. These pods are more secure than the internet is today, and they are more stable because they are not dependent on the stability of centralized companies. In the same way that the internet revolutionized communication, Solid is supposed to revolutionize how we store and transfer data. I think Solid could be a very powerful tool for artists, but it will be a challenge for them to adapt to the technology. I really like the idea of people creating their own pods and hosting their own data. This is very relevant for artists because we often depend on technology that we don't control and have very little power over. For example, I am constantly frustrated by how Facebook is designed. I use it because it's the best way to reach an audience, but the interface is terrible. I have no control over how my art is displayed on the site. The layout is inflexible. And when Facebook decides to change the interface, I am left scrambling to figure out what's going on. As artists, we have very little control over how we are perceived online, and Solid seems to be a way of taking that control back. I've heard that Solid will allow artists to create pods for their art, and that these pods will be able to interact with other pods. This is really interesting because it means that artists will be able to create an independent website that is still connected to a larger network. It will allow artists to have their own space and control over their work, but it will also allow them to interact with other artists. For example, an artist could create a pod for his or her art and share it with other artists. They could then decide to collaborate on a piece by interacting with each other's pods. One of the most interesting aspects of Solid is that it is supposed to be a neutral platform. I think this is important because it will prevent people from using it to promote a political agenda. Solid's only goal is to create a better internet. It's not trying to stop the spread of fake news or regulate hate speech. The only regulation that it will impose is the regulation of its own structure, which is crucial for it to work. I think it's important that people understand this, because I don't want to see Solid used as a political tool. It's also important to note that Solid will only be as useful as people make it. It's not going to be a magical device that will automatically solve the world's problems. Solid is a tool, and it is up to us to use it properly. I think this is important because many people are concerned about the internet, but they are not willing to do anything about it. I've only been following Solid for a short time, but I am really interested in the project. I'm not sure if I will be able to use it to benefit my work, but I'm excited to see where it goes.

This article features an interview with Tony Fadell. Fadell was instrumental in the development of the iPod and iPhone at Apple. He co-founded Nest Labs, which was sold to Google for 3.2 billion. In this article, he talks about his experience designing products and companies. One of my favorite quotes from the article is, "People who are designers need to be able to put themselves into other people's shoes. You have to have empathy. And you have to have a desire to make things better." That quote embodies a significant part of my beliefs as a designer. You are not designing for yourself. You are designing for a user. In order to be effective, you need to be able to look at your project through their eyes. What are their problems? How can you help them with those problems? What makes them happy? How can you make them happier? This approach can also be applied to the people you work with. What are their problems? How can you help them with those problems? What makes them happy? How can you make them happier? Another key takeaway from this article is the concept of using data to drive decisions. As designers, we can often make assumptions about how to make things better. However, the way to truly validate those assumptions is to use data. The article features this quote: "I'm a big believer in first principles. Most people tackle a problem by saying, 'Okay, this is how others did it. Let's consider all the issues and complexities of this problem as it's been looked at before.' But then you end up with something not too much different from what already exists. I find that you have to take a step back and say, 'Let's forget everything we know about this problem and imagine that we're the first person to ever look at it. I'm a big fan of first principles thinking, especially when applied to design. When we focus on first principles, we often end up with an innovative design. I highly recommend this article. This article features an interview with Tony Fadell. Fadell was instrumental in the development of the iPod and iPhone at Apple. He co-founded Nest Labs, which was sold to Google for 2 billion. "We started out doing stuff that we would think people would find interesting - things like a light switch that could change color" - Fadell says - and "although it didn't do any business for us...we were just amazed by how much fun things can be if you start thinking about them as something more than just technology." If you're going to work on radical new ideas, it's important first to understand what makes those concepts thrive: "The most profound innovation is when there's some kind of real passion or desire behind it. It doesn't matter whether your idea happens to turn into money...It matters because entrepreneurship involves creating something that's hard not to want. If it's easy, then everyone will have it; otherwise no one has anything to lose. But if someone wants something so bad they're willing to invest their own time, energy, resources-and sometimes even money-to create it, that's really valuable. It's powerful. And all great innovations are born from passionate individuals who see a huge unmet need. That gap needs filling. In my experience nobody likes being told exactly what to make; nor does anyone care to hear long descriptions of why this thing might come back later. All these things should be left up to intuition and inspiration. When I look back over many years' worth of conversations I've had with brilliant unknowns and companies I'm involved with, I always wonder whether there weren't some edge cases where somebody saw a problem that other people missed but went ahead anyway because he believed deeply enough in his instincts."

A team of scientists used high-energy X-rays to analyze ancient Egyptian papyri fragments and found lead compounds in both the red and black inks used. This is evidence that lead was added for its fast-drying properties rather than for its pigmentation. Painters in Europe used a similar technique when developing oil paints in the 15th-century, except that the Egyptians discovered it 1,400 years earlier. Synchrotron radiation is useful for analyzing art and other priceless artifacts due to its high-energy and short wavelengths. Ink has been used to write for thousands of years, and revealing the secrets of ancient ink technology contributes to our knowledge of the origin of writing practices.

A team of scientists used high-energy X-rays to analyze ancient Egyptian papyri fragments and found lead compounds in both the red and black inks used. This is evidence that lead was used in their manufacturing process. The scientists used two different methods, one involving X-ray diffraction and the other X-ray fluorescence, to analyze the ink of two fragments from the papyrus collection of the Egyptian Museum and Papyrus Collection in Berlin. Both methods are non-destructive and can be performed in situ, which is necessary for artifacts such as these. The first fragment, dubbed the "Gospel of Luke," was written on parchment, or animal skin, in the late 1st century A.D. This was one of the oldest surviving copies of the Gospel of Luke, a canonical Christian text that is a biography of Jesus. It was found in 1911 in an Egyptian tomb and was discovered to have a layer of red ink made from lead compounds. The scientists also discovered the black ink used in this text was also made from lead, but in the form of carbon-based black ink. The second fragment, dubbed the "Acts of Paul," is a text that describes the life of the Apostle Paul, and is considered by some to be a non-canonical Christian text. This fragment is not as old, dating to the 3rd century A.D. It was written on papyrus and contained black ink that was found to have been made from carbon-based black ink, but also contained lead in the form of a copper-based pigment. These were the first of these ancient papyri to be analyzed with such high-energy X-rays. The results have shown that the black ink used for these ancient Egyptian texts was not only carbon-based, but also contained lead. DeepMind has published a paper on their system AlphaZero, an AI that can crack any game that provides all the relevant decision-making information. This includes games like chess and go, as well as board games like chess, checkers, and tic-tac-toe. AlphaZero learns by itself from scratch, without human intervention. The new paper, published in Nature, describes how the AI was trained using the popular Zero-Sum Zero-Sum (ZZS) game. In ZZS, the AI plays against itself, and for each move, it selects the move that it thinks will be the best move for it. The AI is given all of the information about the board and the available moves, and it learns to play to win. The researchers compared the AI's performance to humans, and found that the AI could beat a master player by over 50. AlphaZero is trained to play to win, and it's the first time we've seen a computer system that can do this. AlphaZero uses a "strong" reinforcement learning approach, where it tries out different strategies to see what works best. This approach is different from "weak" reinforcement learning, where the AI only tries out a few strategies to see what works best. AlphaZero is a reinforcement learning algorithm. Traditionally, the best way to train reinforcement learning algorithms is to provide a human with a dataset that shows what to do. The AI learns from these examples, and then it can use this knowledge to do better on the next iteration. But AlphaZero doesn't need this step. It can train itself from scratch. The researchers used ZZS to test AlphaZero's performance, and they found that it was able to play to win 50 of the time. In the second game that they tested, Go, the AI achieved 99.5. This is a massive improvement over what we've seen from other AIs, which haven't achieved more than 90. AlphaZero also beat other AIs in ZZS, and in a version of the game called 5-player Nim, a game that requires thinking on multiple levels. In this version of the game, there are five players, and the AI has to pick the best move for each player. This is a very challenging problem, because the AI has to think about what's best for each player, while also considering the next move for itself. This is the kind of problem that AlphaZero can tackle. This isn't the first time that DeepMind has published research on an AI that can beat humans in games. In 2016, the AI system AlphaGo beat Lee Sedol, a top Go player. The research also used reinforcement learning, and the AI played a version of the game called MCTS. But in this case, the AI was only able to learn from human games, and it was trained on the AI version of the game, not the human version. In 2017, the AI was able to beat another top player, and it's been the most-successful version of AlphaGo. The new AI system is called AlphaZero. It's a much simpler system, but it still shows that reinforcement learning is able to crack complex games. In the past, DeepMind has also used reinforcement learning to solve difficult problems in machine learning. DeepMind's AlphaGo and AlphaZero are proof that AI can crack complex problems that humans haven't been able to solve. This could be a huge step forward for the field. The AI could potentially help train other AIs, or it could even be used to solve human problems. For example, it could be used to make medical diagnoses, or it could help the elderly live independently. AlphaZero is only able to crack games with a clear set of rules. But it's also not able to learn from games that have no clear rules. It's still not clear how AlphaZero could be used to solve real-world problems. It's also not clear how well AlphaZero would work on other board games. The AI doesn't seem to understand the concepts behind board games, and it doesn't seem to understand the game's rules. This means that AlphaZero is probably not the right tool to use to crack the complex rules behind board games. Sea World took legal action against West Virginia State University (WVSU) after students staged a protest inside its zoo last week demanding they end their practice of capturing wild animals and keeping them captive. It said WVSU had no right placing sea lions into cages and taking them back out onto public access beaches where people come to feed them or take selfies with them. "We are pleased our lawsuit [against] WVSU was successful today," says Phil Gershman, president executive director of Animal Defenders International, who represented the animal rights group. "This case marks another victory in our fight to stop SeaWorld and other aquariums from using whales, dolphins, porpoises, sharks and otters in painful exhibitions that violate international conventions on animal welfare. We plan to continue litigation until all marine mammals are released immediately and permanently without any restrictions." Gershman says SeaWorld officials told him that releasing animals back to the natural environment won't work because there aren't enough places available. "They don't want us to release the animals so much as put them under quarantine while they develop disease-free populations elsewhere, but that's not going to happen either since the vast majority of beach-goers have seen sick seals already and basically know how to spot diseased ones," he adds. He also pointed to the fact that many wildlife sanctuaries around America are experiencing financial hardships due to COVID-19 shutdowns meant to prevent spreading the virus. "If SeaWorld doesn't open up our parks again quickly, it's only a matter of time before they're forced out forever - and then it's going to be too late," he says.

Facebook is rolling out its Novi wallet in the US and Guatemala in a pilot program. Users will be able to purchase Paxos Dollar (USDP) using Novi, with Novi depositing the funds directly into their bank accounts. The pilot program will run for six months and will be available to users over 18 in the US and Guatemala. Novi is a digital wallet that allows users to send and receive money, as well as buy and sell cryptocurrencies. It is the first cryptocurrency wallet to be developed by a major social media company. Facebook has been working on Novi for several years, and it is seen as a way to expand the company's reach into the financial services industry. Novi is also seen as a way for Facebook to compete with other digital wallets, such as PayPal and Venmo. The pilot program for Novi is a significant step for Facebook, as it marks the company's first major foray into the financial services industry. If Novi is successful, it could open the door for Facebook to offer a wider range of financial services, such as loans and investments.

Facebook is rolling out its Novi wallet in the US and Guatemala in a pilot program. Users will be able to purchase Paxos Dollar (USDP) using Novi, with Novi depositing US directly into their Facebook account. Paxos will receive US1 million for each of the partnership's two countries over three years as well as other fees, according to a blog post by CEO Alex Konopinski published on Thursday. The new service allows users to earn cryptocurrency while they use third-party services such as Airbnb or Uber. The company's goal now "is to have millions of people across these markets understand how easy and convenient it can be to save [their] money" through Novi wallets. As noted previously - most companies that offer crypto-only banking accounts only accept fiat currencies up until this point so there has always been a barrier between the ease-of-payment offered by digital currency and traditional bank deposits. With Novi, however, it's all about convenience: "The more you accumulate [Bitcoin (BTC), Ethereum (ETH), Litecoin (LTC) etc], the easier it becomes to quickly spend your bitcoin on things like gasoline at Walmart..." "We aim to give everyone an opportunity to own Bitcoin safely without having any knowledge whatsoever - just something that you've saved away which you're not giving anyone access to right now but could easily do because we're doing it for them!"

Facebook is rolling out its Novi wallet in the US and Guatemala in a pilot program. Users will be able to purchase Paxos Dollar (USDP) using Novi, with Novi depositing the coins into the user's bank account. Facebook's Novi coin is set to debut in the United States and Guatemala in a pilot program. Users in both countries will be able to purchase Paxos Dollar (USDP) using Novi, with Novi depositing the coins into the user's bank account. Facebook is rolling out its Novi wallet in the United States and Guatemala in a pilot program. The social media giant is a founding member of the Libra Association. The Libra Association has 28 members in total, including Visa, PayPal, Uber, and Coinbase. Novi is a Facebook subsidiary that makes it easier for people to pay for goods and services using Facebook's messaging app. The app is also used to send messages and make video and voice calls. The Libra Association is a nonprofit that will oversee the Libra blockchain, which is a digital currency that will be backed by a reserve of real assets such as bank deposits and short-term government securities. The Facebook subsidiary Novi announced that it is "working with regulators in the United States to secure appropriate approvals and licenses" in order to conduct the pilot program in the two countries. Paxos Standard is a stablecoin pegged to the US dollar and is the first regulated stablecoin to be listed on Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange. Last year, Paxos issued 100 million USDP coins, with each token backed by one dollar of US dollar reserves held by the company in FDIC-insured banks. Paxos says that it "meets the strictest regulatory requirements and is the only stablecoin in the world that has been granted approval by the New York Department of Financial Services." Earlier this year, Paxos introduced a solution that allows traders to leverage their Paxos Standard tokens. The solution is called Paxos Standard Levered Ether (PAXETH). Following the launch of PAXETH, Paxos also launched a new stablecoin, called Paxos Standard Gold (PAXG), which is pegged to gold. Novi will be partnering with Paxos to make the transactions possible. US regulators have been skeptical of Libra's potential. The chairwoman of the House Financial Services Committee, Maxine Waters, sent a letter to the CEO of Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg, saying that she is "disappointed" with the lack of "meaningful consultation with Congress" and is requesting a moratorium on the project. Meanwhile, the Senate Banking Committee also plans to hold a hearing regarding the project in July.

Facebook is rolling out its Novi wallet in the US and Guatemala in a pilot program. Users will be able to purchase Paxos Dollar (USDP) using Novi, with Novi depositing that money directly into their bank account. In the US, it will be available in 35 states and the District of Columbia. In Guatemala, it will be available in the country's 24 states. Facebook is also making changes to its Libra project. For starters, it is changing the name from Libra to Libra Association. This is because it is changing the governance structure. As of now, Facebook and eight other companies (Coinbase, Stellar, Ripple, Microsoft, Stripe, Visa, Mastercard, and Uber) will be running the association. This means that Facebook will be responsible for a majority of the projects, which will have to be approved by the board. This is not a great idea. As we wrote before, Facebook will be making a lot of money from the association, but will also be heavily involved in its projects. This is not how a non-profit organization should work. That's why the other companies want to remove Facebook from the project. So, the change of name is a step in the right direction. As of now, it is a private project, but it is open to the public. However, that's changing. Now, it is a non-profit organization that is open to all participants. Another change is that it is no longer accepting applications. The only company that can join is Coinbase. It is also changing the launch date. Initially, it was expected to launch in Q1 of 2020, but it will launch in Q2 of 2020. Finally, it is launching the non-fungible token (NFT) ecosystem. Facebook is going to launch the NFT ecosystem to let users to buy, sell, and trade digital assets. As of now, this is only available in the US and Guatemala. However, it will soon be available in more countries. As mentioned before, this is not a great move for Facebook. As we have explained in our previous articles, it will make Facebook a major player in the digital asset industry. It will be in a position to charge a lot of money for these services. This is why we don't expect Facebook to succeed. However, this is a good thing for the crypto industry. As long as Facebook is working in the digital asset space, we will see more and more companies moving to the space. This is good for the market. Disclosure: The author holds no cryptocurrency assets at the time of writing.

Hybrid Electric Vehicles Hybrid electric vehicles combine the best of a conventional internal combustion engine and an electric motor. An electric motor is added to the engine in order to power the vehicle at low speeds and to start the engine. At higher speeds the engine and the electric motor work in unison to provide maximum torque. A high-voltage battery powers the electric motor. A control unit determines the ratio of electric motor to engine torque and delivers it to the wheels. In this way, hybrid electric vehicles offer the best of both worlds. They combine the torque and low emissions of an electric motor with the efficiency of a combustion engine. Hybrid vehicles are economical and fuel-efficient, as well as being environmentally friendly. They can also offer the performance of a conventional car. Hybrid vehicles are becoming increasingly popular. This is due to the improved fuel economy they offer and the improved driving range they provide. A number of manufacturers offer hybrid vehicles including Ford, Toyota, Nissan and Volkswagen. Electric Vehicles Electric vehicles run on electricity produced from renewable energy sources such as wind, solar and hydropower. Electric vehicles use electric motors to power the vehicle. An electric motor is powered by electricity generated from renewable energy sources. The electric motor has the same benefits as an internal combustion engine, but is cleaner, more efficient and has a longer range. The most efficient and environmentally friendly form of electricity is wind power. This is because wind turbines produce electricity without any fuel costs. Wind turbines are a popular source of renewable energy. However, wind power is not always available. When there is no wind the power produced is not as efficient. Wind power is intermittent. This means that electric power companies need to store the energy produced from wind turbines to be used at times when there is no wind. Solar power is another renewable energy source. Solar power can be used to power an electric vehicle, but is not as efficient as wind power. In addition, solar power is intermittent, so electric power companies must store energy generated by solar panels to be used at times when there is no sun. Hydropower is another renewable energy source. Hydropower is more efficient than wind and solar power. Hydropower is also less intermittent than wind and solar power. Hydropower can be used to power an electric vehicle, but is not as efficient as wind power. In addition, hydropower is intermittent, so electric power companies must store energy generated by hydropower to be used at times when there is no water. Toyota has fitted racing cars with hydrogen combustion engines to test the feasibility of the technology for use in commercial vehicles. The technology still suffers from limitations regarding range, and cost, however, and Toyota has said it will not be ready for use in mass-market vehicles for the next few years. Toyota's hydrogen-powered racing cars use a modified version of its 2.4-litre V6 engine. The engine is fitted with a hydrogen fuel cell and a series of catalytic converters to convert the hydrogen into a combustible gas. The cars are able to reach speeds of up to 310km/h and have a range of around 500km.

Toyota has fitted racing cars with hydrogen combustion engines to test the feasibility of the technology for use in commercial vehicles. The technology still suffers from limitations regarding range, and is not competitive with electric vehicles. In 2013, Toyota announced that it would launch a fuel cell electric vehicle (FCEV) in 2015. The car will be sold in Japan and the U.S. at a price of around 100,000. The company claims that the car will have a driving range of 300 miles (480 km) and a refueling time of about three minutes. The new vehicle is believed to be based on the FCV-R concept, which Toyota showcased at the 2012 Tokyo Motor Show. The car is expected to use hydrogen from the chemical reformation of natural gas or by electrolysis of water. On August 28, 2012, Toyota unveiled the FCV-R Concept fuel cell vehicle at the 2011 Tokyo Motor Show. The FCV-R Concept was designed to "highlight the fuel cell system's compact dimensions and demonstrate its suitability for a saloon-type sedan." The FCV-R Concept has a driving range of 700 km (435 miles) and a hydrogen storage capacity of 70 MPa (700 bar, 10,150 psi). Toyota presented an FCV prototype at the 2013 Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. Toyota planned to sell the car in 2015 at a price of about 100,000. In June 2013, Toyota announced that the FCV would be introduced in Japan before April 2015, and in the U.S. and Europe in the summer of 2015. Toyota plans to sell at least 100 FCVs in 2015, mostly in Japan and the U.S. The company plans to sell 1,000 FCVs by 2017. On November 18, 2014, Toyota revealed the FCV under the name Mirai, meaning "future" in Japanese. Toyota plans to release the car in Japan on December 15, 2014, and in the U.S. and Europe in mid-2015. In Japan, it will be priced at 6.7 million yen (US57,000) before taxes. Sales in the U.S. are scheduled to begin in August 2015 at a price of US57,500 before any government incentives. Initially, the Mirai will only be available in Los Angeles, San Francisco, and New York City. The Mirai will be equipped with a 152 hp (113 kW) electric motor, 114 kW fuel cell (FC), two 70 MPa (10,000 psi) hydrogen tanks, a 245-liter fuel tank, and a 28 kWh lithium-ion battery. The FCV is expected to have a range of 435 miles (700 km) and a refueling time of about three minutes. Toyota estimates that the FCV will get 67 miles per gallon-equivalent (3.6 l100 km), and that its well-to-wheel efficiency is 75 percent. In August 2014, Toyota announced that the Mirai would come with three years or 65,000 km of free hydrogen. The company also announced that it will launch a 7.3 million program to encourage the development of hydrogen fueling stations in California. Toyota will partner with FirstElement Fuels to build 19 new hydrogen stations in California over the next three years, and it will provide an additional 3 million to support the California Fuel Cell Partnership's market introduction of zero-emission fuel cell vehicles. The Mirai will be one of the eight vehicles available at the launch of Gran Turismo 6, revealed at the 2013 Tokyo Motor Show. The Toyota FCV was featured in the 2015 James Bond film Spectre. The idea is simple - combine large amounts of gasoline with steam at high pressure (around 100 atmospheres) and heat it into superheated vapor (at around 300 degrees Celsius). When this vapour expands through an engine's intake valve system, it bursts out as hot gases that then create thrust using pistons like those found on airplanes' turboprop engines.

While surgeons have been using 3D printers to make bone implants for years, the implants have been made from metal or plastic, which can cause complications due to the body's immune response. Particle3D's implants are made from a biocompatible material that is absorbed by the body over time, leaving no trace behind. This makes them ideal for patients who need temporary implants, such as those who are undergoing cancer treatment or who have suffered a traumatic injury. Particle3D's implants are also lightweight and strong, making them more comfortable for patients to wear. The company is currently working on developing implants for a variety of applications, including spinal fusion, knee replacements, and skull fractures. If successful, Particle3D's implants could revolutionize the way that bone injuries are treated.

Particle3D is a company that is pioneering a novel method for 3D printing lightweight, customized bone implants that fuse with the skeleton before slowly disappearing. While surgeons have been using metal plates and screws to hold broken bones together since at least the 1800s, these traditional methods can be expensive. "We're trying to find ways of making it more affordable while also improving the quality - specifically by increasing stability," says co-founder Michael Tong. "In other words, we want them to last longer than what's typically used in car accidents or sports injuries." The type of material being used depends on the purpose and location where each implant will go inside the patient.
