The US military has been building a massive database with millions of images of faces, irises, fingerprints, and DNA data over the last 15 years. There are at least 7.4 million identities in the Automated Biometric Information System, including the identities of suspected terrorists and allied soldiers training with the US forces. The Defense Forensics and Biometrics Agency is tasked with overseeing the database. This information was used thousands of times in the first half of 2019 to identify non-US citizens on the battlefield. It is linked to the FBI's biometric database, so the US military can search against the biometric data of US citizens as well. This network will ultimately amount to a global surveillance system. The US military has invested over 345 million in biometric database technology in the last 10 years. Much about the system is still unknown, including its accuracy rate at identifying individuals correctly.

The US military has been building a massive database with millions of images of faces, irises, fingerprints, and DNA data over the last 15 years. There are at least 7.4 million images of faces in the database, which is more than the total number of people living in New York City. The database is growing by about 100,000 new images per day. The military says that the database is used for security purposes, such as identifying potential threats and preventing terrorist attacks. However, civil liberties groups have raised concerns about the database, saying that it could be used for mass surveillance or to target political dissidents. In 2015, the ACLU filed a lawsuit against the Department of Defense, alleging that the database violates the Fourth Amendment. The lawsuit is still pending. The military has defended the database, saying that it is necessary for national security. However, the debate over the database is likely to continue for years to come.

The US military has been building a massive database with millions of images of faces, irises, fingerprints, and DNA data over the last 15 years. There are at least 7.4 million people in the database, and some 1.3 million of them are suspected terrorists. The database contains more than 550 million data points. In this country, the number of terrorist plots and attacks has been falling steadily since 911. However, it is estimated that only 25 percent of those plots have been successfully thwarted, and that only 10 percent of those plots are being prevented by current security measures. A study from the Department of Homeland Security found that there are currently 20,000 people in the US that are "at risk" of being radicalized to commit an act of terrorism. And the US is not the only country that is struggling to stop terrorism. According to a report by the Center for Strategic and International Studies, governments around the world have spent an estimated 20 billion to combat terrorism. The report states that "nearly all terrorist groups" are currently active in the US, Europe, and the Middle East. And there are many more terrorist cells in the pipeline. And yet, despite this massive investment, there has been no reduction in terrorism. So what gives? A number of reasons have been offered as to why terrorism has not declined in recent years. One is that the US government is waging a so-called "war on terror." Another is that there is a failure of technology. And a third is that there is a failure of public policy. It has been claimed that the war on terror is "misguided" and has been "embarrassing." Some have suggested that the US has "wasted billions of dollars on military and intelligence efforts" and has been "deeply ineffective." And yet, it is also claimed that this failure has been "inevitable" and that the US is "too large" to "prevent every terrorist attack." However, a recent report from the Institute for Science and International Security (ISIS) argues that these claims are not accurate. The report states that there are many different types of terrorism and that these different types of terrorism "have not only varied in their success rate but also in their ability to survive and thrive in an environment hostile to their cause." According to the report, it is important to understand the distinctions between terrorism and extremist violence, and to understand that there is "no one-size-fits-all" approach to dealing with terrorism. The report also suggests that the current "war on terror" may be making things worse, and that the failure of the war on terror is being "overstated." According to the report, there is no evidence that "the US has spent billions of dollars on military and intelligence efforts to fight terrorism," and that the US has not been "deeply ineffective" in the war on terror. And it is also argued that the failure of the war on terror is "inevitable" and "not inevitable." And it is also argued that there is no "war on terror" in the first place.

The US military has been building a massive database with millions of images of faces, irises, fingerprints, and DNA data over the last 15 years. There are at least 7.4 billion items in that database - back to when it started. In order for this project to work smoothly, it needs to be computerised so every image is scanned into a big file before being linked up against existing databases. "We've got like 90 million people who've had their pictures taken since 1996. So just given those numbers alone... it's going to take us maybe 20 or 30 years to scan all these photos if we do it manually on paper. But that's what we're trying to avoid doing by using machine vision technology instead where you can check each photo very quickly versus taking an hour, two hours reviewing one picture at a time," says Dr David King from Melbourne's Centre for Intelligent Security Research (CISR). It also means there will only need to be three copies: one kept in the commander's office, another at storage facility in Hawaii, and a third held as a backup somewhere. "This allows our commands to have full access to the information without having to constantly ask intelligence agencies for permission or get around restrictions imposed by some governments overseas because they may not want any sort of disclosure happening here in Australia, but perhaps they would allow disclosures elsewhere," he explains. Using facial recognition software, soldiers must now briefly show their face while holding an object, such as a baggage tag. A prototype system developed by CISR uses image processing techniques to compare the new picture to previously stored ones. (Supplied) If the recogniser identifies something different than expected - which typically happens when someone looks deceptively similar or mistakenly matches someone's father - then it flags the person down for further investigation. This initial match does mean there's no guarantee that individuals' identities will remain anonymous after they're photographed. Like most security systems run by private corporations today, there isn't much protection for personal privacy under Australia's national security laws. Why no way out There is more regulation about how government agencies conduct surveillance including biometric monitoring, but it doesn't go beyond basic guidelines that companies can't knowingly collect private details about their customers unless they explicitly provide consent - often verbally. Right now, however, the whole point of digital biometrics is to make life easier for business managers rather than making citizens safer. Australian armed forces commander General Mark Thompson said the use of cameras to monitor soldiers was "inevitable" during warfare. He told ABC Radio National's World Today program that keeping tabs on troops could help ensure troop morale didn't dry up too soon. But others think even civilians deserve better supervision through law enforcement organisations and independent judges. Former Supreme Court Justice Tony Wilson argues Australians should expect less intrusion into their lives once everyone's seen plenty of action films featuring heavy hand-holding between cops and criminals. Wilson believes Australia's gun controls were unnecessary yet never changed despite mounting evidence of mass shootings across Europe and America. The US military has been building a massive database with millions of images of faces, irises, fingerprints, and DNA data over the last 15 years. There are at least 7.4 million entries, which includes 2.2 million belonging to US citizens. The images are collected from people in Afghanistan and Iraq and are used to identify potential suspects in intelligence investigations. However, there is no public accounting of the exact number of Americans' images that have been collected by the military over the years. In addition to faces and fingerprints, the collection includes biometric information from other body parts such as irises and DNA, as well as data on scars, tattoos and physical markings. The images are used to identify people in intelligence investigations. In the military's most recent fiscal year, the database received more than 100,000 new files, but it is unclear how many of them were of US citizens. The Military Department of Defense collected 2.2 million images of American citizens over a period of five years, according to data obtained by Gizmodo under the Freedom of Information Act. Light from stars tend to pulsate uniformly across the whole surface of a star. Astronomers have discovered a teardrop-shaped object that only pulses from one side. The star is about 100,000 light years away from Earth. The new study, published in the journal Astronomy Astrophysics, has been confirmed by a number of independent observers. The star is called LS 100445 and is one of the first pulsars discovered in 1974. The pulsar is a massive, rotating neutron star with an enormous magnetic field. As the star rotates, the magnetic field lines sweep out a glowing region called the neutron star's "light cylinder," which is the radius at which light can move around the star. The pulsar is known to pulsate at a rate of about 100 times per second. This star has a surface that's the same size as Earth, but its diameter is only about 400,000 kilometers (250,000 miles). This means that the surface of the star is the size of a softball. But this pulsar is unique. "This pulsar is the only one that we know of where the light only pulses from one side," said Marcella Baldo, a graduate student at the University of Texas at Austin. The researchers used the Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer, a satellite that measures the timing of pulses of X-rays emitted from the star, to measure the pulsations. The star pulsates about 100 times per second, which is what astronomers would expect from a rotating neutron star. But, the researchers found that the pulsar also has pulsations that are occurring at a much slower rate, about 100,000 times per second. This suggests that there are two sources of light from the star, and that one of the sources is not rotating. "We were able to detect the other component of the light from the pulsar," Baldo said. "This light was different from the 100-times-per-second component of the light. It was a slow, rotating component." The slow component of the light was also seen in other X-ray pulsars, which suggests that this is not a rare occurrence. But, because LS 100445 is a very bright X-ray source, it is easier to see the slow component of the light. The researchers found that the light from the slow component of the star has a slower frequency than the fast component of the light, suggesting that it has a different physical origin. "We can't explain it with our current understanding of the physics of neutron stars," Baldo said. "But we can't rule out any of the possibilities." In the future, the researchers plan to analyze more data from the Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer and to use data from other X-ray telescopes to look for the slow component of the light. "If we find the slow component of the light, we can determine what the physical source of this component is," Baldo said. The researchers will also look for the slow component of the light in other pulsars. The research was supported by NASA. The unique shape came after researchers observed this Teegarden Object with high-resolution imaging at NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope on Earth and Hubble Space Telescope on space. They also used data collected by the European Southern Observatory's Gaia mission in orbit around nearby sun-like star GJ 876B. Astronomers first detected the unusual planetary nebula in 2010 when they noticed it was dimming more quickly than usual - probably due to an expanding shell that had become thicker on its bright, central axis. "The dramatic variations we see are caused by light streaming outwards rather than being scattered back towards us like other planets do," said lead author Laura Meech, a postdoctoral researcher at Notre Dame University who did her graduate work under Stephen Mclaren's supervision. "We're still trying to figure out what makes them so different. We think it's likely related to how much hydrogen gas there is inside - but that's just speculation right now because no-one has actually measured these parameters outside of objects where the clumps of material have collapsed into smaller spots and made it easier for astrometry satellites to measure their positions." Meech and colleagues then set up observations using the Spitzer telescope aboard the International Space Station (ISS) which allowed scientists to pin-point exactly when the Teegarden Object began expelling its hydrogen-rich gases: It happened over the course of two weeks instead of just one day or even three hours. This could mean the progenitor star wasn't fully ionized immediately upon birth and remained partially neutral until later on. "If you want to know something about your young star, a few days will be plenty long enough," explained astronomer David Bowler, who led another group of observers involved in this study. "The most important thing here however is not knowing precisely why certain types of variation occur, but having evidence that such events happen all along the way! So the fact that we were able to detect variations during both phases indicates this planet might represent a transitional object between the initial stages before the star becomes mostly ionised and finally completely blown apart into a supernova explosion. If we can find more examples of this behavior among others similar ones, it would help establish that some sort of long-term effect exists and that the pulsations aren't entirely epiphenomenological."

Rutgers engineers have created a 3D-printed smart gel that changes shape when exposed to light and a 3D-printed stretchy material that can reveal colors when the light changes. These developments are among the first steps in a series of research efforts at the University to develop new materials that respond to light and environmental changes. "There are many different ways to manipulate light, and the exciting thing about this work is that it can have applications in a variety of areas," said lead author Matthew V. Nicholls, a postdoctoral researcher in mechanical engineering. "In medicine, we could use it to treat wounds and burns; in robotics, it could be used to control robotic grippers and limbs; and in electronics, it could be used to create wearable devices and smart materials." The study was published online in the journal Advanced Functional Materials. 3D printing has become a promising tool for creating new materials, but it has been limited in its ability to create materials that respond to light, Nicholls said. The new research, however, has provided a step toward developing 3D-printed materials that can change shape and color in response to light, he said. The researchers developed a 3D-printed gel made of light-responsive polymers and metal oxide nanoparticles. When exposed to light, the gel swells and becomes a little less dense. As a result, it changes shape. "We were able to create a material that responds to light in the visible range, but we could also potentially create a material that responds to light in the infrared range," Nicholls said. The researchers also created a stretchy material that changes color when exposed to light. The material consists of a gel sandwiched between layers of transparent polymers. When exposed to light, the gel expands and the material stretches, making the layers of polymer shift apart and creating a color change. "This is a very simple system that we can control very precisely," Nicholls said. "The process is really elegant and straightforward, and it's easy to use and easy to implement." The researchers created both materials using a 3D-printing technique called fused deposition modeling, which uses a laser to melt the polymer, depositing the material in layers. The researchers then developed a simple, inexpensive device that can sense and record the changes in the materials. The device consists of a light-emitting diode, a photodetector and a camera. The researchers are currently developing a prototype device to study the materials. "We are trying to find ways to use these materials in a wide range of applications," Nicholls said. "For example, the gel could be used to develop smart gels for drug delivery and wound care.

Brewster Kahle founded Alexa Internet and the Internet Archive on the same day in 1996. Alexa was acquired by Amazon in a deal worth 250 million and converted into an analytics service. The Internet Archive was founded with the vision of storing copies of every website in the world, and is currently in the process of doing exactly that. Kahle has been a technological innovator, entrepreneur, and advocate since the beginning of the web. He has worked with the Internet Archive since 1996, creating what is today a home for the millions of books, movies, software, music, websites, and more. At the Internet Archive's headquarters in San Francisco, Kahle shows us the Wayback Machine, the Petabox, and a book scanner. The Internet Archive is a digital library of free media, including books, movies, software, music, websites, and more. The Internet Archive includes texts, audio, moving images, and software as well as archived web pages. The Archive has not limited itself to collecting the digitized works of others. It now creates its own digital versions of other published works, as well as of live public domain films. The organization also oversees the Wayback Machine archive, which preserves the web pages of now defunct websites. When Kahle founded the Internet Archive in 1996, he envisioned it as a library of the Internet - a place where anyone could go and find information that has since been lost to the digital ether. Today, the Archive is growing at an enormous pace, thanks to Kahle's unending energy and vision. The Archive is home to 150 million books, movies, software, music, websites, and more. The Internet Archive is a 501 (c) (3) non-profit that was founded to build an Internet library, with the purpose of offering permanent access for researchers, historians, and scholars to historical collections that exist in digital format. Was the Internet Archive created to archive the Internet? Kahle: We founded the Internet Archive on April 30, 1996. The World Wide Web was 1,500 days old. It was that young. The Archive was a library that you might build to collect the last 1,500 days of the Internet. That was the plan at the beginning. We would keep a copy of every website. Today, it is a library that keeps a copy of every website, and it is a library that keeps a copy of every book, and it is a library that keeps a copy of every TV show, and every movie, and all the software. It is the library for the world. Was this the first time you have ever tried to archive something? Kahle: I was an archivist before I was an entrepreneur. My first job was in a library, where I worked in the rare book room, which was a place that they kept copies of the books that no one else had, and that is the kind of job that I loved. It is the kind of job that led to the Internet Archive. What have been some of the major challenges? Kahle: Everything at the beginning. There were no books to scan, no one who wanted to help us. We had no money, so we had to try to figure out a way to get books to scan, and to get people to help us. We had to figure out how to get money so that we could pay for the books to be scanned. What is the Wayback Machine? Kahle: The Wayback Machine is the website where you can go and find an older version of a webpage. You can see how it used to be in the past. It is a very handy thing. Public health officials have long been urging Americans to limit the consumption of red and processed meats due to its links with heart disease, cancer, and other illnesses. Researchers have now found that these meats may also increase risk for a rare form of kidney cancer. A study published in the journal Cancer Research found that people who ate the most red and processed meat had a 40% higher risk of developing renal cell carcinoma, the most common type of kidney cancer, than those who ate the least. The risk was even higher for people who ate large amounts of processed meat, such as bacon, sausage, and hot dogs. The researchers believe that the high levels of saturated fat and cholesterol in red and processed meats may be responsible for the increased risk of kidney cancer. These compounds can damage the kidneys and make them more susceptible to cancer. The study's findings add to the growing body of evidence linking red and processed meat consumption to a variety of health problems. Public health officials recommend limiting consumption of these meats to no more than two servings per week.

Public health officials have long been urging Americans to limit the consumption of red and processed meats due to its links with heart disease, cancer, and other illnesses. Researchers have reported that there is no need to drastically cut back on red and processed meats. The relationship between the two and heart disease has been so controversial that some scientists have argued that there is no such thing as a "good" or "bad" meat. However, a new study conducted by researchers from the University of Michigan found that the long-term consumption of red meat and processed meat did not have a significant impact on heart disease. The study, published in the Journal of the American College of Cardiology, was based on a database of more than 100,000 people and examined their eating habits and rates of heart disease. The researchers found that red and processed meat intake was not linked to heart disease in people of all ages, with or without risk factors for heart disease. Dr. Scott Sobel, professor of epidemiology and public health at the University of Michigan and the study's lead author, said, "We were surprised by the lack of association between meat intake and risk of heart disease." The researchers found that red and processed meat intake was not linked to a significantly higher risk of heart disease in any of the study's age groups, regardless of risk factors. The study's findings are important because it found that there was no association between red and processed meat intake and heart disease in people who were at a low risk of heart disease. This is significant because, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, people with higher rates of heart disease are less likely to change their eating habits. In fact, many patients who have a history of heart disease often try to avoid the foods they have been warned about in the past, which can lead to poor health. The researchers said, "To our knowledge, this is the first prospective study to examine meat intake and risk of heart disease in the general population." The study's findings are important because it found that there was no association between red and processed meat intake and heart disease in people who were at a low risk of heart disease. In addition, the study's findings also demonstrated that there was no significant difference in risk of heart disease between men and women who consumed meat. The study was based on data from the United States' National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES). The study's findings are significant because the results suggest that the general public may be overestimating the negative effects of red and processed meat. The researchers added, "Our findings suggest that the public health message that red and processed meat intake increases the risk of heart disease may not be universally applicable to the general population." According to the American Heart Association, heart disease is the leading cause of death in the United States, claiming the lives of 368,000 Americans each year. The AHA also says that cardiovascular disease accounts for more than 60 percent of all deaths. The AHA has urged Americans to limit their consumption of red and processed meats due to its links to heart disease, cancer, and other illnesses.

Eric Schmidt, former Google CEO and former Alphabet executive chairman, has announced his decision to step down as a board member of Alphabet. After spending eight years as the CEO of Google, he stepped down from the role in 2011. Larry Page took over the role and he was appointed as the executive chairman of the company. Eric Schmidt, former Google CEO and former Alphabet executive chairman, has announced his decision to step down as a board member of Alphabet. He will be retained in the company as a consultant. The news comes on the heels of Google's 150 million lawsuit against Oracle over Android and Google's decision to pay a 245 million settlement with Oracle in a separate lawsuit over Android. The latter case stems from Oracle's claims that Google copied Java in the development of Android. Schmidt's departure from Alphabet is the latest development in a series of business changes that has included the sale of Motorola Mobility and Motorola Solutions to Lenovo, the sale of 80 percent of Nest to Google, the launch of Google Fiber, the acquisition of Nest, the exit of Google's venture capital arm, the rebranding of Google's cloud computing division to "Google Cloud," the launch of Google's Android Wear watch and the acquisition of Motorola Mobility. "As the business has evolved, it has become clear that I will be doing less day-to-day management of Alphabet," Schmidt said in a letter to employees. "I am therefore taking a reduced role as an executive chairman of Alphabet and will step down as a director next month." The full letter from Schmidt is below: Dear Colleagues, As you may know, Google announced last week that we will be selling our 80 percent stake in Motorola Mobility to Lenovo for 2.91 billion. The deal will close in the first half of this year. I have been a director of Alphabet since its inception in 2010, and I will step down as a director next month. I am very proud of what we have accomplished together. Over the past seven years, Alphabet has grown from a small start-up to a global leader in the internet, cloud, mobile and data. The company has grown into a major force in the global economy, and the breadth of the Alphabet portfolio is now one of the most significant in the world. We have made major investments in AI and data, the most significant in the industry, and we have built a unique platform for building on our infrastructure, enabling a wide range of innovative new applications and services. We are also on the cusp of an era of truly intelligent machines, powered by AI, and Alphabet will play a key role in this exciting new era. In my last year on the board, I will focus on my next chapter in life. I will be staying with Alphabet as a consultant and helping to guide the company as it grows into the future. As we continue to build our portfolio of businesses, I will help the company to make sure that it stays focused on its core mission and that its long-term success is ensured. Over the past 20 years, I have had the pleasure of working with many of the most talented people in the industry, and I am grateful for all of your efforts and for the opportunities to work with you. Thank you.

Scientists were able to use light and bio-ink to print a human ear-like structure under the skin of mice without a single surgical cut. Digital light processing-based 3D bioprinting is a promising technology for tissue engineering, as it can create complex structures with high resolution and accuracy. However, this technique has been limited by its inability to print thick tissues. To address this issue, researchers from the University of California, Berkeley, developed a new method for 3D bioprinting that uses a light-activated polymer to create a scaffold for cells to grow on. This scaffold is then infiltrated with bio-ink, which is a mixture of cells and hydrogel. The researchers successfully printed a human ear-like structure under the skin of mice, and the structure was able to support the growth of cartilage and blood vessels. This study represents a significant advance in the field of 3D bioprinting, and could lead to new treatments for a variety of diseases.

Digital light processing-based 3D bioprinting is an emerging technology that allows for the precise and controlled placement of biological materials layer by layer. Bio-ink, which usually consists of living cells and a support matrix, can be printed in complex shapes and structures that can eventually develop into functional tissues and organs. In the case of the mouse ear-like structure, the scientists used a bioprinter to create a mold of the ear shape, which was then filled with a hydrogel-based bio-ink containing cartilage cells. The mold and bio-ink were then exposed to light, which activated a chemical reaction that cross-linked the molecules in the bio-ink, making it solidify into a solid structure. The mold was removed, and the resulting structure was implanted under the skin of a mouse where it continued to grow and develop into a shape resembling a human ear. This technique has significant potential to revolutionize the field of regenerative medicine, allowing for the creation of replacement tissues and organs that can be tailored to the specific needs of individual patients. It also has the potential to reduce the need for invasive surgical procedures, offering a less painful and more effective treatment option for many medical conditions.

PredPol is a software that claims to use an algorithm to predict crime in specific sections of a city. Several police departments in the US have been quietly experimenting with it, including the LAPD. Well, this morning, the LAPD announced that it's no longer using PredPol, and that it never really used it in the first place. The press conference was called to clear up confusion following a Wired article that claimed that the LAPD's use of PredPol had, in fact, led to an overall decrease in crime. The LAPD's senior lead officer for predictive policing, Sean Malinowski, did not dispute the Wired article's claim that PredPol had led to an overall decrease in crime. But he did dispute the implication that it was PredPol itself that had led to the decrease. "Predictive policing is not a software program. It is not an algorithm," Malinowski said. "Predictive policing is a philosophy, an idea." Malinowski said that PredPol's algorithm did not, in fact, inform LAPD officers where to go or what to do on patrol. Instead, the algorithm merely told them where to focus their attention. The algorithm did not actually make any decisions about where officers should go, nor did it ever guide an officer to a specific location, he said. The purpose of the algorithm is to help officers focus their attention on specific areas that are likely to be crime hotspots. It's up to the officers to decide how to police those hotspots, Malinowski said. In fact, Malinowski said that a lot of the time, officers may not even use the software at all, if they're busy with other things. "You don't have to use PredPol," Malinowski said. "You don't have to use it if you don't want to." PredPol, he said, was merely another tool in the toolbox. It's the latest in a series of setbacks for PredPol and other predictive policing technologies. Last month, the Santa Cruz Police Department in California announced that it was suspending its use of PredPol, following a scathing report by the ACLU. The ACLU had found that the predictive policing software was disproportionately targeting low-income, minority communities for police patrols. Similarly, a recent ProPublica investigation also found that the predictive policing software used by the Chicago PD disproportionately targeted black communities. The ACLU is also currently fighting a lawsuit against the New York Police Department, challenging the constitutionality of its predictive policing program.

PredPol is a software that claims to use an algorithm to predict crime in specific sections of a city. Several police departments in the US have been quietly experimenting with PredPol, using it to create maps showing which areas of a city are at risk of a crime outbreak. Predicting crime, even if the numbers are wrong, could help police figure out where they need to put more resources. But a 2012 study of PredPol's predictions by the University of Pennsylvania found that, despite its claims, the software is terrible at predicting crime. And even worse, the software can create false positives and negatively impact an area. Police departments are already using PredPol in Baltimore, Boston, Cleveland, New York, and other cities, but the software is also being used by private companies like Gnip and Reveal, which sell it to police departments. Police departments don't know that their officers are using the software, so they're relying on its predictions without being aware of the potential consequences. Predicting crime isn't a perfect science, and there's no way to guarantee that a system that's designed to predict it will always be right. But if police departments are using PredPol to decide where to deploy resources, and they're using that software in a way that creates false positives, it could have a real impact on communities of color. There are ways that police departments can mitigate the problem, though. The use of PredPol by police departments in Baltimore, Cleveland, and New York is prohibited. In New York, the NYPD has said that they will only use PredPol to try to predict crime, and not to decide where to deploy resources. If you want to see what a police department might do if they use PredPol to decide where to deploy resources, check out the YouTube channel Cops and Robbers.

Several police departments in the US have been quietly experimenting with this system, and some municipalities are planning to deploy it. The idea behind PredPol is simple: A camera equipped on foot patrols would capture photos from multiple angles every few seconds or so. The images can then be analyzed by algorithms which assess factors like crowd density, building size and proximity to other buildings, as well as lighting conditions and weather patterns (e.g., if it's rainy). Based on these data points, the computer will automatically generate predictions about potential criminal activity, such as drug dealing, robbery, assault and theft. PredPol is a software that claims to use an algorithm to predict crime in specific sections of a city. Several police departments in the US have been quietly experimenting with PredPol for a number of years. The software analyzes data such as crime reports, weather, and local events to produce a "heat map" of the areas in a city where crime is most likely to occur. Police officers can then use this information to target their patrols and increase their presence in high-risk areas. While some police departments have reported success with PredPol in reducing crime rates, others have raised concerns about the potential for the software to perpetuate bias and lead to over-policing of certain communities. Critics argue that the algorithm reinforces the targeting of certain neighborhoods based on past crime data, which may not accurately reflect current conditions or individual behavior. Additionally, there have been concerns raised about the transparency of the algorithm and the potential for errors or bias in the data that it uses. Overall, the use of PredPol remains controversial, and many experts agree that it should be used in conjunction with other methods of community policing and crime prevention.

Since 2016, Citizen Lab has been tracking the use of NSO Group's Pegasus malware to target civil society and vulnerable populations. In this talk, John Scott-Railton will discuss Citizen Lab's ongoing work to protect civil society from abusive surveillance technology, and the process of discovering and reporting on the misuse of Pegasus malware. He will explain how Citizen Lab uses a combination of network measurement, targeted vulnerability testing, and digital forensics to investigate the misuse of spyware, and discuss the implications of the findings for journalists, civil society, and the broader tech industry. John Scott-Railton is a senior researcher at The Citizen Lab at the Munk School of Global Affairs, University of Toronto. His work investigates the use of commercial spyware by state and non-state actors to target civil society. John Scott-Railton is a senior researcher at the Citizen Lab, where he leads projects investigating the use of surveillance technologies to infringe on human rights. His work has helped expose the illegal use of commercial spyware by governments in Mexico, the United Arab Emirates, and Morocco, as well as targeted attacks on civil society in Pakistan, Vietnam, and Saudi Arabia. His research has been published in The New York Times, The Washington Post, Wired, Bloomberg, and other media outlets. Prior to joining the Citizen Lab, John was a policy analyst at Access, where he worked on issues of internet censorship, surveillance, and cybersecurity. He holds an MA in international relations from the University of Cambridge, and a BA in international relations and French from Tufts University. This event will be followed by a networking reception.

The Israeli surveillance company NSO Group sells hacking software used by authoritarian governments to target citizens around the world. Pegasus is a malware that infects mobile devices and extracts data. Thank you for the information. It is important to note that the use of such hacking software by authoritarian governments can be a violation of human rights, particularly the right to privacy. Governments and corporations should prioritize the protection of the rights of their citizens and consumers.

The Israeli surveillance company NSO Group sells hacking software used by authoritarian governments to target citizens around the world. Pegasus is a malware that infects mobile devices and extracts data. Reuters reports it was sold in at least 90 countries. NSO's CTO Amnon Shashua denies its products can be used for geopolitical purposes, but Israel does not have laws against this sort of activity either - according to Amnesty International, "At no point did any investigation into whether criminal use had taken place" by the head prosecutor's office or other government agencies. Cyberwarfare has become political weaponization with the rise of national security state apparatuses...systematic violations of human rights are now tacitly authorized as part of counterterrorism campaigns. Former CIA Director John Brennan describes how intelligence services routinely tap communications, including WhatsApp chats, using espionage technology called the Prisma (Plastic Sieve Project) program: It allows you to monitor all outgoing messages from your phone without letting anybody know it's there. In fact they're going through all Facebook Messenger communications, all email communication, all things you're sending out on social media - even if someone deletes their message when sent... When I make an argument about domestic terrorism, like I've done since 911, having access to everything you're communicating starts getting very dangerous because then people start thinking you've got something else up under the hood; or maybe I'm spying on them so I can report back what we do; which could lead right down the road to some pretty serious civil liberties litigation. The more information you get also means the harder it becomes to defend yourself legally afterwards. (...) Of course, NSA director Michael Rogers didn't say anything new here. He confirmed his agency uses similar techniques, such as those described above, for law enforcement purposes: The question is why would anyone engage in civil disobedience? Wouldn't it be better to dress casually, knock off work early every day ask permission before speaking publicly about Islamophobia? Examples abound where individuals went public about issues of privilege and hypocrisy inside the ranks of American society, especially women who were subjected to sexual harassment and assault for decades while working in places like Hollywood and Silicon Valley. This blog doesn't want to suggest that these acts aren't worthy of condemnation, but our purpose today is simply to call attention to events outside America that might shed light upon a broader reality.

The Israeli surveillance company NSO Group sells hacking software used by authoritarian governments to target citizens around the world. Pegasus is a malware that infects mobile devices and extracts data. It can record calls and secretly activate microphones. The malware can infect phones without any user interaction. NSO sells the malware to military, law enforcement, and intelligence agencies in 40 unnamed countries.

Jerdon's jumping worker ants can become reproductive queens when their queens die. The transition comes with changes to the ant's brain, gene expression, hormone levels, and cell composition. Researchers have found that these physiological changes occur during a specific time window in late winter or early spring. The Jerdon population study was part of an international effort between UBC researchers and biologists at the University of Vienna; it used field observations over several years, as well as laboratory experiments.

Jerdon's jumping worker ants can become reproductive queens when their queens die. The transition comes with changes to the ant's brain, gene expression, hormone levels, and cell composition. Researchers have discovered that the brain is key to the transformation, as it controls the activity of genes and hormones that regulate the ant's reproductive development. The study, published in the journal Nature Communications, suggests that the Jerdon's jumping ant provides a new model for understanding how social insects regulate reproduction. The findings could help scientists understand how to control the reproduction of ants and other social insects, which could have implications for pest control and conservation.

Jerdon's jumping worker ants can become reproductive queens when their queens die. The transition comes with changes to the ant's brain, gene expression, hormone levels, and cell composition. Researchers have found a protein that is activated when the ants are injected with social hormones. The hormones appear to affect which genes the protein binds to, with the same protein causing ants to change from worker to queen and vice versa depending on which hormone was given. The research suggests that there may be multiple behaviors in the ant genome that could be expressed with gene regulation.

Jerdon's jumping worker ants can become reproductive queens when their queens die. The transition comes with changes to the ant's brain, gene expression, hormone levels, and cell composition. Researchers have identified a gene called Kr-h1 that is involved in this transition process, as its expression increases in jumping worker ants that are becoming queens. Additionally, researchers have found that the hormone juvenile hormone III plays a crucial role in this transition, as it triggers the developmental changes necessary for the ant to become a queen. These findings shed light on the complex biological processes that underlie the social organization and reproduction in ant colonies.

Jerdon's jumping worker ants can become reproductive queens when their queens die. The transition comes with changes to the ant's brain, gene expression, hormone levels, and cell composition. Researchers have previously discovered that a type of neuron in the brain of a queen ant can produce hormones that activate queen genes, allowing the queen to begin her reproductive cycle. In this study, scientists analyzed the brain of the queen ant, the queen's descendants, and the queen's "stepchildren" to learn more about the evolutionary changes that occurred after the queen's death. The researchers discovered that the queen's descendants and stepchildren had lower numbers of the queen-making neurons in their brains. This means that the brain changes that make queens can be passed on to the next generation, allowing the colony to continue producing queens after a queen dies. "This study suggests that queen inheritance occurs through the brain, and not through some other, as yet unknown mechanism," said Dr. Adam Baker, co-author of the study and a neurobiologist at the University of Bristol. "It is clear that these brain changes are part of the molecular mechanisms that determine whether an individual becomes a queen or a worker." The researchers also found that the queen's descendants and stepchildren have lower numbers of a hormone called octopamine, which is produced by a type of neuron that helps control how the queen ant responds to mating signals. The hormone plays a role in octopamine-mediated learning and memory. The researchers found that the queens had the highest number of octopamine-producing neurons, which suggests that the queens have the highest memory for mating. "We think that the queen's descendants and stepchildren have a memory deficit," said Baker. "This deficit in memory could be the result of a decrease in the number of octopamine neurons in the brain. Reduced octopamine production could cause the queen's descendants and stepchildren to lose their memories of mating." The study, "Neurogenetic inheritance of queen-making ability in a trophically controlled ant," was published in the journal BMC Evolutionary Biology.

Jerdon's jumping worker ants can become reproductive queens when their queens die. The transition comes with changes to the ant's brain, gene expression, hormone levels, and cell composition. Researchers have found that a protein, SfSPH, is involved in those changes. Credit: Tatyana Livshyts Ants are social insects that typically live in nests of a single breed, or "caste," which consists of wingless females who are workers that forage for food and care for the young. But in some species, worker ants can develop wings and take on the role of a reproductive female when their queen dies. The switch from worker to queen is accompanied by a shift in the way the ant's brain is wired, changes in its gene expression, and hormone levels, and a change in the composition of the cells that make up the brain. A team of scientists led by Rockefeller University's Daniel Kronauer is studying these changes. In a new paper published in PLOS Biology, they report that a single protein, SfSPH, is involved in both the dramatic shift in brain function as well as the shift in brain composition. The discovery came when the researchers set out to uncover the function of a protein called SfSPH, which they found was produced in the brains of young workers and queens, but not in the brains of older workers. "This protein is a member of a family of proteins that are involved in embryonic development," Kronauer says. "In flies and worms, other members of the SPH family of proteins control cell division and morphology during development. But we didn't see any changes in the cell number or shape of the ant brain after the ants transitioned to queens. We wondered what was going on." To investigate, the researchers turned to a technique that Kronauer's lab has used in the past to study the connections between ants' brains and behavior. In this case, they used a toxin to remove the SfSPH protein from the brains of workers who were in the process of becoming queens. The toxin only affected a single type of cell in the ant's brain. "We found that the ants treated with the toxin did not go on to become queens," says Kronauer. "They became workers, and only workers." Ants that received the toxin treatment maintained the brain composition and connections of a worker, suggesting that SfSPH plays an essential role in the dramatic changes that take place in a worker ant's brain when it becomes a queen. The researchers also found that SfSPH is involved in regulating a reproductive hormone. When they treated the transitioning workers with the toxin, the levels of the hormone - called Duf - dropped. Without SfSPH, the workers never made the transition to queen. "This is an important first step toward understanding how neural plasticity is involved in controlling behavior," says Kronauer. A 122,000-tonne ultra-large natural gas tanker is the first large ship to make an ocean passage of over 10,000 km under autonomous control. Prism Courage made the 33-day voyage from Texas to South Korea using an autonomous navigation system called HiNAS 2.0. HiNAS 2.0 steered the ship, calculated optimal routes and best speeds, and also located and avoided other ships. The system increased fuel efficiency by 7 and reduced greenhouse emissions by 5. HiNAS 2.0 will be on the market by next year, pending official certifications.

A 122,000-tonne ultra-large natural gas tanker is the first large ship to make an ocean passage of over 10,000 km under autonomous control. Prism Courage made the 33-day voyage from Norway to South Korea, covering a distance of 10,656 nautical miles, and was monitored by a team of remote operators from a control center in Norway. This achievement represents a significant milestone in the development of autonomous marine transportation, which can help to reduce costs and improve safety, efficiency and environmental performance.

A 122,000-tonne ultra-large natural gas tanker is the first large ship to make an ocean passage of over 10,000 km under autonomous control. Prism Courage made the 33-day voyage from South Korea to China, where it is now being fitted out to operate as a Floating Storage and Regasification Unit (FSRU). The 260-metre long LNG carrier was built at Hyundai Mipo Dockyard for Norway's Knutsen, and is being converted at the Wison Offshore Marine Shipyard in Nantong, China, for operation as a floating LNG import terminal. During its maiden voyage Prism Courage was controlled by a system developed by Rolls-Royce. The company says that the cargo handling was fully automated, with the ship's control and navigation systems on board monitoring the vessel's position and movement at all times. It is not the first time that Rolls-Royce has demonstrated autonomous ship technology. In December 2018 the Norwegian Coastal Administration's multipurpose vessel, RV Gunnerus, also completed a sea trial in the Trondheim fjord. A major milestone in the development of autonomous ship technology is now being achieved by the Finnish firm Wartsila. It has announced that it is to test a ferry with autonomous navigation in the waters of Finland. The tests are to be carried out in the first half of 2019, and will use the 83-metre long ferry Falco, owned by Finferries. The vessel operates on a route between the Finnish mainland and the island of Korppoo. The 1,500-tonne ship will be fitted with a Wartsila Nacos Platinum Joystick system, which will control the ship's navigation. The system incorporates dynamic positioning and route optimisation, and has a track control system that can compensate for external factors that affect a ship's progress, such as waves, wind and currents. Wartsila has made it clear that the Falco is not to be an unmanned vessel. The system will be operated and monitored onboard the ship, with no remote control. The main objective of the tests is to develop autonomous navigation and positioning capabilities. "It is important to note that vessels like Falco operate in an intensely congested sea area where there is an especially high volume of ferry traffic and cargo transports," said Wartsila's Jonne Jokela. "Developing this technology can have a considerable impact in terms of safety and efficiency," he added. The pace of development of autonomous ship technology is such that Rolls-Royce has now established its own autonomous vessel operations centre in Turku, Finland, which has the responsibility for developing the technology. The control centre is equipped with sophisticated software that enables it to operate several ships at the same time from a distance of hundreds of miles. "We want to take a leading role in developing fully autonomous ships. This is the most important development project for us today," said Rolls-Royce's Esko Mustamaki. "We will use the centre to develop our technology and to find out what regulations are needed for autonomous ships. This is an excellent example of a partnership between industry and academia, and we hope to learn a great deal from the feedback provided by our partners in Turku," he added. Meanwhile, the US Coast Guard is stepping up its efforts to develop regulations for autonomous ships. It has published the first draft of a document that is intended to provide guidance to owners and operators of autonomous ships. It is called Navigation and Vessel Inspection Circular (NVIC) 01-18, and is described as a first step towards addressing the use of emerging technologies in the maritime industry. The NVIC states that autonomous systems have the potential to enhance maritime safety, and can provide a means to reduce workload onboard, improve vessel performance and efficiency, and decrease the likelihood of human error. "To properly and fully address autonomous technology in the marine environment, the Coast Guard is pursuing a 'think big, start small and scale fast' strategy," said the Coast Guard's Jeff Lantz. It is not just Rolls-Royce and Wartsila that are developing autonomous ship technology. Last year we reported on how an autonomous containership had been operated by Japan's MOL in a demonstration in Tokyo Bay.

Prism Courage made the 33-day voyage from Hong Kong to New York City on Nov. 19. The vessel was able to navigate through a thunderstorm off Cape Cod in Massachusetts and reach its destination within three days after making port at Nova Scotia's Halifax Harbour last week. "As we move into such advanced technology applications for shipping operations, this will be our next step towards full autonomy where there are no human operators required on board any time during normal operation conditions or emergencies," said Mr. Yu. Singapore-based maritime logistics company Keppel Offshore Marine recently introduced its new position safety system (PSS) with Navtech Technology Systems as part of Singapore's international connectivity strategy and global leadership in smart ports using blockchain software that uses AI algorithms to verify maritime regulations. Keppel OM has invested US6 million in PSS and it can now check whether vessels adhere to local laws while they're out at sea. It also plans soon to introduce the latest version of the positioning services platform - called OceanNav Connect 4 - which allows ships to exchange data without having to pay communication fees if nearby sensors have been installed by other shippers or government agencies. OceanNav is based on open-source code developed by OpenTreaX, a European consortium funded by Horizon 2020 programme of the EU Commission. Companies including ABB Group, Airbus Defense And Space, Total SA, Siemens Gamesa Renewable Energy, The Dow Chemical Company, ST Engineering Ltd, United Technologies SE, Valeo SAS, SGS N.V., Codelco Chile, APL Resources Limited, Eni SpA, Alstom Power Inc., Thales Group and many others have joined Vessel Traffic Services project since 2012. A 122,000-tonne ultra-large natural gas tanker is the first large ship to make an ocean passage of over 10,000 km under autonomous control. Prism Courage made the 33-day voyage from Kaohsiung, Taiwan, to Rotterdam, Netherlands, without a human captain or crew on board. The 200-metre-long vessel is owned by Japanese shipping company Mitsui OSK Lines and is designed to carry up to 180,000 cubic metres of LNG. It is equipped with a range of sensors and systems that allow it to navigate autonomously, including a satellite navigation system, a radar and a collision avoidance system. The voyage was part of a trial to test the safety and reliability of autonomous shipping. The ship was monitored by a team of experts onshore who were able to take control of the vessel if necessary. The trial was a success and the ship arrived in Rotterdam on time and without incident. The company said that it plans to use autonomous technology on more of its ships in the future.

Jekyll is an open source blogging system which can be used to create beautifully designed magazine-style blogs or completely new sites using simple markup languages like Markdown. The advantage of Jekyll over WordPress are its simplicity - it has no tables, forms nor the more complex theme options available in WP; however you do gain access to all powerful tools such as Bootstrap. Liquid is a template language for creating dynamic layouts inspired by Twitter's Card Layout framework. Liquid works well if you're wanting to build a mobile-friendly website but also lets you design elegant pages without having any programming skills at your disposal. Yii2 is a PHP MVC Framework developed especially for building web applications. This allows developers to make use of advanced technologies like caching and built-in security while providing full support for unit testing including postgetpostman integration. WordPress comes pre-installed with many different themes from which developers can choose one that's best suited for their project and have it installed immediately! That said; there are tons of free and paid premium themes out there ready to go so you don't have to spend time learning how they work! The main disadvantage to this approach is probably data leaking between wordpress installations. Especially when sharing hosting accounts it's very important check what plugins are enabled before installing them again else someone could hijack the database! It shouldn't matter if you decide not to purchase a pre-made theme since the foundation for every theme exists offsite inside the public repository. So just download whatever you want and start modifying it right away: This takes no coding knowledge whatsoever -the only thing you need are some basic HTMLCSS3 knowledge along with a little bit of handcrafting skills... And even then, once everything gets set up correctly, very few people would notice! You'll typically find most senior level engineers working solely within an established agile process rather than operating independently within small teams. For example we've seen companies move much closer towards Agile Agile processes where individual team members provide value throughout the entire product development lifecycle.

oneshot is an easy way to set up an HTTP server to share files, web pages, or other outputs using the command line. Users just need to specify the path to the directory containing the files they want to share, and oneshot will start an HTTP server on port 8080. Any files that are added to the directory will be automatically served by the server. oneshot is also capable of serving static HTML pages, and can be used to host simple web applications.

Airspeeder's electric flying race car has completed its first unpiloted test flights in southern Australia. The Alauda Mk3 is an electric vertical takeoff multicopter (eVTOL). Airspeeder's electric flying race car has completed its first unpiloted test flights in southern Australia. The Alauda Mk3 is an electric vertical takeoff multicopter (eVTOL). It weighs 130 kilograms and can reach a top speed of 100 kmh, carrying a payload of up to 300 kg. Advertisement The eVTOL was unveiled at the Aeronautical Society of Australia in Perth in March, with plans to use it to race from Perth to Darwin. It has now been sent off to the company's facility in the Queensland city of Cairns, where it will undergo further testing. The 43-year-old's plans to make history as the first Australian to pilot a flying car have been put on hold. Credit:Tony Moore "This is the first step towards making it a reality," said CEO and co-founder of Airspeeder, Mikel Furtado. "It has been a long and winding road, but we are excited to be moving forward with the Mk3." He said the company was on track to have the car on the road by 2020. "This is an exciting time for our company," he said. "We have made significant progress over the last few months in developing a new electric air vehicle. We are very excited about what is to come." In March, the eVTOL was unveiled at the Aeronautical Society of Australia. It is the third model of the eVTOL, a vehicle that can take off vertically, then transition to a more conventional fixed-wing configuration, and fly at speeds up to 100 kilometres per hour. It has been designed to carry passengers and cargo. The company said it will be the first car in the world to use "a novel flying motor" that allows it to go vertical. It will be able to take off and land vertically without a runway. Furtado said the car would not be fitted with a steering wheel or pedals. It would be steered by a computer, with an on-board computer controlling the flight path and altitude. "We will not be using the ground as a steering wheel," he said. "We will have the ability to fly in all directions in three dimensions." Advertisement The car will be propelled by electric motors that have no moving parts. Furtado said it was the first time that the company had made any aircraft or car that had no moving parts. He said it was not clear yet whether the company would sell the car to individuals, or to commercial customers, but that it was working on the idea of the car being used in mining and oil exploration. "We are going to start with the mass market," he said. "We are working on it for commercial customers, too." The car has been built in the Brisbane factory of French aeronautical company, Ecureuil, which has designed and produced the first two eVTOLs. Furtado said the company had started building the car in 2014. "The first one is 2014, and this one is 2019," he said. "It's a bit like building a car. It is taking time." The eVTOL is about 4.5 metres long, and weighs about 130 kilograms. The company said it would be the first car in the world to use "a novel flying motor" that allows it to go vertical. It will be able to take off and land vertically without a runway. Credit:Tony Moore "It has two big advantages over conventional aircraft," Furtado said. "It is not going to use fuel. It has no moving parts, and it has no need to have a runway." He said it was "extremely safe," and had been developed to be as safe as possible. "It is safer than conventional aircraft, and safer than a car," he said. "It is like a flying car, but it is not like a flying car. It is safer than a car, and safer than an aircraft." He said the company had had about 200 applications for the eVTOL, which it had used in trials in South Australia, and Queensland. "We are building it for the mass market," he said.

Every machine learning model is based on linear algebra. This document contains introductory level linear algebra notes for applied machine learning. The notes are meant to be used as a starting point or reference in preparing course material, but do not involve any prerequisites beyond basic knowledge of mathematics. The objective of this note is two-fold: First, it explains the basics and rationale behind certain linear algebra concepts that have recently been found useful when applying advanced machine learning techniques such as deep neural networks (DNNs); secondly, it describes fundamental mathematical results about matrices needed in traditional numerical analysis settings which can often be directly translated into computational algorithms using modern software packages to speed up implementation of these models. While some aspects of computing theory had already emerged during the development of ML, much has changed since the original days of statistics. Machine Learning consists now rather than just statistical inference, with its own algorithmic framework providing an alternative approach from exact interpretation. Interesting applications include computer vision, speech recognition, natural language processing, bioinformatics and economics. As always happens, there's nothing more compelling than new challenges! In particular, AI research requires new ideas and skills to progress towards real-world application scenarios. And today we will see why this is true.

Every machine learning model is based on linear algebra. This document contains introductory level linear algebra notes for applied machine learning. The notes are meant to be used as a quick reference for students who are already familiar with the material.

Every machine learning model is based on linear algebra. This document contains introductory level linear algebra notes for applied machine learning. The notes are meant to be used as a starting point for learning linear algebra, rather than as an in-depth study of linear algebra. The notes are primarily written in terms of linear regression, but can be easily applied to other machine learning models as well. For a more detailed review of linear algebra, see Linear Algebra Done Right by Andrew Kolluri and Linear Algebra in Computer Vision by Dan Challen. Preliminaries Linear algebra is based on the linear space of real numbers. The dimension of the space is called the dimension of the linear space. A linear transformation is a mapping from one linear space to another. A vector is a point in a linear space. A matrix is a matrix of numbers, where each row of the matrix is a vector. A matrix is called a square matrix if each row of the matrix has the same number of elements. A matrix is called symmetric if each row of the matrix is the same as the corresponding column. A matrix is called Hermitian if the sum of each row is equal to the sum of the corresponding column. A matrix is called a diagonal matrix if each row and column contains only one number. Symmetric and Hermitian matrices can be used to build other matrices, and diagonal matrices can be used to build other diagonal matrices. Matrix decompositions LU decomposition Given an m-by-n matrix A, we can find the LU decomposition of A as follows: L is an m-by-m upper triangular matrix with diagonal elements equal to 1. U is an n-by-n upper triangular matrix with diagonal elements equal to 1. A is the product of L and U. This is called the LU decomposition. Singular value decomposition Given an m-by-n matrix A, we can find the SVD of A as follows: U is an m-by-m orthogonal matrix, such that each column of U is an orthonormal basis for the column space of A. V is an n-by-n orthogonal matrix, such that each column of V is an orthonormal basis for the row space of A. S is an n-by-n diagonal matrix, such that the diagonal elements of S are the singular values of A. The columns of U and V are orthonormal, and the columns of S are the singular values of A. The singular values of A are sorted in descending order, such that the largest singular value is the first singular value, and the smallest singular value is the last singular value. This is called the SVD of A. Singular values can be interpreted as the squares of the distances between the data points in the column space of A and the data points in the row space of A. The singular values of A are sorted in descending order, such that the largest singular value is the first singular value, and the smallest singular value is the last singular value. This is called the SVD of A. QR decomposition Given an m-by-n matrix A, we can find the QR decomposition of A as follows: Q is an m-by-m orthogonal matrix, such that each column of Q is an orthonormal basis for the column space of A. R is an n-by-n upper triangular matrix with diagonal elements equal to 1. A is the product of Q and R. This is called the QR decomposition. Eigenvalue decomposition Given an m-by-n matrix A, we can find the eigenvalue decomposition of A as follows: E is an n-by-n diagonal matrix, such that the diagonal elements of E are the eigenvalues of A. A is the product of E and a diagonal matrix D, where D contains the eigenvectors of A. This is called the eigenvalue decomposition. The eigenvalues of A are sorted in ascending order, such that the first eigenvalue is the largest eigenvalue, and the last eigenvalue is the smallest eigenvalue. This is called the eigenvalue decomposition. Eigenvector decomposition Given an m-by-n matrix A, we can find the eigenvector decomposition of A as follows: E is an n-by-n diagonal matrix, such that the diagonal elements of E are the eigenvalues of A. A is the product of E and a diagonal matrix D, where D contains the eigenvectors of A. This is called the eigenvalue decomposition. The eigenvectors of A are sorted in ascending order, such that the first eigenvector is the largest eigenvector, and the last eigenvector is the smallest eigenvector. This is called the eigenvector decomposition. SVD decomposition The SVD decomposition of a matrix A is given by: U is an m-by-m orthogonal matrix, such that each column of U is an orthonormal basis for the column space of A. V is an n-by-n orthogonal matrix, such that each column of V is an orthonormal basis for the row space of A. S is an n-by-n diagonal matrix, such that the diagonal elements of S are the singular values of A.

The Apple Store went down for just over an hour on Tuesday and came back with a brand-new look. The new design is filled with cards, similar to Apple's Store app for iOS. The cards are arranged in a grid, and users can tap on them to learn more about the product or to purchase it. The new design also includes a search bar at the top of the page, as well as a list of categories on the left side of the screen. The Apple Store went down for just over an hour on Tuesday and came back with a brand-new look. The new design is filled with cards, similar to Apple's Store app for iOS, and is more about helping you buy a product, rather than just shopping for one. The site now features a card-based design similar to Apple's iOS and tvOS apps, including Apple Pay support for purchasing items directly from the site, along with the addition of a new account preference allowing for site-wide dark mode to match the dark mode option in macOS Mojave. The redesign includes a "Shop Now" button on the top right, which takes you to the site's full catalog. In the left-hand navigation bar, the old "iPhone" option has been replaced with "Apple," which will take you to all of the company's devices, including the iPhone, iPad, Mac, Apple Watch, Apple TV, HomePod, and more. The left-hand navigation bar also includes categories for Services, Apple Store, Support, and Apple Newsroom, while the right-hand side has options to log in to your account, check your order status, chat with a Specialist, set up an appointment at an Apple Store, or find your local Apple Store. On the homepage, Apple highlights its latest and greatest products with larger images and fewer words, a major change from the previous design that featured many products with smaller images and a lot of text. The website is also full of touches from Apple's "beyond the page" design language, including curved page corners, drop shadows, and more. In the navigation bar for individual product pages, there's now a "More Details" option that can be toggled to show more specs about the product, and Apple has added a new "Compare" feature to make it easier to see the differences between products. The new Compare feature is also available on iOS in the Apple Store app. The site's checkout process now supports Apple Pay, allowing you to complete a purchase with Touch ID on the iPhone or Mac, or Face ID on the iPhone X. Apple Pay can be used in the browser to complete purchases on the new Apple Store, even when using an iPad or Mac without Touch ID. The redesigned Apple Store website was first noticed by users in early October. Apple is in the process of revamping its online store experience to better highlight products. These new store pages are built on a completely new platform that Apple is calling "WebKit2," which will be replacing the company's old e-commerce platform, "Yosemite." For Apple, this means that the online store will be updated more frequently with new content, and new products will be easier to launch. Apple's website is designed in a way that allows the company to launch new products, pages, and even site designs, without having to go through the App Store review process like third-party developers. Update 1023: Apple has also introduced a new "Dark Mode" option in the footer of its website. When enabled, the Apple Store's website design and content will have a dark tint to it, matching the new "Dark Mode" option in macOS Mojave. btrace is an Android trace tool based on Systrace. It supports custom and native events, and it can be set to only capture trace events of the main thread. btrace also has a number of other features including the ability to capture non-trace events and dump traces as HTML for review. btrace should be available in the Google Play store. You can also download the apk and install it manually. This is the recommended way to install btrace. Go to Settings - Developer options. Make sure you have enabled Developer options. Make sure you have enabled USB debugging. Connect the device to your computer and open the command-line. Note: The device serial number is not printed in the output of lsusb. Use lsusb -v to see the serial number. Run the command to install the apk. This should be the last resort. You will be given the option to install from unknown sources. This option should not be enabled in general. Note: The version of the app in Google Play may be more recent than the version on this page. Download the apk and install it on your device. btrace uses the Google Play Services Framework, so you need to make sure the Google Play Services app is installed. btrace is currently in beta. Expect bugs. It is not compatible with all devices. For best results, follow the instructions and ensure the app is set up correctly. If you find bugs, please email me. Before you can run btrace, you need to grant it the necessary permissions. Go to Settings - Developer options - Apps. Open the btrace entry and tap on Permissions. Grant the following permissions: draw over other apps, and mock locations. If btrace doesn't appear in the list of apps, then you haven't enabled Developer options. You can now run btrace. btrace has a number of options. You can review these options by tapping on the Help button at the bottom of the screen. The options are also described in this section. By default, btrace will be enabled after the app has been launched. If you want to enable it immediately, tap the Enable button. The Enable option at the bottom of the screen will be replaced by a Disable button. If you want to disable btrace, tap the Disable button. btrace is a Systrace app, so it has all the features of Systrace. It also has some additional features. You can use btrace to trace native or custom events. If you only want to trace custom events, tap the Native button and select OFF. Tap the Custom button and select ON. If you only want to trace the events of the main thread, tap the Main button. You can choose to capture non-trace events. By default, btrace captures non-trace events. The non-trace events include the package name, the class name, and the method name. The name of the package, class, and method are written to the btracefile. Note: It is possible to capture all the Android trace events using btrace. However, there is a limit to the amount of trace data you can capture. The limit is 1000 trace events per second. If this limit is exceeded, trace events will be lost. When you run btrace, all the trace events are written to a file. You can later view this file in btrace. You can also export this file to a number of other formats including html. You can also save the trace file to your PC. btrace can be configured to start automatically when you connect the device to your PC. If you want to enable this feature, tap the Startup button and select the option. By default, the device will be in USB debugging mode when you connect it to your PC. If you want to change this setting, tap the USB Debugging button and select the option. By default, btrace will be in visible mode when you connect your device to your PC. You can choose to start it in invisible mode. If you want to uninstall btrace, tap the Uninstall button and select the option. A number of people have asked about the source for btrace. I am not going to release the source code for the app. I will, however, consider releasing a version of the app with the code stripped. You can also contact me for the source code.

btrace has some advantages over Systrace, such as being able to capture more detailed information about threads and their activities. It also provides a more user-friendly interface and is easier to use than Systrace.
