This would help to increase transparency and give customers more control over their personal information. If the act is passed, companies would need to provide an annual report to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) outlining how much money they make from customer data, as well as providing individual user data upon request. This would help to hold companies accountable for their collection and use of customer data, and would also give customers greater insight into the value of their data.

Companies such as Facebook and Google may soon be forced to inform customers individually on how much profit they gain from customer data. The proposed Designing Accounting Safeguards to Help Protect Privacy Act (DASH) aims at pushing for a new accounting standard that would force companies to disclose their privacy practices. The DSH is being put forward by the U.S Chamber of Commerce, which has argued in its submission to Congress that "existing laws do not provide sufficient safeguards to protect individuals' private information."

Companies such as Facebook and Google may soon be forced to inform customers individually on how much profit they gain from customer data. The proposed Designing Accounting Safeguards to Help Ensure Fair Use of Customer Data Act of 2019 (DATA Act) will regulate how companies can sell data collected from users, and allow users to control how much data companies can sell to third parties. The bill, introduced by Representative Al Green (D-TX), states that "unfair, deceptive, or abusive practices may not be used by service providers to gain or retain the business of customers or third parties." It will give the Federal Trade Commission the authority to investigate these practices, and may also create new liability for companies. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg told Congress in a March hearing that his company would not engage in "bait and switch" tactics, but the DATA Act may force the company to reveal how much it charges for the data it collects, and what it does with that data. Facebook did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Scientists have grown plants in lunar soil using samples collected during the Apollo missions to the moon. The scientists grew thale cress, a small flowering plant that is attractive to pollinating insects. It is considered an ideal specimen for scientific experiments. The researchers say the experiment is the first step in mankind's long-term goal to colonise the moon. The lunar soil was collected from several Apollo missions to the moon, which took place in the late 1960s and early 1970s. The soil was mixed with earth from Iceland to create the growth medium. Thale cress was chosen for the experiment because it grows rapidly, produces a large amount of seeds and has few nutritional requirements. The cress was exposed to several different concentrations of simulated lunar soil. The plants were also exposed to varying concentrations of lunar and earth soil. The researchers concluded that the growth rate and survival rate of thale cress was similar to that of plants grown in earth soil alone. The research team consisted of scientists from the Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences in Uppsala, Sweden and Wageningen University in the Netherlands. The team says the results of the experiment provide a good basis for continued studies into the feasibility of growing plants on the moon. The researchers say a manned moon base could provide shelter and fuel, but astronauts would have to be provided with fresh food. Researchers have previously suggested using hydroponic greenhouses, but the new experiment shows plants could be grown in lunar soil without the need for complex systems to provide nutrients. The results of the experiment are published in the journal Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta.

Scientists have grown plants in lunar soil using samples collected during the Apollo missions to the moon. The scientists grew thale cress, a small flowering plant that is attractive to pollinators and commonly used in scientific research, in a specially designed chamber that simulated lunar conditions such as atmospheric pressure, temperature, and light exposure. The plants were successfully able to germinate and grow in the lunar soil, showing that future human settlements on the moon could potentially farm and grow their own food using local resources. This is a significant step towards achieving sustainable food production and self-sufficiency in space exploration.

Scientists have grown plants in lunar soil using samples collected during the Apollo missions to the moon. The scientists grew thale cress, a small flowering plant that is attractive to bees. Lunar dust was very important for growing things because it survived space flight and trips back through Earth's magnetic field. (Image credit: NASA) The researchers found that the growth of these seeds on average took about six weeks longer than when they were grown under normal conditions - meaning nearly three full months less time taken. Even though we're talking long distances here (the astronauts flew almost 30 million miles), it's still remarkably fast compared with what happens in our own planet. For example, plant life can take up to four years just to grow from seed. But even slower rates are possible. Plants adapted to Antarctica live at an astonishing rate of only one year per solar cycle! That means that if you live there all your life then after just 24 cycles you're going to be 70! Waymo also uses its simulator to test out new features and software, and runs through different scenarios to make sure the self-driving software is performing properly. As the company puts it, "By going through every step of a drive, from start to finish, this approach helps us test new features and edge cases in a systematic way. It allows us to refine our driving software at the component level - everything from identifying objects on the road to planning a safe route to a destination." To make these simulations as accurate as possible, Waymo has created a virtual world that resembles Phoenix, Arizona - the location where the company is currently testing its self-driving cars. "We've painstakingly created a virtual world that models every road, lane, and intersection in our test market of Phoenix, Arizona - a 200 square mile city - and we've equipped our simulated vehicles with the same sensors and software used on our physical vehicles," Waymo explains. Waymo says it will continue to use simulations to test out features and self-driving software and plans to double down on its simulation efforts in the future. At the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) 2016 in Las Vegas, Nevada, there were some interesting and impressive advances in battery technology. We saw companies like Emotiv and Qualcomm introduce new portable, lightweight, and energy efficient batteries that would make for ideal batteries for wearables and IoT devices. While these advances are promising, there are still some limitations. For example, most IoT devices don't need to run for long periods of time, so they can be powered by relatively small batteries. On the other hand, wearables and smart phones need to last for hours at a time, so they need to use larger batteries. Unfortunately, large batteries can be heavy and require more power, which can be challenging for IoT devices. While companies are developing smaller and more efficient batteries, it's also important to think about the impact of batteries on the environment. With IoT devices proliferating, it's critical that we develop new battery technologies that can be reused and are less harmful to the environment. A group of researchers from the University of Texas at Austin and the University of California, Riverside, have developed a new type of battery that can be recycled and reused. The researchers call their new battery a "resilient battery." Developed by Richard Liu, a professor at the University of Texas at Austin's School of Materials Science and Engineering, and Joseph Chon, a professor at the University of California, Riverside's Department of Mechanical Engineering, the resilient battery uses metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as a new electrolyte. MOFs are a class of materials that are being developed for a wide variety of applications, including gas sensors, lithium-ion batteries, and supercapacitors. The new electrolyte, however, has a number of advantages. For one, it's very light. That means that the battery can be easily recharged and reused. Another advantage is that the MOF electrolyte can be easily removed from the battery, and it can be reused in other applications. The researchers tested the battery by using it to power a smart phone and a wearable device. While these devices could be powered by lithium-ion batteries, the researchers found that the new battery had comparable performance. "This is an exciting time in battery technology," says Professor Liu.

When you're waiting in an airport line (or a doctor's office or the library), is there anything you'd like to do? We all love free time - it lets us recover from stressful situations or allow our minds to wander. But if we're already stressed out by waiting in lines and having difficult conversations while trying not to show it on our faces, it's hard to feel rested when those opportunities come up again afterward! So what can be done about it? The answer might surprise you: You could use stopping dead at a busy intersection as an opportunity for relaxation! In fact, many studies have shown that walking through traffic may even reduce blood pressure and lower heart rate. But "stopping" doesn't mean just standing still without moving around: It also means facing people head-on rather than angling away from them into sidewalks or busy streets. (This was the case at my little town fair last weekend.) In one study published in the Journal of Social Psychology, researchers asked participants who were about eight years old to pretend they were blackjack dealers or waitresses - and found that their reactions to angry patrons differed: Children who faced straight ahead had less blood pressure rise and faster reaction times compared to children whose eyes darted toward either sidewalk, according to research conducted in San Francisco General Hospital's Center for Brain Health Initiative. And another recent report suggests that simply sitting down long enough every day might help increase cognition and social skills among adults, possibly because of improved circulation to areas such as the frontal lobe, where decision making takes place.

"The veggie burgers are in a really good place right now," said Emily Bushaw, Culinary Director at America's Test Kitchen. "I think the growth of the meatless burgers has been really interesting. It's gone from just your sort of fake meat patties to a whole new world of veggie burgers and beyond meat burgers." Bushaw said the testers used a 10-point rating system for each burger. They took into account factors such as the "char factor," or how well the burger seared, and texture. "We looked at the overall flavor profile of the burger," Bushaw said. "We were really surprised by what we found. There was a mix of vegan and vegetarian burgers." The testers found that one brand of vegan burger was the best tasting. "The one that really won it for us was the Follow Your Heart [vegan] burger," Bushaw said. "We thought it had a really good flavor profile, which is surprising because vegan burgers can be a little bit bland." The second place winner was a vegetarian option from MorningStar Farms. "They are both good options for people who are looking for a meatless burger," Bushaw said. Beyond Meat's 'Beyond Burger' came in fourth place, while the Impossible Burger 2.0 came in 10th. "We thought both of these burgers were good," Bushaw said. "Both of these are made to be meat replacements. They are not trying to be vegetable-based burgers." Bushaw said she was most surprised by the high ranking of the vegan burgers. "I think it was a pleasant surprise for us," Bushaw said. "Both of those burgers were on the more affordable side, which is always nice. They were a really good surprise, and we will be using them a lot more in our test kitchen." Bushaw said the testers looked at how well the burgers could be cooked at home. "We did them at home," Bushaw said. "We did not grill them, we cooked them on a cast iron pan on the stove, and that's how we judge them because that's how most people at home will be cooking them." Bushaw said the vegetable-based burgers did not perform as well in the test. "They were a little bit on the blander side, but I think that is because they are trying to be vegetable-based burgers," Bushaw said. "They are trying to replace vegetables on a burger, not be a meat replacement." Bushaw said the testers also looked at the black bean burgers. "They are the most common," Bushaw said. "They are a really good meat replacement for people who are looking for something to throw on a barbecue." Bushaw said the testers also looked at the nutritional value of the burgers. "We looked at the protein content of each burger," Bushaw said. "We looked at how much protein each burger contained, how much sodium, and how much fat it contained." Bushaw said the testers also looked at how much of each ingredient was used in each burger. "We looked at how much vegetable or vegetable protein was in each burger," Bushaw said. "We wanted to know how much of the patty was actually vegetables and how much was other stuff." Bushaw said the testers discovered that Beyond Meat's burger uses mostly pea protein. "They are a huge percentage of what is in the patty," Bushaw said. Bushaw said the testers found that some of the vegan burgers contained a lot of coconut oil. "Coconut oil is not necessarily bad for you," Bushaw said. "It's just that if you are eating this patty thinking it is all vegetables, there is a lot of coconut oil in there. It's a good thing to keep in mind." Bushaw said the testers also looked at the sodium content of the burgers. "You would think the plant-based burgers would be lower in sodium," Bushaw said. The most common issue for new data scientists is that they don't question their own results. It is important to validate the results that are generated from machines as the results may be biased. For example, a machine learning algorithm might be trained on a dataset that is biased towards a particular group of people, which could lead to unfair or inaccurate results. Another common issue for new data scientists is that they don't have a good understanding of the business context. This can lead to them making decisions that are not aligned with the goals of the business. For example, a data scientist might build a model that predicts customer churn, but the model might not be useful if the business does not have a plan to reduce churn. It is important for data scientists to be aware of these common issues and to take steps to mitigate them. By doing so, they can help to ensure that the data they are working with is accurate and unbiased, and that the decisions they are making are aligned with the goals of the business.

A team of engineers in Korea has designed a new Virtual Reality glove that can create the sensation of touch when manipulating digital objects. VR gloves are not new, but this is the first time an illusion of physical tactile feedback for virtual hands has been achieved. The gloves use both motion tracking and haptic stimulation to simulate the responsive feeling associated with real-life interaction. The technology uses RFID tags embedded within each finger tip along with LED lights positioned on top of fingers to track movements. It also deploys sensors around the hand which detects touches across multiple points simultaneously. The gantry-like glove connects to your smartphone via Bluetooth and allows you to move them as if they were part of your own body. A small array of electrodes at each fingertip records vibrations from each movement you make, so it creates sensations like pressure or slap. As well as allowing users to interact naturally with things virtually, these gloves could be used by therapists to help rehabilitate those who have suffered brain injuries or strokes. While its early prototype doesn't quite replicate all aspects of human experience (such as fine motor control), we cannot deny it's impressive nonetheless - especially given what's involved.

A team of engineers in Korea has designed a new Virtual Reality glove that can create the sensation of touch when manipulating digital objects. VR gloves are not new, but existing systems require a mechanical apparatus that provides tactile feedback to the hand, limiting their portability. The new system, created by Yong Tae Kim and a team of engineers at Korea's Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, uses a novel haptic technology called Lagrangian Dynamics. A user wears a conventional VR glove with sensors that track the motion of the hands. Each of the fingers is attached to a small motor. When the user's hand "touches" a virtual object, the corresponding motor causes the finger to bend, thus simulating the feeling of touch. The software relies on Lagrangian Dynamics, a system that was originally developed to simulate physics in computer animation. It calculates the exact amount of resistance that the user should feel when manipulating a given virtual object. The researchers tested their system using a 3D model of a cube. They found that users could reliably distinguish between surfaces that were hard and soft, rough and smooth, with up to 95.5 accuracy. To test the system's effect on user performance, they had users use a VR environment to move objects from one place to another. They found that users of the new system performed these tasks about 20 faster than users of a conventional VR system. The system is still in the prototype stage, but Yong Tae Kim and his colleagues have submitted a patent for their technology. They hope to use it to create a wearable tactile feedback system that can be used with conventional VR gloves.

Scientists have been prohibited from keeping human embryos alive in their labs for more than 14 days for the last few decades to avoid ethical issues that might be raised by a baby born with a brain disorder. The ban was imposed when thousands of people went onto an online petition demanding exemption, saying they had no other option but to destroy their child's embryo if it turned out to be abnormal. The European Parliament recently gave its backing for extending the moratorium on researching and storing live human embryos beyond three weeks until at least February 6 next year. This means that researchers will not only continue studying them in vitro (in laboratories) as well as cryopreserving them for future use but also keep some of these frozen embryos alive longer than previously allowed under EU law. "This is another step towards allowing scientists to study human embryonic stem cells while protecting human life" said Dr. Anna Hallstrom, President of Life Sciences Association who has campaigned tirelessly against the ban. "Air crash victims' families are entitled to know what happened before the body can even be examined. Human embryonic stem cells shouldn't just go uninvestigated because there may be risk factors involved like certain genetic disorders or birth defects which could lead to serious illness later down the line. It makes sense to allow scientific experimentation without endangering innocent lives. We call upon our MEPs to support this proposal so we can bring about real change once again, soon!" A number of industry bodies such as the Biotechnology Industry Organization (BIO), representing some 2,500 biotech companies worldwide; BioEurope Foundation based in Brussels-the foremost - pan-European organisation working on advancing bioeconomy development across Europe - expressed concern over an extension of the current de facto moratorium prior to the two-year deadline set by the European Commission, pointing to possible negative consequences for science and innovation. "BioEurope strongly supports a discontinuation of the existing moratorium via the adoption of legislation requiring a very strict application procedure and oversight system covering all aspects including ethics clearance procedures and safety monitoring for innovative applications involving human pluripotent stem cell lines" said Mario Borghezio, president of BIO and former Italian Prime Minister. Aside from the fact that new knowledge gained through experimentation using human embryos would benefit many patients suffering from diseases caused by mutations, shared embryonic developmental pathways between humans and animals represent important opportunities for testing compounds or creating animal models of human disease. Scientists have been prohibited from keeping human embryos alive in their labs for more than 14 days for the last few decades to avoid ethical issues that might be raised if they were allowed to develop further. However, in December 2016, the United Kingdom became the first country to lift this restriction, allowing scientists to study human embryos for up to 28 days. The decision was met with mixed reactions, with some people arguing that it was a necessary step to advance medical research, while others expressed concerns about the ethical implications. One of the main arguments in favor of lifting the 14-day rule is that it would allow scientists to study human embryos in greater detail and to develop new treatments for diseases such as infertility and miscarriage. For example, researchers could study how embryos develop and how they respond to different treatments, which could help them to develop new ways to help people who are struggling to conceive. Additionally, studying human embryos could help scientists to better understand how diseases such as cancer develop, which could lead to new treatments. However, there are also some ethical concerns that have been raised about lifting the 14-day rule. Some people argue that it is wrong to allow embryos to be kept alive for longer than necessary, as this could lead to the development of embryos for research purposes that would never be implanted into a woman's uterus. Others argue that it is wrong to experiment on human embryos, as they are considered to be potential human beings. The debate over whether or not to lift the 14-day rule is likely to continue for some time, as there are strong arguments on both sides of the issue. However, the decision to lift the rule in the UK has opened the door to new possibilities for medical research, and it will be interesting to see how the research that is conducted in the coming years will affect the ethical debate.

The Perturb-seq map is the first comprehensive functional map of genes that are expressed in human cells. The data is available for any scientist to use. It allows scientists to ask a broad range of questions about which genes are turned on in different types of cells, tissues, and organs. The map is based on sequencing of the RNA found in each of 245 different types of cells and tissues, and is generated using a method called Perturb-seq. It provides a reference point for researchers to ask questions such as "What pathways are turned on in this cancer?" or "What genes do these neurons express?." The Perturb-seq map also allows scientists to see whether certain gene-editing methods are effective. For example, CRISPR-Cas9 is a method to edit genomes that has been a major breakthrough in recent years. However, some researchers have suggested that it could be ineffective in some cases, due to the presence of so-called 'off-target' effects that might disrupt other genes. By comparing the data produced by Perturb-seq to the changes in the genome made by the CRISPR-Cas9 method, the team could check whether off-target effects really do occur. Another use of the map is to examine how genes are turned on and off during the process of cell division. The map shows which genes are expressed in each of the different phases of the cell cycle, and how they change as cells divide. "The Perturb-seq map is a powerful resource for researchers around the world, and should help us to understand how our genes are regulated, and how mutations can lead to disease," says Dr Nicholas Luscombe, Group Leader at the Francis Crick Institute and joint corresponding author of the paper.

In addition to its primary purpose of uncovering biological processes regulated by genetic variations within cancer patients, the Pertubseq MAP can be used to further study other forms of variation including epigenetic alterations such as DNA methylation patterns [Iyer et al., 2007], protein post-translational modifications [Kang et al., 2008 ] and somatic mutations [Timmers et al., 2006]. While it may seem intuitive that mapping RNA interference knock-downs onto pathways could provide insight into the relationship between certain phenotypes and specific gene products, this was not realized until recently when several efforts focused on identifying which pathways were most significantly affected after knockdown of mRNA sequences [Xue et al., 2008; Zeng et al., 2010; Zheng et al., 2010b]. These studies addressed technical issues related to targeting short interfering RNAs (siRNAs), but did little more than rank pathway hits according to their statistical significance without attempting to link them to common mechanisms leading to the observed cellular effects. Here we describe the implementation of a systems-level analysis pipeline called 'Pathway Analysis Tool' (PAT). PAT uses Bayesian network models to integrate multiple sources of information about biology with mathematical programming techniques for making predictions regarding potential downstream consequences of perturbed signaling networks. We demonstrate how integration of this type of global predictive modeling approach leads to more accurate hypotheses and new testable ideas. The resultant functional relationships between components of a given system represent novel hypotheses generated by integrating multiple independent sources of knowledge. Furthermore they characterize molecular interactions defined by prior literature consistent with experimentally determined causal relations and therefore serve as biologically meaningful hypotheses amenable to validation via follow-up experimentation. Results Integrating perturbation evidence Our Pathway Analysis Tool integrates three major classes of information: 1) published genomic profiles associated with adverse side-effects; 2) disease-associated SNP genotypic data; 3) known transcriptional regulation events identified through genome-wide association studies (GWAS). IBM is acquiring Red Hat for 34 billion. Red Hat is an open source, enterprise software company best known distributing and supporting their enterprise version of Linux. IBM will pay cash to buy all Red Hat shares at 190 per share. Red Hat shares closed at 116.68 on Friday so this is a huge premium. Red Hat will become part of IBM's Hybrid Cloud division.

IBM is acquiring Red Hat for 34 billion. Red Hat is an open source, enterprise software company best known distributing and supporting their enterprise version of Linux. IBM will pay 72 per share in cash. Red Hat's Linux distribution is the most widely used in the enterprise. This will allow IBM to increase its presence in the enterprise software market. This is also an opportunity for IBM to make it easier for their developers to work with Red Hat's software. They'll have a large number of developers working on open source projects. IBM is also acquiring SoftLayer Technologies, an enterprise hosting company that focuses on Linux and virtualization. It will be run independently of the rest of IBM's IT business. SoftLayer will provide the hardware infrastructure for the new Red Hat enterprise Linux distribution. IBM will also acquire Nomad, a cloud management software company that focuses on the private cloud market. Nomad will be run independently of the rest of IBM's IT business. It will also provide the software infrastructure for the new Red Hat enterprise Linux distribution. The acquisition of Red Hat is part of IBM's effort to become a major player in the cloud computing market. The acquisition of Nomad is a move to compete in the growing private cloud market.

IBM is acquiring Red Hat for 34 billion. Red Hat is an open source, enterprise software company best known distributing and supporting their enterprise version of Linux. IBM will pay a premium price of approximately 190 per share in cash for Red Hat. Red Hat's expertise in open source technology and Kubernetes will also help IBM in their efforts to develop artificial intelligence and other emerging technologies.

IBM is acquiring Red Hat for 34 billion. Red Hat is an open source, enterprise software company best known distributing and supporting their enterprise version of Linux. IBM will pay 190 per share in cash for Red Hat. According to IBM the acquisition is projected to contribute 2 points of compound annual revenue growth to IBM over a 5-year period. IBM will remain committed to Red Hat's open governance, open source contributions, participation in the open source community and development model, and fostering its widespread developer ecosystem. In addition, IBM and Red Hat will remain committed to the continued freedom of open source, via such efforts as Patent Promise, GPL Cooperation Commitment, the Open Invention Network and the LOT Network. A statement from IBM says, "Red Hat is a leader in enterprise Kubernetes and cloud-native applications, and has a robust developer toolset and DevOps offering to speed adoption of emerging technologies. IBM intends to remain committed to Red Hat's open governance, open source contributions, participation in the open source community and development model, and fostering its widespread developer ecosystem. In addition, IBM and Red Hat will remain committed to the continued freedom of open source, via such efforts as Patent Promise, GPL Cooperation Commitment, the Open Invention Network and the LOT Network." "The acquisition of Red Hat is a game-changer. It changes everything about the cloud market," said Ginni Rometty, IBM chairman, president and CEO. "IBM will become the world's 1 hybrid cloud provider, offering companies the only open cloud solution that will unlock the full value of the cloud for their businesses. "Most companies today are only 20 percent along their cloud journey, renting compute power to cut costs," she said. "The next 80 percent is about unlocking real business value and driving growth. This is the next chapter of the cloud. It requires shifting business applications to hybrid cloud, extracting more data and optimizing every part of the business, from supply chains to sales." "Open source is the default choice for modern IT solutions, and I'm incredibly proud of the role Red Hat has played in making that a reality in the enterprise," said Jim Whitehurst, president and CEO, Red Hat. "Joining forces with IBM will provide us with a greater level of scale, resources and capabilities to accelerate the impact of open source as the basis for digital transformation and bring Red Hat to an even wider audience - all while preserving our unique culture and unwavering commitment to open source innovation." There are already a number of companies that have made their way into the data center that have open source at their core and IBM has already worked with a number of these including Docker and Mesosphere. Urban Air Port will build its first Air-One transport hub for autonomous delivery drones and electric flying cars in Coventry, UK. The facility will launch later this year and support the creation of up to 2,500 jobs. The new centre at the former Kingfisher factory is designed so that it can accommodate a range of deliveries including commercials, parcels, freight, services or passenger trips by drone and vehicle - an area known as Multi-Mode Aviation (MMA). "We are investing 9 million into our world-class MMA development program over five years with plans to offer full-scale testing facilities for EV vehicles such as autonomous driving kits and self-driving testbeds," said Alex Dolan, Chief Commercial Officer, VanMoof. Using drone technology and sensors, the new airport promises to make deliveries more efficient. It will also help develop infrastructure which enables drone use in rural areas where roads cannot be accessed easily. Currently being built next door to General Motors' future plant in Maidenhead, the airport's base has been strategically located close to major road links. "The site offers both connectivity from existing routes outwards along the A319 route towards Cambridge Airport, London City through Canary Wharf via M3 M1 and access onto Motorway Network Route 10 between Doncaster and Sheffield via junction 14 of A42AH71M6 explained Dave Spratt, Managing Director with lumiAir Group who made the announcement. With flexible working arrangements already available on-site, companies have started to see huge returns on investment within short space of time. This includes Amazon, DHL Express and Wingless Solutions amongst others. With benefits including reduced logistics costs, improved business agility and boosted brand awareness, the location makes sense given what other industries are forecast to experience.

Urban Air Port will build its first Air-One transport hub for autonomous delivery drones and electric flying cars in Coventry, UK. The facility will launch later this year and support delivery drone and air taxi technology, and it will eventually transport cargo and people across cities. Urban Air Port aims to install over 200 similar sites worldwide by 2025.

Urban Air Port will build its first Air-One transport hub for autonomous delivery drones and electric flying cars in Coventry, UK. The facility will launch later this year and support the growth of urban air mobility by enabling safe and efficient operations of autonomous drones and eVTOLs (electric vertical take-off and landing vehicles). The Air-One hub will provide a landing and take-off space for a range of unmanned aerial vehicles, with the potential to transport medical supplies, groceries, and various other items. The Coventry location was chosen for its central location in the UK and its proximity to major road networks. The project is part of a larger initiative to create a network of urban air transport hubs around the UK and eventually globally.

Urban Air Port will build its first Air-One transport hub for autonomous delivery drones and electric flying cars in Coventry, UK. The facility will launch later this year and support a new generation of sustainable mobility solutions. Air-One is a dedicated mobility hub that will manage fleets of delivery drones and electric flying cars. The hub will be managed by Urban Air Port, a company focused on the integration of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) into urban environments. Urban Air Port has already received letters of support from the City of Coventry, the Transport Systems Catapult, and the University of Warwick. Urban Air Port will begin by operating a fleet of unmanned delivery drones, flying up to 30 miles at a time, with a capacity of 10 pounds. The drones will carry items like groceries and online orders, and will be routed to Air-One hubs for refueling and reloading. The hubs will also serve as a base for Urban Air Port's electrical air vehicles. The company has already signed agreements with the engineering group Vertical Aerospace, and has also received significant support from Volocopter. "The biggest opportunity in the market is the electrical vertical take-off and landing (eVTOL) aircraft that will start to become available in 2020. They will be able to carry one to four passengers, with ranges of 20 to 100 miles, and will eventually be affordable to the mass market. The eVTOLs will be the foundation for the Urban Air Mobility (UAM) industry, in the same way that the Ford Model T was the foundation for the automotive industry," said Jonathan Tremain, Founder and CEO of Urban Air Port. Earlier this month, Urban Air Port announced the construction of its first Air-One transport hub in Pawling, New York. The Pawling hub will enable UAV delivery in the New York area, and will later support eVTOL flights when they become available.

Apple has released iOS 12, which features significant performance improvements over iOS 11 (it is 40 faster for launching apps and up to 70 faster for launching the camera). It has a new Screen Time feature, which tells you exactly how much time you spend on your phone or tablet, and which apps you're spending it on. Unlike iOS 11, it groups notifications together by app instead of sending floods of notifications from any one app. The iBooks, Apple News, Stocks, and Voice Memos apps have all been redesigned, and the Messages app now has Memojis (custom animated Animoji avatars). Maybe the most exciting part is ARKit 2, which will allow developers to build AR experiences that are shared by multiple users.

It also includes a new app called Screen Time, which gives you visibility into your and your children's iPhone, iPad and iPod touch usage, including the amount of time spent on specific apps and websites. The apps have a category called "Productivity" that is meant to include apps such as email, messaging and calendar apps. But the category also includes Clio's iPhone app. This means that the amount of time you spend using Clio on your iPhone or iPad will be included in the Screen Time statistics, which could result in some confusion. A study at Columbia University Irving Medical Center has found that Far-UVC light can safely kill 99.9 of seasonal coronaviruses present in airborne droplets. Conventional UV lamps can kill viruses on surfaces, but this is the first time scientists have been able to use this type of light to kill a virus in the air. Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that are known to cause respiratory illnesses in humans, ranging from the common cold to Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS). The study, published in Scientific Reports, shows that the Far-UVC light can be used to kill airborne SARS and MERS coronaviruses. "This study shows that Far-UVC light has a major advantage over [the] conventional germicidal UV light in that Far-UVC kills viruses in the air, and also on surfaces," says David J. Brenner, PhD, lead author of the study and a professor of radiation biophysics at Columbia University Vagelos College of Physicians and Surgeons. Far-UVC light, which has wavelengths between 207 and 222 nanometers, has been used for disinfecting water, food and surfaces. However, because it has high-energy components, it can't be used in the presence of people. The study shows that Far-UVC light could be used in public spaces, such as airports, public transportation, doctors' offices and schools. "Far-UVC light has a very limited range and cannot penetrate through the outer dead-cell layer of human skin or the tear layer in the eye, so it's not a human health hazard," says Brenner. "That means it's not only safe; it's not something that we have to worry about as far as it affecting us." While UVC light is currently used to disinfect surgical tools and surfaces, it can't be used to disinfect the air because of the hazards to the eyes and skin. The study, which was conducted in a lab, tested Far-UVC lights' ability to kill aerosolized coronaviruses. The coronavirus was released into a test chamber, and then the Far-UVC light was turned on for varying lengths of time. To determine how effective the Far-UVC light was, the scientists measured the viral load in the chamber. The results showed that the Far-UVC light was able to greatly reduce the level of viral particles in the air. Further experiments showed that Far-UVC light could kill coronaviruses in the air, whether the air was circulating or still. "This study shows that two hours of Far-UVC light can kill 95 percent of the virus in the air, and 45 minutes of Far-UVC light can kill 90 percent of the virus," says Brenner. He notes that, even though the Far-UVC light can't penetrate through human skin, it can penetrate clothes, which means it could be used to kill viruses in closed spaces. "For public health workers that are in the midst of an outbreak, this could help decontaminate an entire space," says Brenner. He adds that the light can be mounted on the ceiling, walls or floor. "The light could be mounted in the ceiling or on the walls or floor. We can take our germicidal technology and make it into a thin coating that could be sprayed or rolled on almost any surface. "You could use this technology in a subway station or an airport or any enclosed area."

Synthetic wavelength holography is a new non-line-of-sight method that can rapidly capture full-field images of large areas with submillimeter precision. The method has endless potential applications, including noninvasive medical imaging, early-warning navigation systems, space exploration, underwater acoustic imaging, and more. It works by indirectly scattering coherent light onto hidden objects, which scatters again and travels back to a camera. An algorithm is used to reconstruct the signal and reveal hidden objects. It may still be over a decade before the technology will appear in everyday use.

Synthetic wavelength holography is a new non-line-of-sight method that can rapidly capture full-field images of large areas with submillimeter precision. The method has endless potential applications, including noninvasive medical imaging, industrial inspection, and autonomous vehicle navigation. It works by combining multiple coherent light sources with different wavelengths, creating a synthetic wavelength that is longer than the individual wavelengths. By measuring the interference patterns of the synthetic wavelength, a holographic image can be reconstructed. This method is not limited by the line-of-sight, as the interference patterns can penetrate through obstacles such as walls and obstacles, making it a powerful tool for imaging in inaccessible areas. Additionally, the submillimeter precision enables the detection of small deformations and surface variations not visible to the naked eye, making it a valuable tool in fields like material science and engineering.

A theoretical model was reported recently by Chen et al [83] to explain previous experimental results on spatial frequency selectivity in static and dynamic amplitude-only 2D synthetic wavelength hologram generation. In this paper we extend their approach to understand the effects of the temporal variation in amplitude modulation intensity (AMID). When AMID changes over time during pulse shaping process, the desired fringe spacing between two adjacent zero-order spots will also change accordingly because of the Fourier transform nature of wavelet transformation process. Hence an additional factor called "temporal extent" has just begun to be considered when dealing with the mathematical expression of single-shot synthetic wavelength holograms. Then we conduct numerical simulations to demonstrate theoretically why such a phenomenon exists so consistently and quantitatively. Finally we present conclusions about the importance of considering both the spatial location and temporal evolution of the object under investigation and what could motivate future work along these lines. Synthetic wavelength holography is a new non-line-of-sight method that can rapidly capture full-field images of large areas with submillimeter precision. The method has endless potential applications, including noninvasive medical imaging, smart home technology, and self-driving vehicles. In this paper, we present a novel optical method to capture full-field images with 32-cm-diameter field of view and 0.5-mm precision using a single 22-m2 sensor array. The method is realized through the use of diffractive optics to transform an unconventional wavelength-swept light source into a set of parallel structured light beams with a spectrum-dependent 3D wavefront. Our method is able to capture full-field images with unprecedented precision over large areas, while maintaining low system complexity.

Synthetic wavelength holography is a new non-line-of-sight method that can rapidly capture full-field images of large areas with submillimeter precision. The method has endless potential applications, including noninvasive medical imaging, security, and industrial inspection. Synthetic wavelength holography works by modulating the wavelength of a light beam and then using an interferometer to record the interference pattern between the modulated beam and a reference beam. The interference pattern is then processed to reconstruct a full-field image of the object. This method has several advantages over traditional holographic imaging methods. First, it does not require the object to be in the direct line of sight of the imaging system. This makes it possible to image objects that are behind obstacles or that are moving. Second, the method is very fast, allowing images to be captured in a matter of milliseconds. Third, the method is highly sensitive, allowing it to detect small changes in the object's shape or position. Synthetic wavelength holography is still a relatively new technology, but it has already shown great promise in a variety of applications. In one study, researchers used synthetic wavelength holography to image the interior of a human heart. The images were of such high quality that they allowed the researchers to see the heart valves and chambers in detail. In another study, researchers used synthetic wavelength holography to image a security checkpoint. The images were able to detect hidden objects, such as weapons and drugs, that were not visible to the naked eye. Synthetic wavelength holography is a promising new technology with a wide range of potential applications. It is likely to play an important role in noninvasive medical imaging, security, and industrial inspection in the years to come.

Everyone is talking about Kubernetes! Apps running in these workloads probably have the concept of users. And where you have users, you have auth. We'll cover topics like service-to-service communication, authentication and authorization in Kubernetes, commonly known as Kubernetes auth. In Kubernetes, service-to-service communication happens quite frequently. When a microservice calls another microservice, it's important that the calling microservice is authorized to access the other microservice's resources. This is where Kubernetes auth comes into play. Kubernetes auth is implemented using the Kubernetes API server, which is the main control plane of the system. There are several ways to authenticate in Kubernetes, including: - Certificates: Service accounts can be used to grant access to Kubernetes resources using X.509 certificates. Kubernetes uses client certificates to authenticate service accounts. - Tokens: Tokens can be used to authenticate users or service accounts. Tokens are generally self-contained and can encode information such as user ID, group memberships, and expiration time. - OpenID Connect (OIDC): This is an open standard that defines how authentication information is exchanged. Kubernetes can be configured to use OIDC for authentication. Once a user or service account is authenticated, Kubernetes uses authorization policies to determine which resources the user or service account has access to. Kubernetes authorization can be controlled using several mechanisms: - Role-based access control (RBAC): RBAC defines roles and their permissions. You can create and assign roles to users or groups of users. - Attribute-based access control (ABAC): ABAC defines policies based on attributes like user, group, and IP address. - Node authorization: Kubernetes can be configured to authorize nodes based on properties like node name or labels. In summary, Kubernetes auth is a critical part of securing your Kubernetes cluster. By using Kubernetes auth, you can ensure that only authorized users and services can access your resources.

"The next wave of payment innovation is here just around the corner, and it's going to change everything about what you pay for online," he added.

The company said it has taken steps to help protect users' payment data, including encrypting card numbers and using anti-fraud monitoring systems. "We designed Facebook Pay to securely store and encrypt your card and bank account numbers, perform anti-fraud monitoring on our systems to detect unauthorized activity and provide notifications for account activity," Deborah Liu, Facebook's vice president of marketplace and commerce, said in a blog post. "You can also add a PIN or use your device biometrics, such as touch or face ID recognition, for an extra layer of security when sending money or making a payment." Facebook also said it will share your financial data with its affiliates and service providers to process payments, to detect fraud, and to help provide customer support. Many companies have only one product line, for example, a print or photo lab, or a data center. Organizations with multiple products often have one platform to track and organize customer data, but the platforms are not connected, resulting in fragmented data. The challenge: When customers switch products or services, the data that should link the customer to the different products is lost. The result: Marketing spends more time re-creating customer profiles, and marketing data is fragmented and difficult to access. The solution: Marketing must work closely with IT to ensure that the customer data that flows from IT to marketing is connected, complete, and accurate. The right marketing technology and integration between the platform and marketing software can help organizations address the challenge. Here are some suggestions for a customer data platform: 1. Establish a standard. IT and marketing should collaborate on the structure of the data to make it easier for marketing to access and use. The first step is to create a standard that allows marketing to access all customer data from a common place. It's not a question of creating a single platform; rather, it's a question of establishing a standard that allows marketing to access data from multiple sources. 2. Connect the data. Marketing and IT must create a system that allows the customer data to be pulled from one platform into another. The platform should allow for easy updates to the data, including adding and deleting data, as well as providing a view of the data. 3. Share the data. Marketing and IT should collaborate to ensure that the customer data is available to marketing from multiple platforms. The goal is to allow marketing to access the data across multiple platforms without the data having to be copied. 4. Integrate the data. IT and marketing should collaborate to create a platform that allows the data to be pulled from multiple sources and integrated into one platform. 5. Create a single view of the customer. Marketing and IT should collaborate to create a system that allows marketing to access the customer data from multiple sources. The goal is to allow marketing to access the data across multiple platforms without the data having to be copied. 6. Optimize the data. Marketing and IT should collaborate to ensure that the customer data is available to marketing from multiple platforms. The goal is to allow marketing to access the data across multiple platforms without the data having to be copied. The data should be optimized to provide a view of the customer. The challenge of a undifferentiated product is a good problem to have. Scientists can manipulate dreams using an app combined with a sleep-tracking device called Dormio. In a recent study, the researchers inserted certain topics into a person's dreams using the technique. The dream manipulation method works by detecting the sleep patterns of a person using the Dormio. The sleep-tracking device sends a smartphone app a signal when the person is in the rapid-eye movement (REM) stage of sleep. When the Dormio detects that a person is dreaming, the app plays sounds that match the content of the dream. For example, if a person is dreaming about running on a beach, the app plays the sound of the waves. The app only plays the sounds when the person is in the REM stage of sleep. The Dormio is able to differentiate between sleep stages by using a technique called actigraphy. Actigraphy can detect the changes in the movements of a person as they sleep. It can detect when a person is tossing and turning, or if they are in a deep sleep. The REM stage is when dreaming occurs, but it only lasts 20 minutes or so. This is why the sounds need to be played at the right time. The researchers tested their technique in a lab by playing the sounds from a smartphone app. They also tested it by playing the sounds from a bedside lamp. The dream manipulation method was able to influence the dreams of 96 percent of the participants. In the study, the researchers divided the participants into two groups. One group had the app play sounds related to the content of the dream. The other group had the app play sounds unrelated to the dream. For example, if the person was dreaming about a dog, the researchers had the app play a dog barking sound. If the person was dreaming about a car crash, the app played the sound of a car crash. After the participants woke up, the researchers asked them to write down the content of their dreams. The study found that the dream manipulation technique had more success in influencing the dreams of the group that had the app play sounds related to the content of the dream. The researchers then asked the participants to explain how the sounds they heard during their dreams had affected their dreams. The researchers found that the dream manipulation technique had a better chance of affecting the dreams of people who were familiar with the sounds they heard while they were dreaming. The study was published in the journal Neuron on Dec. 14.

Microdiff is a zero-dependency object and array comparison library. It is fast, extremely lightweight, and easy to use. Microdiff features support for Deno, Node, the web, service workers, TypeScript, and JavaScript. Its simple API makes it easy to compare objects and arrays in a variety of scenarios, and it includes a number of useful options such as array order sensitivity and custom comparison functions. Overall, Microdiff is a great option for anyone looking for a small, high-performance comparison library for their JavaScript or TypeScript project.

Before writing about angels today it will be best if we discuss what exactly are they? Angels have long been seen as messengers charged with guiding people through life's challenges or helping them solve problems that seem impossible to fix. They also provide spiritual guidance throughout our lives and can even allow us to connect with God himself! There are multiple religions that believe in angelic beings but most Christians see angels like Gods sent down into the world to spread love around the planet. There are certain Scriptures where Jesus talks quite openly about angels - he says "you shall not kill" (John 10:10); tells us to pray to "the father" instead of simply him in John 14:13-14; tells us to ask "Hail Mary full of grace..." when we feel worried in Luke 1:38-39 etc. But there is no mention of any specific kind of animal shape entity asking such things of humans! Or the ones supposedly called "angels of death" knocking on doors demanding our physical presence? It has been said that the main reason why too many believers don't believe in an actual needy heavenly government is because of unfounded stories told thousands and hundreds of years ago by clerics who were influenced by medieval beliefs about demons and demonic possession. These stories included supernatural creatures being forced away from their bodies during sleep and having horrific experiences in hell after dying which had terrified children until Christianity became widely accepted worldwide more than 2000 years later. Many still go so far as to say we're all possessed by demons every night due to the fearful legend surrounding these entities but Michael Joyner doesn't buy this stuff. He explains that while it's true angels do visit Terrans (humans), they only come once per lifetime unless one asks them directly to visit again. What happens next depends entirely upon one's behaviour. If your actions reflect kindness towards others and faithfulness to yourself and other human knows you'll get another chance; if you're evil you fail miserably and can't return. Believing in angels helps assign meaning to our own lives without resorting to crazy interpretations of events like those mentioned above. The first time I came across this concept of 'prayer animals' was back in 1998 when I read Nicholas Carr's book "The Shallows: Why" (it mentions prayer animals too!). Involving myself in various communities online over the last ten plus years I've now become aware of several different groups dedicated solely to teaching how to request petitions from animals including cats, dogs, birds and fish! Some of the literature suggests using particular phrases or chants based around sacred geometry whilst others suggest direct communication between the petitioners and the requested pets via some type of methodical strumming of metallic objects attached to the limbs of the requesting person. While I'm sure prayer animals exist there really seems little evidence just yet either way. It's hard enough convincing ourselves that invisible forces like gods could help us do something; but imagine explaining that miracles happen nearly daily thanks to our personal prayers directed at celestial beings whom aren't materialistic individuals living off of taxes paid by real humans? Who would take me seriously anymore? Hopefully soon future research can catch up to current scientific understanding and prove whether the existence of mysterious humankind-altering beings is worthy of our total belief system or merely superstition. So if you're looking to update your status, show your appreciation for friends, fans, family members, pets and all things awesome, look no further. While I'm partial to rainbow ponies and unicorns, there's nothing better than finding new emoticons that dress up your favorite brands and sites. It's really fun collecting images of a variety of background colors, shapes, hair styles and eye colors that match the design theme. You never run out of options nowadays - thank goodness! Once you've found the perfect photo stock for your profile picture, it's important to add a few words to let people know what's up with you. A simple text message can turn old connections into wonderful memories, express gratitude for loved ones nearby or introduce yourself to a new group of people. I've compiled 20 inspirational quotes below to give you a bit of inspiration. axum is a web application framework that takes full advantage of the tower and tower-http ecosystem of middleware, services, and utilities to get timeouts, tracing, compression, authorization, and more for free. It also integrates with an established suite of third-party services like dropbox, S3, Amazon ECS, etc. Why axum? Because: We've been using tower for a long time and it has matured into a great framework. The axum community has been growing rapidly and is very active. Axum offers a lot of additional services, such as HTTP timeouts, tracing, compression, and authorization. Axum is based on the same core technology as tower. The existing core code is more than 10 years old, and so it's already well tested. The tower community has been around for a long time, so there are lots of contributors and tools that can be used to get started quickly. Tower has a solid infrastructure for managing extensions, so there are a lot of components already available. There are a lot of services built on top of tower, such as a full API to Elasticsearch, a great Vault client, and a solid, secure vault extension. What is axum's licensing? All code in the project is MIT licensed. What is the source code structure? The main repository contains: axum: contains the main codebase. axum-contrib: contains all the third-party components, including elasticsearch, vault, and dropbox. axum-server: contains the axum server. axum-client: contains the axum client. axum-examples: contains the example client and server. axum-test: contains the unit tests. axum-library: contains the tests for the axum client. axum-services: contains the service providers. axum-services-core: contains the core services. axum-middleware: contains the middleware for the services. axum-integration: contains the integration tests for the services. axum-ext: contains the extension packages. axum-extensions: contains the extension packages. axum-contrib-cloud: contains the third-party cloud services. axum-client-cloud: contains the cloud client for the axum server. axum-server-cloud: contains the cloud client for the axum server. axum-integration-cloud: contains the integration tests for the cloud services. axum-integration-cloud-template: contains the integration tests for the cloud services. axum-integration-cloud-template-config: contains the cloud service configuration for the cloud services. axum-integration-cloud-template-node: contains the cloud service configuration for the cloud services. axum-integration-cloud-template-node-local: contains the cloud service configuration for the cloud services. axum-integration-cloud-template-node-local-integration: contains the integration tests for the cloud services. axum-integration-cloud-template-node-local-integration-node: contains the integration tests for the cloud services. axum-integration-cloud-template-node-local-integration-node-local: contains the integration tests for the cloud services. axum-integration-cloud-template-node-local-integration-node-local-integration: contains the integration tests for the cloud services. axum-integration-cloud-template-node-local-integration-node-local-integration-node: contains the integration tests for the cloud services. axum-integration-cloud-template-node-local-integration-node-local-integration-node-local: contains the integration tests for the cloud services. axum-integration-cloud-template-node-local-integration-node-local-integration-node-local-integration: contains the integration tests for the cloud services. axum-integration-cloud-template-node-local-integration-node-local-integration-node-local-integration-node: contains the integration tests for the cloud services. axum-integration-cloud-template-node-local-integration-node-local-integration-node-local-integration-node-local: contains the integration tests for the cloud services.

You could use Zope 2's Caching or Memcached implementation but depending on your setup you might find yourself reimplementing its functionality in MoinMoinaid if not already included elsewhere by default with an easy configuration change - especially considering how central caching can be relative even when used from scratch outside any frameworks such as these two mentioned here which were built using zcml etc..

axum is a web application framework that takes full advantage of the tower and tower-http ecosystem of middleware, services, and utilities to get timeouts, tracing, compression, authorization, and more for you. It uses NodeJS as its main runtime engine which makes it easy to integrate with other technologies such as Express or any Java-based server. The name "Tower" came from an analogy between how we think about applications in general (e.g., Facebook) versus websites (e.g., Twitter). Tower provides the same type of abstraction over your infrastructure like CoreOS does on bare metal hardware: Instead of having to worry about the CPU core allocation amongst all processes running concurrently or whether each process has enough memory to run effectively, you can simply focus on building meaningful functionality while knowing what will happen at scale. A: I have questions regarding performance in regards to latency improvements. Obviously I don't want my app load times to increase but I do wonder if there are certain things within app development itself I'm doing wrong. In particular, when using the nodejs http module specifically before sending requests, am I better off checking whether there's been data available since our last request? My understanding so far is this should be done once per connection instead. This would allow us to avoid starting TCP connections every time we make a new request without actually blocking until some kind of response comes back from the remote end. Is this assumption correct? Another way of looking at things is this. When working with socket programming languages like node, one thought often occurs is: "Okay, the clientremote side needs to spend some effort establishing a TCPIP connection for me to talk to them, then they need to transfer their data across the wire... now because I've already established a new thread that's been waiting around here for it to finish I'll probably get into trouble later on if someone else wants to call another function first?" Sounds reasonable right? Well, it's not really. The overhead associated with creating these threads places a significant costpain point on both sides that leads many people towards writing code like: Client Side Code var client ...; open socket and wait for state change events if (clientstate OPENSTATE) { var recvrdata; ... } ... etc... And on the receiving end we'll have: ... function receive { ... return data; This might block } ... I'd love to hear opinions based on industry best practices andor experiences? A: For those interested in kernel-mode networking TCP transport, here's Larry's contribution to StackOverflow discussing why you're better off handling responses yourself than relying solely upon OS-level operations. (He also includes a short discussion on TCP vs UDP.) That said, I wouldn't say goodbye to OS level features altogether - especially where network initialization termination heartbeats go - unless absolutely necessary.

Apple announced updates to iOS, iPadOS, MacOS, TV OS, and WatchOS in the opening keynote for WWDC2020. Public betas will start next month. iOS 14 will introduce new capabilities for widgets and the App Library, making it easier for users to organize and access their app collection. Siri is also getting a new compact interface and improved translation capabilities. Messages is getting richer conversations and the ability to pin conversations to the top. iPadOS 14 will introduce Scribble, which allows users to hand-write in any text field and automatically converts it to typed text. macOS Big Sur will include a redesigned user interface, new features in Safari, and improvements to Messages and Maps. WatchOS 7 will add new fitness tracking features, including dance tracking, sleep tracking, and hand-washing detection. Additionally, the new TV OS update will bring improved multi-user and gaming support. Overall, the updates are aimed at improving user experience and adding new functionalities to the Apple ecosystem.

Apple announced updates to iOS, iPadOS, MacOS, TV OS, and WatchOS in the opening keynote for WWDC2020. Public betas will start next month. iOS 14 will introduce new capabilities for iPad, a rebuilt Maps app, and a new HomePod. iPadOS will include multiple windows, a redesigned home screen, support for external drives, and Apple Pencil improvements. The Apple Watch, TV, and iPad are all about to get some very important updates. And no, it's not just a new watch face or a better remote. The company is really giving us the goods. SEE ALSO: Apple's iOS 13.3.1 update fixes iPhone 11 Pro's location tracking issues During its annual WWDC developer conference on Monday, the company announced updates to iOS 13, iPadOS, macOS Catalina, watchOS 6, and tvOS 13. Public betas will be available next month, and Apple says the software will be officially released this fall. Some of the updates are pretty standard. There's the usual round of app updates and changes to Apple services like Apple News, Apple Music, and Apple Podcasts. But there are also some notable additions that will change the way you use your devices. Apple's big announcements for its operating systems are below. Apple Watch: New faces, a dedicated App Store, and more The Apple Watch will receive two new faces: a modular face called "Gradient" that can display up to nine complications (i.e. information like your next calendar event) and a "X-Large" version of its "X-Large" analog face for showing more details at once. The Apple Watch will also get its own App Store, a new Voice Memos app, the ability to use the speaker and microphone for phone calls, and an Apple Books app. A new Noise app can also detect the decibel level of the room you're in and warn you if it's too loud. The Apple Watch will also track your menstrual cycle (and when you're fertile), and a new Trends tab in the Activity app will show you 90 days' worth of your activity and how you compare to the previous 90 days. Finally, Apple is also introducing a new version of its Apple Watch for the first time since 2016. The Apple Watch Series 5 has an always-on screen that doesn't dim and is still on when you lift your wrist to check the time. The Series 5 starts at 399. iPad: External drive support, mouse support, a Home screen redesign, and more iPad will get its own dedicated operating system with iPadOS. The iPad will now support external storage (including thumb drives), as well as mouse support. The iPad will also get a new Home screen with widgets, a redesigned Photos app, and new multitasking features for apps that support it (think using two apps at once). There's also a new "Dark Mode" to make your iPad easier to read at night. The Apple Pencil is also getting a new "Pencil Kit" for developers to support handwriting and drawing across iPadOS. iPhone: A redesigned Maps app, Memoji stickers, and a new Look Around feature iOS 13 will get a redesigned Maps app. Apple says the new app is faster and more accurate with better information about roads, beaches, parks, and buildings. It will also have more detailed ground cover, better pedestrian data, and more precise addresses. The new app will be available in the U.S. by the end of 2019 and in more countries in 2020. There's also a new "Look Around" feature that gives you a street-level view of a city, similar to Google's Street View. It uses the same 3D rendering technology as the Apple Maps "Flyover" feature. Apple's new Memoji stickers are exactly what you'd expect. They're customizable stickers based on your Memoji that you can send to friends in iMessage. Mac: A new Music app, Sidecar, and Screen Time The Mac is getting an updated Music app and a new Sidecar feature that lets you use an iPad as a secondary display for your Mac. Apple's also introducing a new "Find My" app that combines its Find My Friends and Find My iPhone features into a single app. Screen Time will finally be available on the

Apple announced updates to iOS, iPadOS, MacOS, TV OS, and WatchOS in the opening keynote for WWDC2020. Public betas will start next month. iOS 14 will introduce new capabilities for widgets, home screen, and Siri. Widgets can now be placed anywhere on the home screen, and can be customized to show different information depending on the time of day or your location. The new home screen layout allows you to place apps in folders and subfolders, and you can also pin apps to the top of the screen for quick access. Siri has been redesigned to be more conversational, and can now answer questions more naturally and provide more information. iPadOS 14 will bring new multitasking features to the iPad, including the ability to use multiple apps at the same time in Split View and Slide Over. You can also now drag and drop files between apps, and use the new Quick Notes feature to jot down notes without leaving the app you're currently using. MacOS 11 Big Sur is a major overhaul of the macOS operating system, with a new design that's more in line with iOS and iPadOS. The new design includes a new Dock, a new menu bar, and a new system font. Big Sur also includes a number of new features, such as a new Control Center, a new Messages app, and a new Safari browser. TV OS 14 will bring new features to the Apple TV, including the ability to use AirPlay 2 to mirror your iPhone or iPad screen to your TV, and the ability to use your iPhone as a remote control for your Apple TV. WatchOS 7 will bring new features to the Apple Watch, including new watch faces, new workout tracking features, and the ability to track your sleep.

Instacart, an app that allows users to have groceries and other household items delivered, has changed its tipping policy. The previous tipping policy included tip amounts in its minimum payouts, meaning that shoppers were guaranteed to receive a certain amount of money for each delivery, regardless of whether or not the customer tipped. However, the new policy does not include tip amounts in the minimum payouts, meaning that shoppers can now receive less than the minimum if the customer does not tip. This change has been met with criticism from some shoppers, who argue that it will make it more difficult for them to make a living.

Instacart, an app that allows users to have groceries and other household items delivered, has changed it's tipping policy. The previous tipping policy included tip amounts in it's minimum payouts, meaning drivers had to meet a minimum amount of tips in addition to their hourly wages. The new tipping policy eliminates this minimum. In addition, Instacart has increased the base pay for it's drivers by 0.05 per mile and 0.20 per order. The new policy went into effect on December 14, 2017. The base pay of 1.40 per mile is the highest in the industry, according to TechCrunch. Instacart's Chief Business Officer Nilam Ganenthiran told TechCrunch that the change was made in response to driver feedback, and that Instacart would continue to work with shoppers to find ways to improve their experience. Drivers will still receive a "quality bonus" based on performance. A driver with a 4.85 rating will receive a 50 cent bonus per order, while a driver with a 4.90 rating or higher will receive a 1 bonus per order. A driver's rating is affected by their responsiveness to orders, on-time delivery, and accuracy of orders. What do you think of Instacart's tipping policy? Let us know in the comments. The movie ticket subscription service that helped drive millions of customers to the theaters, but ultimately went bankrupt, has been acquired by cofounder Stacy Spikes, and will relaunch in early 2020. The new MoviePass, now called MoviePass Entertainment, has been acquired out of bankruptcy for an undisclosed amount below 250,000. Spikes said in a statement that MoviePasss future will be about more than just discounted movie tickets. MoviePass was a data-driven marketing company, but its first chapter was the theatrical exhibition business, Spikes said. This chapter of MoviePass is about entertainment and building community. We are about to take a wild ride here, Spikes wrote in the statement. This acquisition is just the beginning. Stacy Spikes, cofounder of MoviePass, believes MoviePass will come out on top. MoviePass Entertainment MoviePass Entertainment is focused on two main areas: movie ticket subscription and media. The media aspect will include an online media destination, a radio show, podcast, and video content. The movie ticket subscription service will launch in early 2020, with Spikes planning to start with a small group of subscribers in select cities. Spikes said in a statement that the price for the subscription service will be between 9.95 and 14.95 a month. MoviePass had a booming success when it launched in 2017. The service, which allowed members to see as many movies as they wanted in a month for a flat fee, attracted more than 3 million subscribers at its peak. But MoviePass couldnt make that business model work. Ultimately, MoviePass ran out of money to pay for movie tickets, and in August it announced that it was temporarily shutting down its service. Spikes has a theory for why the company went under. He believes that many of the companies that followed MoviePasss lead, like AMCs A-List and Sinemas Sinemia, will eventually go out of business, and MoviePass will emerge as the leader. Spikes said in a statement that MoviePass has a unique and experienced team, and a data-driven technology platform. We will have to be flawless in our execution, he said. I believe we will be. WeWork has closed down around 2,300 phone booths at some of its sites in the US and Canada after it discovered elevated levels of formaldehyde. The discovery was made after one of its members complained of an unpleasant odor in one of the booths. Formaldehyde is a colorless, flammable gas at room temperature and has a pungent, distinctive odor. It is used to make fertilizer, plastics, and dyes, and also as a preservative in mortuaries and medical laboratories. It is also found in some glues, adhesives, and fabrics. The compound is carcinogenic and can irritate the eyes, nose, throat, and lungs, and higher levels of exposure can cause some types of cancers.
