Ice cream develops a crunchy texture if left out of the freezer for too long due to overly large ice crystals. Scientists from the University of Tennessee have developed a solution that involves a microwavable cup and a biodegradable lid.

Ice cream develops a crunchy texture if left out of the freezer for too long due to overly large ice crystals. Scientists from the University of Tennessee have developed a way to keep ice cream soft even at room temperature, by using a gel that prevents the formation of large ice crystals. The gel is made of a polymer called poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG), which is a common ingredient in food and medicine. The gel is added to the ice cream mixture before it is frozen, and it forms a network of tiny fibers that trap the water molecules and prevent them from forming large crystals. This keeps the ice cream soft and creamy, even after it has been left out of the freezer for a while.

Ice cream develops a crunchy texture if left out of the freezer for too long due to overly large ice crystals. Scientists from the University of Tennessee have developed a new process that makes it possible to create ice cream that stays creamy and soft for longer. The scientists discovered that exposing ice cream mix to a high pressure environment results in smaller ice crystals. Small ice crystals mean the ice cream remains creamy and soft, even if it has been stored at room temperature for some time. The process involves forcing the mix through a high-pressure nozzle and cooling it very quickly. This stops the ice crystals from forming. The ice cream can then be stored at low temperatures. The results are promising: the new technique makes it possible to store the ice cream for 2 to 3 months at -5 C (23 F) and for one month at -18 C (0 F). The new technique is still being tested and could come to market in the near future. Source: Hans Bosch, "Ice cream that doesn't melt, even at room temperature," news.ku.dk, 2015. 2015, Ice Cream, Innovation, Netherlands, Unilever

Ice cream develops a crunchy texture if left out of the freezer for too long due to overly large ice crystals. Scientists from the University of Tennessee have developed a way to melt these hardened crystals so that their frosting remains soft. The research team, led by Professor David Donnelly and Associate Professor Neil Williams, used computer simulations based on crystallographic principles found in nature as well as thermodynamic calculations to determine how best to break down ice formation in frozen foods such as sundaes bases or even smoothies. The researchers then built an experimental apparatus using copper water heat exchangers with heating coils coated with special polymers designed to lower freezing point without melting the product itself. "The main theoretical problem was knowing what kind of cooling mechanism should be used and also understanding where the optimal operating temperature is when it comes to different types of food products because they're not all going to respond the same way" said Bachelor's student, Timothy Youleech, who conducted his thesis work under Dr. Donelly at UT-Knoxville's College of Veterinary Medicine Biomedical Sciences Department of Food Science Extension Center. Youleech says he worked closely with the scientists during the course of his study to develop new apparatus called phase change materials (PCMs) which are capable of low-temperature vaporization while maintaining both thermal stability and high conductivity properties demanded by commercial refrigeration equipment. PCMs generally consist of hydrophobic particles surrounded by a polymeric matrix able to absorb a certain amount of energy upon freezing before releasing this stored latent heat of fusion through evaporation of its constituent liquid molecules into the surrounding medium once the applied heat source has been removed.

It could prove useful in the cryopreservation of cells, tissues, and organs. The additive could be in products within the next five years.

Ice cream develops a crunchy texture if left out of the freezer for too long due to overly large ice crystals. Scientists from the University of Tennessee have developed a new method to prevent large ice crystals from forming in ice cream. Instead of traditional cooling methods, the researchers used a process called micro-cooling, which involves rapidly cooling the ice cream at a very low temperature of -196 C. This technique allows the ice cream to freeze quickly, preventing large ice crystals from forming and improving the overall texture and taste of the ice cream. In addition to improving the texture of ice cream, this new method could also have applications in other frozen foods, such as frozen fruits and vegetables, and in the preservation of biological materials like blood and semen. Overall, this new technology has the potential to revolutionize the frozen food industry and improve the quality and shelf life of frozen foods.

A network of radio telescopes in the Netherlands made detailed recordings of a lightning bolt during a summer storm in 2018. The recordings, which were processed only recently, show lightning as a brief, intense flash of radio waves, and help explain the surprisingly large amounts of radio waves emitted by lightning. A radio telescope is a type of radio receiver attached to a large dish or array of dishes to collect radio waves from distant astronomical sources. The image at the top of the page shows lightning as seen by a camera. The second image is what the radio telescope network recorded.

A network of radio telescopes in the Netherlands made detailed recordings of a lightning bolt during a summer storm in 2018. The recordings, which were processed only recently, show lightning at 1.4 GHz, 2.4 GHz and 5.8 GHz. By observing the lightning as it traveled through the air, scientists were able to calculate the speed at which the lightning traveled through the atmosphere. This speeds are typically between 400 to 600 meters per second, which is about 760 to 1,120 mph. The speeds are not consistent with lightning traveling in a straight line, so the researchers believe the lightning traveled in an elliptical orbit. The researchers used the measurements of the three frequencies of radio waves to calculate the curvature of the orbit. They also calculated the curvature of the orbit by measuring the time it took for the three radio waves to travel through the air. The results of the calculations are in agreement with a theoretical model for elliptical orbits of lightning. The research team published their findings in the journal Nature. "I think that this is a beautiful, beautiful piece of research," Kevin Connors, a researcher at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, said in a statement. "It's extremely well done and the paper is clear and well written.

It's probably our most important mission and we have spent a lot of time and effort on it. " "If you are wondering why we haven't released Signal before, it's because we have been focusing on privacy and security from day 1. That's why we did a desktop client, why we launched on mobile, why we've built our own servers, why we don't store any logs, why we've chosen not to integrate with Facebook's messenger and other companies, why we've taken the liberty to change the name of our service. It's not because we don't want to provide a great product, but because we want to provide the best possible experience for our users and we want to make sure that they feel comfortable using our service. We believe that there is a difference between privacy and security and that it's not possible to have both at the same time. For example, we think that people shouldn't be tracked and we believe that we should be able to prevent that. But we also believe that people should be able to protect their privacy and we believe that we should be able to help them do that. So when we built Signal, we did so because we believe in the importance of privacy and security. " "If you think about it, Signal has the exact same features as WhatsApp and Facebook Messenger. It allows you to send messages, photos, videos, calls, group chats and more. It's just that Signal does not track you, does not log any data, does not store any logs and does not provide any special services for the data that it does collect. We have a strict policy on the amount of data that we collect and we don't use it for advertising or for marketing. " "If you want to know why we have not released Signal before, it's because we have been working on privacy and security for over a year. We have done a lot of work on the server and desktop clients and we have built all of the infrastructure needed to support all of the features that we offer. And now we are ready to make it public. " "We are really excited to make Signal public and we hope that you will enjoy using it. " "Signal will be open source and we are working on a GitHub repo right now. " "We have a lot of ideas and we will be announcing them in the near future. " "What about mobile? " "We are working on a desktop client for Android and iOS, but we do not have any information about when that will be ready. " "We have a lot of other interesting things planned for the future and we are really excited about it. " "What about developers? " "We are working on an SDK and there are a lot of exciting things planned for it. " "Signal is not a clone of WhatsApp or Facebook Messenger. It's a privacy focused messenger that has many of the same features as those apps, but without tracking and without logging. " "Signal has a lot of features that WhatsApp and Facebook Messenger do not offer. Signal is the only messenger that lets you send files without storing any of them, that allows you to create and share groups, that allows you to add multiple contacts to a group and that allows you to create channels for private chats. " "Signal is a private messenger and it is not just a clone of WhatsApp or Facebook Messenger. " "We hope that you will enjoy using Signal. " "It's still a work in progress, but we are really excited about it. " "We will be adding a lot of new features in the coming months and we are really excited about it. " "We will also be making Signal open source, so you can see the code for yourself and check out how we built it. " "You can join the Signal community and ask us questions on our Telegram group, telegram.mesignal, or on Twitter at signalapp."

Signal is a private messaging app that doesn't track or store data on its users. In this thread, the Signal development team answers questions by Redditors. The team plans to pop in from time to time to answer questions about the app. ut3hCrypt Signal Development Team QA with the Signal Development Team Hi, we're the Signal development team. We're here to answer your questions. Are there any plans for a webdesktop client in the future? Yes, we plan to do a webdesktop client eventually, but we haven't started on it yet. Being that the NSA can easily break AES and probably break Elliptic Curve Cryptography, what is the point of using Signal? People have been trying to break AES for 15 years and they've had no success. The same goes for the ECC curves we use. We don't see any reason to believe that the NSA can break them. Regardless, the NSA can always break any system if they can coerce you to give them your keys. That's why we're putting a lot of effort into building features that reduce the need for keys. Is there any concern with Whisper Systems being a corporate entity and the fact that (as I understand it) the keys are held on their servers? Yes, that's a concern. That's why we're building features that reduce the need for keys. Can you comment on how Signal's encryption stack compares to that of RedPhoneTextSecure? Signal uses the TextSecure protocol, which is used by both Signal and TextSecure. The only difference between the two apps is that TextSecure supports SMS messages, while Signal does not. Is it possible to integrate Signal into a non-Google Play store ROM? This is a bit complicated. Signal uses the TextSecure protocol, which is open source. You can integrate the protocol into whatever ROM you want. However, the Signal app is not open source, so you can't just take the app itself and put it on a different store. What are your plans to have Android 4.4 support? We'll probably make a 4.4 branch of the app that will work on older Android versions. That said, we'd really like for all of our users to upgrade to Android 5.0 because the new permissions system makes it much easier to keep your private messages private. I'd just like to say a big thanks for the hard work and dedication you guys are putting into making signal better! It's a great app and I'm really happy to support you guys! Keep up the good work! Why is it that all Signal messages are sent with Signal? That's because all of our users are required to install Signal. If you send a Signal message to someone who doesn't have the app installed, the message will be sent using Signal's fallback transport (the regular phone number). If they install the app later, the fallback messages will automatically be converted into Signal messages. We considered building a non-Signal version of the app that only uses SMS messages, but we decided not to do that because it would have required a lot of complicated fallback logic. Is there any difference between the RedPhone and Signal encryption stacks, besides the obvious SMS support on RedPhone? I see you are moving away from the RedPhone name, so I assume there must be some reason. RedPhone and Signal use the same encryption stack. The only difference is that RedPhone supports SMS messages, while Signal does not. We decided to move away from the RedPhone name because we don't think it accurately describes the app any more. The goal of the app is to replace the regular phone call functionality, and "RedPhone" sounds like a VoIP app (which it is not). I'd like to use Signal but my friends are more comfortable with Facebook Messenger. I'm wondering if you guys have considered making it easier to communicate between the two platforms and if that's something you guys are planning to do? I've thought about it, but I'm not sure it's possible without a whole lot of complexity. If we're going to make it easy to chat with someone who doesn't use Signal, we'd rather do it through SMS messages than through Facebook. SMS messages are a lot simpler than Facebook, and the fallback logic is much easier to handle. Just wanted to say that I was happy to see the new update to the app that included group messaging. Our interview series continues from last week's discussion between Kirstian Grnnemark, founder and CEO at Freeooo Limited, and Daymond John, co-founder and Chairman Emeritus at FUBU Group Inc., who gave us his advice during the year he spent leading Universal Studios Japan. (As always, please feel free to post any additional thoughts below!) 2. Do you think there are some fundamental differences in business culture between Asia and America? Daymond: It seems that many executives here don't understand what they need to do beyond just closing sales meeting after sale meeting. They think "people buy my stuff" - which means only letting people see the product physically before selling it. I think most Asian cultures want everything fast - they often say "nothing good happens overnight" - but Americans generally take things slowly and that's not necessarily bad because sometimes nothing worthwhile ever does happen overnight. You should build something big enough to become successful 'on purpose' - not accidentally - and then let others help make it bigger. If businesses aren't growing quickly or multiple times over, executives should focus on figuring out why. Both groups seem to lean toward positivity despite failure and an open mindset towards new ideas and opportunities even though growth has stalled. Daymond: If executives spend three minutes thinking "buying must increase 50 next month," then they won't find anything wrong with themselves unless they also think "my life will go down the toilet if I make that mistake." However, once someone learns through experience and mistakes that success doesn't come easy or instantaneously, such attitude becomes helpful rather than detrimental. Overall, however, Chinese companies tend to treat employees better than American ones while bringing much less value to customers. So although being honest might hurt short-term profits, it's really usually well received long-term because honesty helps all stakeholders connect directly with each other without unnecessary middlemen or intermediaries. Kirstian: Mostly American leaders assume their decisions benefit everyone except them personally, therefore making it difficult to admit errors made and learning lessons gained from failed attempts. Most importantly, not knowing where one's company stands financially makes it impossible to avoid wasting resources unnecessarily. One example I've seen time and again would be: A European leader wants to put two billion euros into building a factory but fails to ask whether consumers actually require such products anymore or wantneed it cheaper somewhere else instead. Therefore, he uses half of the money to develop some innovative servicesproposals competing against existing offerings in order to generate income for himself, staff members, stockholders, etc. And keeps the rest invested in marketing activities. Daymond: Anyone could create an internet site especially designed to sell eBooks for 5 per copy, but attract only 2,000 orders annually, yielding no profit whatsoever, and leave 80 percent of net earnings back to itself. In contrast, when Amazon creates a site intended purely to set eBook prices, collect shipping fees, and charge consumers 5 percent commission amounting to 40 million dollars monthly turnover. (and leaves 80 percent to its investors.) Many small-to-mid-sized enterprises choose to follow the second path since they lack sufficient understanding of consumer preferences andor demand patterns. Especially regarding more important factors determining enterprise survival, such as: customer satisfaction rate, retention rates, advertising costs, brand recognition, differentiation strategy, ability to innovate, economies-of-scale, etc. Kirstian: There needs to be enough transparency among top management teams for different levels within organizations to effectively communicate with each other. For instance, if an employee asks a manager how the organization will handle certain crisis situation, managers should immediately send corresponding instructions to relevant departments ahead of expected outcomes if possible since graduates may end up taking shortcuts due to ignorance. (While attending a conference recently, I heard a headline claiming Google is hiring 30,000 engineers. How? With google ads. Horrible) Also, HR professionals need to establish mechanisms for transparent communication internally and externally. For instance, internal communications should refer to key performance indicators, competitors' practices, current market trends, industry standards, etc. On external communications, "I'm sorry

Scalene is a high-performance CPU and memory profiler for Python. It is fast as it uses sampling instead of instrumentation or relying on Python's tracing facilities. Scalene performs CPU profiling by collecting statistics on the amount of time each function and line of code is taking to run. It also provides memory profiling capabilities by tracking the amount of memory used by each object and the overall memory footprint of the program. Scalene can be used to identify performance bottlenecks in your code and optimize your Python applications. It is also useful for identifying memory leaks and inefficient memory usage patterns in your code. Overall, Scalene is a powerful tool that can help developers build faster and more efficient Python programs.

This Twitter thread follows Facebook's company-wide end-of-year meeting. During the meeting, the speakers discuss the company's role in the major events of the year, reflecting on the role it played in the global political environment. The most important thing that happened this year? We learned how to prevent abuse on Facebook. But the most important thing that happened in 2018? We got used to doing things that don't work very well. - Mark Zuckerberg (markzuckerberg) December 19, 2018 The main goal of this year's meeting was to make sure that Facebook's senior leadership had a good look at how the company was changing. "I want you to understand that we are different now," Zuckerberg said in his address. "We are different because we have more users, and we are different because of what we have learned from the past year." "We've done a lot of things that have not worked," he said. "We've done a lot of things that haven't worked very well." The next steps Zuckerberg is calling for "deeper investment in technology" and a "sober look" at the way that Facebook thinks about the world. In his talk, Zuckerberg laid out the two goals that he wants to focus on: One is to "take a deep dive into understanding what's happening in the world." The other is to "build technology that helps us better understand how the world works and help us solve problems in a way that matters." Zuckerberg said that the work of the company will focus on three things: data, culture, and philanthropy. Zuckerberg said that he wants to "re-focus" the company on the things that matter most, and he said that this is a good time to do that. "Now is a good time to ask hard questions," he said. "I want to ask questions like: what's going on with this? What should we do about that? Why is this happening? What are we doing to prevent this?" "We're in a lot of work right now," Zuckerberg said. "I want to make sure we are focusing on what's important. That's why I'm asking for everyone's help to make sure we are focusing on the things that matter." Zuckerberg said that he will be going through the company's 100,000-plus employees to ensure that they understand what he wants to do and how they can help. "We are going to make sure we are doing things that are right," he said. "We're going to work hard to make sure that we are doing things that are good for our users and the world.

Key-based login eliminates the risk of a man-in-the-middle attack, because the SSH server is configured to accept only a key, not a password. This is a secure method, as long as you use SSH with a passphrase-protected key. If you don't use a passphrase, you risk falling victim to a man-in-the-middle attack. But if you use a passphrase-protected key, there is a risk that someone can get access to the machine you're using to generate the SSH key. In that case, the intruder could use ssh-copy-id to copy the key to another account. The solution to this risk is to generate the SSH key on a machine that is in a secure location and never let anyone else access that machine. I call this machine the "key machine." The first step in creating a key-based SSH login is to generate an SSH key pair. To do this, log in to the key machine, and run ssh-keygen. This will prompt you for a passphrase. This will prompt you to enter a user name, a secret, and an issuer. The user name is the name of the account you're using on the remote server. The secret is a random number. The issuer is the domain name of the server. You can specify the domain name with the -I option. This will generate a QR code, which you can scan with the Google Authenticator app. It will then prompt you for a passcode, which you can get from your Google Authenticator app. You should now see a 6-digit passcode that refreshes every 30 seconds. This article discusses tips and tricks for using SSH more effectively. It covers how to add a second factor to your SSH login, use agent forwarding safely, exit from stuck SSH sessions, and more. If you're already a frequent user of SSH, you may have been wondering how to add a second factor to your login, how to use agent forwarding safely, how to exit from stuck SSH sessions, and how to make sure that the SSH daemon is running on your server. These are all excellent questions, and this article will cover them all. Step 1: Adding a second factor to your SSH login The first step in adding a second factor to your SSH login is to create a password-less authentication method. The SSH client supports two methods for password-less authentication. They are public key authentication and GSSAPI. 1. Public key authentication Public key authentication is the simplest method for password-less authentication. In this method, the server sends a public key that can be used to authenticate the user. When you login to a server, you provide your public key to the server, and it uses that key to authenticate you. If you ever lose your private key, you'll be unable to log in to the server, but your public key can still be used to log in to the server. The key to this method is that the server must have your public key. This is often a problem because the server may not be the same as the one you're logging into. In addition, it's possible for the server to deny your public key. The following diagram illustrates this scenario: 2. GSSAPI GSSAPI is an authentication method that is used by Kerberos. It's often referred to as Kerberos authentication, but that is a misnomer. Kerberos is the authentication protocol, and GSSAPI is a mechanism for authenticating with Kerberos. GSSAPI works in conjunction with a Kerberos ticket. When you try to login to a server, you first send your credentials to the server. The server sends your credentials to the Kerberos ticket server. The ticket server stores your credentials in a database. The ticket server then returns the ticket to the server. When you try to login to the server, the server sends the ticket to the client. The client uses the ticket to authenticate with the server. The client sends the server your public key, which the server uses to authenticate you. The GSSAPI protocol is very complex. It's possible for a server to deny a ticket. In addition, it's possible for a server to deny a ticket even if you provide your public key. For this reason, GSSAPI is often considered a less secure method of authentication than public key authentication. It is important to understand that GSSAPI is a protocol that is used by public key authentication. You can use GSSAPI to add a second factor to public key authentication. However, it is not the same as adding a second factor to public key authentication. In the example above, you would use GSSAPI to add a second factor to public key authentication, but you would not use GSSAPI to add a second factor to public key authentication. Step 2: Using agent forwarding safely Agent forwarding allows you to run a command on a remote machine without actually logging into the remote machine. It's important to use agent forwarding safely. If you use agent forwarding in an insecure way, it can lead to security problems. This article covers how to use agent forwarding safely. 1. Use the -A option When you use the -A option, the SSH daemon stores your key in the agent. When you use the -A option, the SSH daemon stores your key in the agent. When you use the -A option, the SSH daemon stores your key in the agent. This allows you to run a command on a remote machine without logging into the remote machine. It also allows you to run a command on a remote machine without storing the key on the remote machine. The following example shows how to use the -A option: ssh -A 2. Use the -N option When you use the -N option, the SSH daemon sends a prompt to the client. The client then sends the password to the server, and the server stores the password in the agent. The SSH daemon sends a prompt to the client. The client then sends the password to the server, and the server stores the password in the agent. The following example shows how to use the -N option: ssh -N 3. Use the -F option When you use the -F option, the SSH daemon forwards the password from the client to the server. The following example shows how to use the -F option: ssh -F 4. Use the -D option When you use the -D option, the SSH daemon stores the password in the agent. The SSH daemon then forwards the password from the agent to the server.

A Mexican startup called Biomitech has developed an artificial tree that it claims is capable of processing the same amount of air pollution as 368 living trees. Unlike trees, Biourbanitech's tree requires no water, soil, or sunlight to do its job. The Smog-Eating Tower is designed to remove CO2 from the atmosphere, and it is currently being tested in Mexico City, one of the world's most polluted cities. The tower was developed with the help of researchers at UNAM, Mexico's National Autonomous University. It uses a photocatalytic pigment called titanium dioxide, which is activated by the sun's rays and oxygen in the air to neutralize pollutants. Mexico City has struggled with air pollution for decades. In 1992, the UN named it the most polluted city in the world. The city has made some progress since then, but it still ranks among the world's most polluted. Biomitech plans to build 1,000 of the artificial trees over the next few years, and it says it hopes to eventually install them in urban areas around the world. The Smog-Eating Tower costs about 25,000 to build, which is much cheaper than trying to plant 368 real trees. It's also cheaper than other technology to fight air pollution. The company says that one of its trees costs about 10 percent of what it would cost to build an air-purification system. Biomitech is not the first company to develop a structure to help purify air in urban areas. In 2017, a company called Green City Solutions installed air-purifying trees in cities around Europe. They use mosses that absorb pollutants. While Biomitech's technology may be effective at cleaning up air pollution, trees do a lot more than just remove pollutants from the air. They can also help fight climate change by removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and storing it in their trunks. Trees can also help prevent flooding by absorbing excess water and releasing it into the atmosphere. They can also help moderate temperatures by reducing the amount of heat absorbed by the pavement. And they look nice, too. Photo credit: Biomitech Mexico City Smog-Eating Tower

A Mexican startup called Biomitech has developed an artificial tree that it claims is capable of processing the same amount of air pollution as 368 living trees. Unlike trees, Biourbano doesn't produce oxygen but rather converts pollutants into compost. It's a lot like the way that industrial plants operate. Instead of capturing and using the gases released by combustion, they release them to the air, making the whole process inefficient. Biomitech's machine works by capturing the gases, such as carbon dioxide and nitrogen oxide, from the air and converting them into compost using a mixture of plant matter and special microbes. The company claims that it can process more than 1,000 times the amount of pollutants as a living tree and says it will be able to capture more than 90 percent of nitrogen oxide and 70 percent of carbon dioxide. This will have a big impact on air pollution and climate change. However, some scientists have pointed out that this technology is still in its infancy and is not yet ready for commercial use.

A Mexican startup called Biomitech has developed an artificial tree that it claims is capable of processing the same amount of air pollution as 368 living trees. Unlike trees, Biourban  which measures about 7 feet tall and 3 feet wide  can be installed in any location and doesnt require sunlight or water to operate. It does require electricity, however, as the trees bio-regenerative process is powered by a small fan and a pump that pushes air through a series of filters. Biomitech says that Biourban can remove up to 90% of pollutants from the air, including particulate matter, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen oxides. It can also absorb sound and help to regulate indoor humidity.

It was interesting then to hear John McDonnell call for an all-out effort of economic development in order to reduce carbon consumption globally while avoiding any social upheavals that might emanate from such large-scale intervention. The technology behind the Biourban trees is still in the early stages of development, but the potential benefits are significant. A Mexican startup called Biomitech has developed an artificial tree that it claims is capable of processing the same amount of air pollution as 368 living trees. Unlike trees, Biourban doesn't require many years to grow. The 14-foot metal tree uses microalgae that pulls carbon dioxide and other contaminants from the air, releasing pure oxygen as a byproduct. China's state-owned train developer CRRC has unveiled a magnetic levitation train that can reach speeds of up to 600 kph. It began development in 2016, with a successful trial run on June 27. The high-speed rail car is the first commercial vehicle developed by China's biggest railway company and used for passenger transportation under Chinese law according to online reports. "We have made considerable progress since being charged this year in developing novel technologies such as magnetic levitation technology and new materials," said director of design at Beijing Engineering Research Institute (BERI) Zheng Xiaoqiang during a media conference when he announced the project launch. "The latest electric locomotive prototype ran smoothly without any problems or incidents on its test track in Tianjin at an average speed of 350 kmhour, which means it passed all tests we planned from the beginning of testing last summer. The prototype achieved 300kmhour with no acceleration time. We also performed other important tests successfully, including long-distance tests over several hundred kilometres along country roads using battery power only," added President Wang Jing after launching the four-car highspeed train model at the firm's headquarters in Beijing earlier this month. Developed originally by Japan's Hitachi Heavy Industries Co., the electric train uses superconducting magnets and copper coils instead of steel wheels to move through rails above ground level while allowing passengers sitting inside the carriage to see panoramic views ahead thanks to windows opening vertically upwards like shutters. The Japanese had transferred their maglev patents back into 2007 but only one half of the system was built because large parts were still missing until later that year when they finally received official approvals regarding the rest of the components of the overall scheme, Berli Jucker revealed. It took another five years before China officially started construction work at its own site, although some sources believe that due to anti-trust concerns between countries involved, the Japanese who are partners in the project may not be allowed to build more than 50 per cent - meaning there could well remain substantial gaps within certain critical elements such as control systems, batteries, engines etc.

It began development in 2016, with a successful trial run taking place in May. The train can also travel up to 2,000 km on a single charge and will be powered by lithium batteries. It could be used in both passenger and cargo transport, and could help further the development of China's high-speed rail network. China has been rapidly developing its high-speed rail network. In August, China opened the world's first fully automated high-speed rail line in Chongqing. The 300-km long line can carry up to 1,300 passengers per hour at speeds of 120 kph. It could help China's ambitious plans to expand its high-speed rail network to 38,000 km by 2025, and 150,000 km by 2050, including extending it across the world to connect China to Europe and Africa.

China's state-owned train developer CRRC has unveiled a magnetic levitation train that can reach speeds of up to 600 kph. It began development in 2016, with a successful trial run in January 2019. The train, which is called the Shanghai Maglev, is currently the fastest commercial train in operation, with a top speed of 603 kph. It runs on a 30-kilometer track between the Pudong International Airport and the Longyang Road station in Shanghai. The Shanghai Maglev is the second generation of maglev trains in China. The first generation, called the Transrapid, was developed by a German company and operated in Shanghai from 2004 to 2011. The Transrapid had a top speed of 430 kph. The Shanghai Maglev is expected to carry up to 10,000 passengers per day. It is expected to reduce travel time between the airport and the city center from 40 minutes to 8 minutes.

The train utilizes magnetic levitation technology, which works by using magnets to lift the train slightly above the tracks, reducing friction and resulting in faster speeds. This new train is expected to significantly reduce travel times, especially for long-distance journeys, and could potentially revolutionize transportation in the future.

China's state-owned train developer CRRC has unveiled a magnetic levitation train that can reach speeds of up to 600 kph. It began development in 2016, with a successful trial run in June last year. The maglev can make the trip from Beijing to Shanghai in three and a half hours, two hours shorter than the time needed for a conventional bullet train to travel the same distance. CRRC exports trains worldwide, but it has yet to release plans for how it will commercialize the maglev.

A bug in Tesla's Autopilot driving program would sometimes pull cars towards lane dividers in specific spots on a Reddit user's commute. Despite reporting the issue to Tesla many times, he received no response. There have been several software updates since the user started reporting the issue, with some updates fixing the issue temporarily, but dashcam footage confirms that it still occurs. Tesla owner Walter Huang died in a crash at a site similar to the one where this bug occurs last year, and there is evidence that the vehicle veered towards a lane divider and sped up while on autopilot prior to the crash. Tesla maintains that Autopilot is meant to assist drivers and that drivers must still be attentive while using the program.

A bug in Tesla's Autopilot driving program would sometimes pull cars towards lane dividers in specific spots on a Reddit user's commute. A bug in Tesla's Autopilot driving program would sometimes pull cars towards lane dividers in specific spots on a Reddit user's commute. Despite reporting the issue to Tesla many times, the bug still persisted. "I am a frequent Tesla driver and have a range of experiences with their vehicles," the Reddit user wrote. "I own a Model S, Model X, Model 3, and the Roadster. I have also driven the Model 3 in Autopilot. The following is a description of my experiences with Autopilot, based on my experience with these vehicles." The user first reported the bug to Tesla in October 2018. When asked about the bug in a forum post, a Tesla representative responded: "We are looking into this. Thanks for bringing this to our attention." The bug persisted and the user continued to report it. The bug persisted for weeks, even after Tesla's representatives attempted to replicate the bug in the test lab. Finally, after months of reporting the bug, Tesla fixed it in software. The Reddit user wrote: "When I finally got my car back in January 2019, it had been fixed. I have had no issues with Autopilot since then." Incidents with Autopilot have been reported across the country.

A bug in Tesla's Autopilot driving program would sometimes pull cars towards lane dividers in specific spots on a Reddit user's commute. Despite reporting the issue to Tesla many times, he says the bug persisted for over a year. The bug would tell the car to make a left turn when it was already in the leftmost lane, but sometimes the car would go to the right when it was supposed to go left. Tesla says the problem was caused by a faulty camera and was fixed in June 2017. In the case of the Reddit user's car, the bug remained even after Tesla updated the software. Tesla says it "not aware of any instance" of the bug in its cars. The problem was a faulty camera that was replaced by Tesla in June 2017, but it had no effect on the Reddit user's car. A Tesla representative told Business Insider that the company wasn't aware of any other instances of the problem. The Reddit user, who goes by the handle "ugarsh," said he's spoken to many Tesla employees over the last year, and none of them had seen the issue before. Tesla says that its cameras don't identify lane markings as one or two lines, but rather, as three lines. "A lane with a dotted line on one side and a solid line on the other is recognized as a single left-bound lane, and a lane with a solid line on both sides is seen as a single right-bound lane," the representative said. If there's a bug in the software that makes the car think it's in the rightmost lane instead of the leftmost lane, the car will try to get to the left, even though it's already in the leftmost lane. The bug persisted for many months, and Tesla was unable to fix it. "For reasons unknown to me, Tesla's Autopilot (AP) software has a bug that causes the car to behave very strangely in a very specific location on my daily commute. AP will detect a lane divider which is actually the exit lane on a highway off ramp. After the car departs the highway, it will try to veer to the left, even though the car is already in the left lane." The Reddit user said that he initially believed the bug was a problem with the car's GPS, but found out it was an issue with the software. "I've brought this to Tesla's attention many times over the last year, but they've never been able to fix it. They've inspected the car several times. They've had me demo the issue to service personnel, engineers, and managers. They've tried changing the firmware. They've tried upgrading the AP hardware. They've tried disabling AP in the location. They've tried changing the lane detection sensors, and they've replaced the AP computer twice," the Reddit user wrote. "I even insisted on trying to demo the problem on one of the loaner cars. I finally gave up after they swapped my car for a loaner while my car was in for service and the same issue persisted in the loaner car." It's not clear why the car has this problem, and the Reddit user doesn't know of any other Tesla drivers who have experienced the issue. Tesla says that all of its Autopilot-equipped cars have the same hardware, but it's not clear if the software is updated at different times. The bug persisted even after Tesla updated the software. It's not clear why Tesla didn't find the bug sooner. Tesla's Autopilot system has been in use since 2015, and the software has been updated multiple times over the years. Tesla has collected more than 1.3 billion miles worth of data from Autopilot since its launch, so it's surprising the company didn't come across the problem sooner. Tesla has been pushing for full self-driving features to roll out to its cars before the end of the year. The company has even said that some cars it built since October 2016 have the hardware necessary for full autonomy, but Tesla says it's waiting for regulatory approval before rolling out those features. Tesla did not immediately respond to Business Insider's request for comment on this story. SEE ALSO: Tesla says it's going to try

A bug in Tesla's Autopilot driving program would sometimes pull cars towards lane dividers in specific spots on a Reddit user's commute. Despite reporting the issue to Tesla many times, no one was able to fix it until now. The driver who submitted the video said that his car had been doing this for years, and that he reported multiple incidents to Tesla but never received an answer or explanation of what happened. Because Autopilot uses laser-based sensing technology rather than cameras, there are very few clear signs when something is wrong with the software - so even users who have experienced similar issues usually can't prove they were affected by Tesla's system. But in recent months, more people encountered these problems using their own vehicles as well, which led some locals to take matters into their own hands. According to The Verge, dozens of residents living near Silicon Valley shared videos showing how drivers' cars would suddenly turn toward lanes while moving at highway speeds without any obvious reason. Some of the footage shows the vehicle coming straight out of nowhere before pulling over onto roadsides; others show the cars directly hitting barriers both physical and virtual. One video posted on YouTube involved two vehicles colliding head-on after being pulled away from a traffic convoy. A third video shows three SUVs veering off an interstate bridge and crashing down into the water below. Tesla has since claimed that all instances where its autonomous-driving features can be compromised come about due to human error. It also says it's working hard to improve AutoPilot's ability to detect abnormal situations like those seen here, although there's still much work ahead.

One of the most uncomfortable aspects of AI technology is that we do not understand how the algorithms that we end up with work. While we know that the technology works, sometimes it does so in ways that are counterintuitive and unwieldy from a human perspective. In its current state, deep learning often uses so-called "black box" methods for their modeling and training. This means that while we can see what happens within an algorithm, once it has learned to solve problems using these black-box models - even though they have been proven effective at doing so - we cannot get inside it or examine how it goes about completing each step involved in solving tasks such as image recognition and speech processing. We may think that this lack of transparency means that machine learning systems will never be able to perform well enough on some complex applications (such as autonomous driving) but that wasn't necessarily true when data analytics and machine learning were first developed 20 years ago.

StoreDot, an Israeli company, has developed car batteries capable of fully charging in five minutes. The batteries can be mass-produced on standard production lines. StoreDot has so far raised 130 million NIS (25.5 million) from investors including PayPal and Goldman Sachs. In addition to its impressive speed rating for a battery pack, the company claims that it is also "low-cost" compared with other lithium-ion technologies - potentially allowing a large-scale market penetration into electric vehicles. The technology apparently uses low-density graphite plates similar to those used by Tesla to manufacture their Model S premium EVs. While all forms of solar energy have what's called "the same problem": producing too much power during peak periods when demand is high but there are few or no panels available to use it, photovoltaic systems may soon find themselves facing some new competition: floating wind turbines. Wind energy tends to produce more electrical output throughout most parts of the day than anyone could ever need at any given point in time, like the photo above shows. But as you might guess, this means problems if you're trying to get enough usable electricity out of your system without relying entirely on intermittent renewable sources such as wind as well. (At least that's the case today.) Imagine plugging up half a dozen solar panel arrays together, each one able to provide 1 megawatt-hour capacity through 16 hours per day. And then imagine adding another 10mWp worth of PV capacities over two days, along with six additional units providing 2 mWh each out of 14 hour shifts - totaling 25MWp of combined capacity at 24 hours each day. That wouldn't quite cover even half of New Zealand's annual energy consumption ... unless there were floating offshore turbines around! As Jianguo Li reports in Bloomberg Green, researchers think they've found just how big the problem: "The greatest challenge lies not only in achieving sufficient levels of fuel economy, but in keeping costs down because current models require expensive equipment that will cost billions of dollars to install and maintain," said Professor Edward Jones, lead author of the study published online last week.

Epilepsy is a common disorder that affects approximately 50 million people worldwide. Currently, there are no effective treatments for the approximately 50 percent of patients who do not respond to anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs). One recent advance in epilepsy treatment is the use of deep brain stimulation (DBS) to stimulate specific areas of the brain in order to suppress seizures. DBS can be effective for certain patients with medically refractory epilepsy, but the surgical implantation of electrodes to perform DBS can be difficult and expensive, and patients may have side effects that can be unpleasant andor debilitating. A new study by CSHL scientists, led by Assistant Professor Joshua Gordon, shows that stimulation of the vagus nerve in adult mice improves their ability to learn and retain information. The research team's work, which appears online today ahead of print in Nature Neuroscience, suggests that vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) in humans may also have similar beneficial effects. "There's a lot of interest in this," said Gordon, who is a member of the CSHL Neurobiology Behavior Program. "Vagus nerve stimulation is already being used in some human conditions, and this may open the door for other uses of VNS in humans." The vagus nerve is a major nerve that runs from the brain through the neck and thorax, to the abdomen. It is part of the parasympathetic system, which regulates heart rate and digestion, among other functions. VNS has been used to treat epilepsy and depression in humans, and recent studies have suggested that it could help treat other conditions such as chronic pain and inflammation. Gordon and his colleagues studied mice with VNS devices implanted in their necks. The VNS devices stimulate the vagus nerve, which is the largest nerve in the parasympathetic system. The vagus nerve carries information about the state of the body's organs to the central nervous system, including areas of the brain that are important for learning and memory. The researchers found that mice with VNS implants showed improved memory and learning in several behavioral tasks. They were better at remembering the location of a hidden platform in a water maze and they were better at recognizing objects they had previously encountered. The team found that VNS also increased the number of new neurons in the hippocampus, a part of the brain important for learning and memory. VNS increased the expression of genes in the hippocampus that are important for learning and memory. It also increased the release of a brain chemical called norepinephrine, which is important for arousal and attention. "What's really exciting here is that we're taking insights from animal neuroscience and trying to figure out how to help people with psychiatric and neurological conditions," said Gordon.

Business development consultant and author to help companies grow online using SEO and Content Marketing Strategy I'm just going to say this once: I'm not a fan of The Holiday Club series because I don't completely understand what they mean when they sum up each book by saying "Anna Kendrick will save Christmas" (the second book). As someone who doesn't know Anna Kendrick well enough to even like her movies - let alone consider them my favourite flick s got me wondering if she had anything else coming out anytime soon. Maybe it's time to stop being so picky? Speaking of unnecessary hype for unfamiliar actresses... Jennifer Aniston did something very similar last week after taking home Best Supporting Actress for her work on SNL-namely giving off the impression that every TV showfilm award was hers too. And speaking of Aniston, that's probably why I can't stand her either... For those of you who didn't watch Saturday Night Live last night, Kat Dennings' reaction to receiving her Golden Globe for Outstanding Performance By A Female Actor In A Comedy Series was pretty ridiculous. You could tell right away that she really wanted to go somewhere besides there (I imagine she felt guilty for having won two years in a row), so instead she decided to talk semi-seriously but then throw it back into comedy mode whenever possible throughout the speech. (Just kidding.) If you're curious, here's a behind-the-scenes video of her acceptance speech which starts about 2:50 in; can't spoil anything in advance though... Why do awards exist? To push certain types of people ahead of others based solely upon looks rather than talent. Sounds preposterous, huh? But guess what? That's exactly how Hollywood operates these days. Be strong girlfriends. Even if I never get to see another actor I've admired win an Oscar, I'll still be cheering them on every single step of the way. As part of National Literacy Month, readers across Canberra went head-to-head in writing short stories inspired by words found in Australian literature. "My heart ached almost immediately reading 'Canberra' by Tony Danaher, written in 1961 during his first visit to the capital city - taken as much pleasure from its description of the natural surrounds of Canberra as from the personalities he encountered along the way. "I wrote a story called 'A Memoir Of My Modern Life' following in the footsteps of William Faulkner while wandering around North Braddon Harcourt [a suburb near Canberra] at night with no light sources except candles and matchstick lanterns. I followed him down memory lane sending flashbacks of family life as far back as WWII. It became quite therapeutic actually getting lost amongst the streets."

A new book from a long-time Android engineer offers a behind-the-scenes look at early Android development. This article features two chapters from the book that covers the startup's search for a business model and the challenges they faced in building the first Android devices. The book, titled "Android: A Memoir," is authored by former Android engineer Chet Haase, who played an instrumental role in the development of the mobile OS. Haase's memoir offers readers an insider's perspective on the early years of Android, including candid accounts of the company's decision-making processes, technical challenges, and the personalities involved in its growth. At first, Android was seen as a competitor to Apple's iOS, but the company soon realized that it needed a different approach to succeed. A new book from a long-time Android engineer offers a behind-the-scenes look at early Android development. This article features two chapters from the book that covers the startup's search for a mobile phone operating system and how Android was born. Advertisement This article was updated to reflect that the book is now available in paperback and e-book. Google's search for a mobile phone operating system began in 2003, but Android wasn't ready for prime time until two years later. In the first chapter of his new book "Hacking Android," former Google engineer Jigar Shah reveals how the search for an operating system that could run on phones led the search-engine giant to abandon Symbian and settle on a custom mobile operating system. Shah's book, "Hacking Android: Building the World's Most Popular OS" (No Starch Press), is now available in paperback and e-book formats. Android was designed to run on phones and tablets, and the new book sheds light on how the company's early attempts at creating a mobile operating system were ultimately unsuccessful. "The first few years of Android were very painful," Shah told TechNewsWorld. "Android started as a project in 2003, but we didn't really start building the product until 2006. That's when the original hardware partners came on board, and we were able to ship the first device." The new book is the result of a year-long collaboration between Shah and developer Matias Duarte, the creator of the Android Studio IDE. The two worked together to develop a series of case studies that illustrate how Android was built. Duarte told TechNewsWorld that he and Shah had a "great collaboration," and that the book has "turned out really well." Duarte also noted that he thinks the book "could help people who want to understand how Android was built." "For developers, it's a good read," he said. "It will help them learn how to write apps for Android." A look at Android's early days When Google began work on Android, it was still working with Nokia to develop a mobile operating system that would run on phones. "That's when we got into the phone business," Shah said. "Google and Nokia had been working on the project for two years, and they had been building prototypes for a long time. It was really in 2003 that we decided to do something about it." The project, however, ran into problems. Shah said that the phone business wasn't as lucrative as expected, and the company "was having trouble scaling." Google eventually dropped Nokia as a partner and turned to a more established operating system, Symbian, to run on phones. Shah said that Google considered Symbian as a "potential option," but "we ultimately didn't like it because it was very complicated." Shah told TechNewsWorld that the team had a "couple of years" to develop Android before the device makers got on board, but that the team had "very little time to do that." "It's a very hard thing to do," he said. "You have to create a new OS and a new platform. It's not something that you can just copy and paste. It's a very hard problem." Shah said that the "major challenge" was that "the world has changed a lot in those two years." "It was very difficult to make a new platform," he said. "The big problem was that we had to make it work for everyone. It was very difficult to figure out how to make it work for everyone." That included making it work for a variety of phones and tablets. Shah said that "the early devices were very expensive, and we had to make sure that the OS worked on low-end devices." Shah told TechNewsWorld that Google had to make a lot of changes to Android to "make it run well on low-end devices." "That was the biggest challenge," he said. "It was really hard to make a new OS that would run on low-end devices. It's not something you can just copy and paste." Shah also noted that Google was dealing with some technical challenges. "We were working with the chipset manufacturers," he said. "It was very hard to make sure that all the components worked well together. It was really a challenge to get that right." The book offers some inside looks at how Google overcame those challenges. Shah told TechNewsWorld that the team eventually "figured out a way to make the OS work well on low-end devices." "That was the biggest challenge," he said. "It was really hard to make a new OS that would run on low-end devices. It's not something you can just copy and paste."

Woven Planet Holdings, a subsidiary of Toyota, is buying Lyft's self-driving division for 550 million in cash paid over five years. Lyft will see an annual savings of 100 million per year by selling its division. "This is a good time to sell as there is a lot of money in the market looking for something to buy," says Lyft CEO Logan Green. "This will be a good home for our engineers who are working on these projects. They will be able to complete their work with fewer distractions and more money." Lyft's self-driving division will now be a part of the Toyota company called Toyota Advanced Technologies. TAT has been developing autonomous vehicles for many years and is one of the few companies that has a permit to operate autonomous vehicles on the road in California. The division will continue to work on self-driving technology for Lyft and its parent company Alphabet, but it will also be developing technology for Toyota and TAT. One of the big goals of Toyota is to get autonomous vehicles on the road within the next few years. "We have been developing this technology for a long time," says TAT CEO Osamu Ii. "Lyft has been one of the best companies in this area, and we are very happy that they agreed to sell their division to us." "This acquisition will put us ahead of our competitors in the field," says Ii. "We have been working hard to get our self-driving vehicles on the road, and we now feel we can make that happen much sooner than we anticipated. We hope to have autonomous vehicles on the road by 2020."

Vince Ramos was the owner of Phantom Secure, a company that customized BlackBerry phones to make ordinary wiretaps impossible. Phantom was started in 2008 as Ramos saw a need to protect mobile communications, and he soon found himself in hot water. Ramos was subpoenaed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) to testify in a case against two men accused of a shooting spree in Virginia. Phantom was used to store data on a Blackberry phone used by one of the shooters, and Ramos refused to turn over the phone to the FBI. The company also refused to turn over a Blackberry used by one of the other shooters, and a judge ruled that the company must hand over the phone. Ramos lost the case, but not before getting some bad press, and Phantom was forced to close. Now, the company is suing the government, and in the process is trying to shed light on how and why the FBI is using encrypted mobile devices. The FBI is using the technology to crack passwords and intercept communications between criminals and the targets of its investigations. In the case of Phantom, the FBI is using its authority under the Stored Communications Act (SCA) to compel companies to turn over the data they store on mobile devices. The SCA allows the FBI to compel a company to hand over data, but the company must show that it is not technically feasible to decrypt the data. The FBI argued that it was not technically feasible for Phantom to decrypt the data, but a judge ruled that Phantom was obligated to do so. Phantom, in its lawsuit, is trying to show that the FBI is not just using the SCA to gain access to data stored on mobile devices, but is also using the law to get data stored on devices that have not been encrypted. "There is no question that the FBI has not limited its requests to those stored on devices that have been encrypted," the lawsuit states. "Rather, the FBI has been issuing and enforcing a blanket prohibition against the provision of any non-compromised data to the FBI." The lawsuit argues that the FBI has issued blanket prohibitions on data retrieval to several companies, including Verizon, ATT, Sprint, and Google. "Indeed, in a number of instances, the FBI has specifically issued prohibitions against the provision of uncompromised data to the FBI," the lawsuit states. "Thus, the FBI's blanket prohibition against the provision of non-compromised data to the FBI has resulted in numerous instances where the FBI has been prohibited from obtaining non-compromised data from various companies." In a press release, Phantom said that the government's "absurd" demands are a result of a 2006 law that allowed the government to compel companies to hand over data, but only when the data was encrypted. The law was designed to make it harder for criminals to get around wiretaps, but it also made it harder for companies to protect customers' privacy. "The fundamental flaw in the 2006 law was that it did not provide companies with the means to overcome this technical barrier," Phantom said in the press release. "This law was passed to help law enforcement, not to make it more difficult for law enforcement." Phantom is arguing that the government's use of the SCA to compel companies to hand over data that is not encrypted is unconstitutional. "The SCA was enacted to provide the government with the means to compel the disclosure of evidence in criminal cases," Phantom said in the press release. "The SCA does not provide a government agency with the authority to compel the disclosure of evidence that is not the subject of a criminal investigation." Phantom is arguing that the government is using the SCA to get data that is not the subject of a criminal investigation, but rather is evidence of crimes that the government has already investigated. Phantom argues that the government is using the SCA to get data that is not relevant to a criminal investigation. The company's lawsuit argues that the government's interpretation of the SCA is not only unconstitutional, but also dangerous. "The use of the SCA to compel the disclosure of non-compromised data undermines the protections that are afforded to consumers under the Fourth Amendment," Phantom said in the press release. "This is because it permits law enforcement to obtain and store evidence that is not the subject of a criminal investigation, and then to later obtain the same evidence by using the SCA." Phantom is asking a judge to order the government to stop using the SCA to compel companies to hand over data that is not encrypted. "We are asking the court to hold that the SCA may not be used to compel companies to disclose non-compromised data," Phantom said in the press release.

By modifying BlackBerry devices, he and his company helped others maintain their privacy while communicating through emails and text messages. Throughout its years of operation, Phantom Secure attracted customers from all over the world, from business executives to diplomats to heads of state. But, in 2016, Ramos was arrested and charged with conspiring to aid and abet international drug trafficking organizations and with conspiracy to engage in money laundering. The US government prosecutors accused him of modifying BlackBerry devices to make them harder to wiretap and then selling those devices to drug cartels. The charges were the result of a four-year investigation by the FBI. Ramos denied the allegations against him and his company. He said that he didn't know any of his customers' crimes. He felt that the government was targeting him to please their allies in Canada. Ramos was convicted of racketeering in a US federal court in 2018. He is serving a sentence of 12 years in prison.

Its servers were routed to ensure data was out of reach of third-parties. As the devices became more popular, criminals became aware of their capabilities and started using the technology. Ramos eventually pleaded guilty to running a criminal enterprise that facilitated drug trafficking and was sentenced to nine years in prison.

This article discusses WebAssembly and its possible future applications. WebAssembly is an intermediate layer between various programming languages and many different execution environments. It can be used to run code on any platform supporting JavaScript, including browsers that do not support the latest improvements in their native JavaScript engines. Webassembly was created by Google as part of a project called Chrome Native Runtime (CNR). CNR aims at creating new hardware-based virtualization technologies for web browsers. Use cases The practical use case we are interested in here is development with JavaScript tools from third-party vendors, such as React or AngularJS. A common approach nowadays involves developing libraries using Node.js and then exporting them via module exports to make it easier to create modules within other programs written in either JavaScript, TypeScript or Clojure. But why? With every new toolkit there comes a plethora of unnecessary boilerplate code inherited through previous versions of the system. This makes it difficult to reuse existing functionality while still being able to evolve independently, especially if one wants to add new features without having to modify two separate systems simultaneously. With WebAssembly you could avoid this problem by writing your own implementation based on original source code instead of modifying nodemodules... packaging files or even copying entire libraries into another place. In addition, some types of services become particularly useful when they act like factories -they provide infrastructure components that let developers easily build complex solutions without worrying about loading dependencies and managing version numbers. We are convinced that such composition will see more and more opportunities soon thanks to all these benefits: 1) combining multiple implementations reduces the time needed to develop and test software, 2) sharing library code across platforms increases productivity significantly, 3) reusability helps prevent reinventing wheel issues, 4) lower costs allow companies to offer better products to clients, 5) composable modularity simplifies architecture decisions, 6) similarity allows us to re-use parts of frameworks built earlier, 7) debugging becomes much easier because libraries follow certain standard conventions, 8) performance gains due to shared runtime overheads, 9) dynamic compilation enables faster developments regardless of whether browsers or servers execute our client-side script, 10) interestingly enough, component modularity also plays a big role when maintaining old codebase. Google's intent is clear: under the hood WebAssembly provides proven technology which they hope would give users unprecedented capabilities to break out of traditional browser limitations. While now only available on Windows (and macOS), Google has already announced plans to release Linux builds later this year. There are promising signs though that both Microsoft and Adobe have been testing preemptive binary translation techniques before official releases ever happen. Examples Native runtimes vs WebAssembly As explained above, there exist several competing approaches to building a native application wrapper around popular scripting languages. The reason behind each of those choices varies widely but usually relates to cost savings. For example, a Unity game engine developed entirely in C requires less resources than a whole HTML5 app running natively. But what does a pure native solution actually mean? In fact, most games today rely heavily on custom math calculations so there's always something to optimize. And since computations aren't done directly inside the GPU with OpenGL ES, CPU usage goes up accordingly. On top of that, memory management problems arise if you've got lots of data structures allocated during 2D rendering operations. At the same time, WebAssembly embraces a completely different target market: smaller mobile devices where small RAM sizes don't leave room for massive amounts of additional storage space. Since WebAssembly compiles JavaScript code first, no expensive external libraries need to be imported beforehand; everything runs alongside the main program executable itself right away. As a result, optimization efforts directed toward making mathematical algorithms fit tiny RAM capacities work much harder and allow designers to keep things simple. For engineers who want to maximize efficiency in production or debug mixed-mode apps, there exists yet another option that's becoming increasingly popular lately. Pre-compiled binaries There are several reasons underlying this trend: 1) speed-ups: compiling takes almost nothing compared to interpreting large blocks of code, 2) maintainability: it's easy to recompile similar scripts whenever necessary, 3) stability: statically compiled binaries enjoy higher reliability levels, e.g., regarding security-related bugs, 4) portability: as long as you're working with the correct compiler options and toolchain configuration settings, cross-browser compatibility isn't too challenging anymore as well, 5) multi-platform support: just imagine how convenient it would be to put together a cross-platform desktop environment! Unfortunately, pre-compiled methods are often accompanied by caveats: although the code base doesn't require constant updates to stay secure, compilers can't handle changes made after initial setup stages. Because of this difficulty managers need to carefully select the best solution for specific requirements; this may involve switching between multiple implementations over time depending on budget constraints relevant from day-to-day business practices. Comprehensive benchmark suites Today there's hardly anyone who hasn't heard of JIT compilation, aka inline assembly. Some people consider it outdated and think it's hard to get good results with modern processors despite recent technological advancements. However, JIT compilation is maturing beyond recognition, delivering great enhancements with respect to speedups; fortunately, the number of independent projects dedicated exclusively to solving specific tasks keeps

This article discusses WebAssembly and its possible future applications. WebAssembly is an intermediate layer between various programming languages and many different execution environments. It can be used to run code written in a variety of programming languages in an efficient and scalable way. It allows Web browsers to be more interactive and lightweight, which is necessary for users who are browsing websites that use a lot of JavaScript. WebAssembly is the first implementation of a new, next-generation programming language that will allow a variety of programming languages to be executed in a Web browser. Its design allows it to run code written in many languages on a single, unified execution environment, rather than having to run code in a separate environment for each language. Its main goal is to provide a general-purpose execution environment for Web-based programming. Although the first version of WebAssembly was released in September 2015, it is still in its infancy. WebAssembly allows code written in many different programming languages to be executed in a Web browser, making it easier for programmers to write their code. It allows the execution of code written in many languages in a single environment. The idea of WebAssembly has been around for a long time, and was first proposed by Mozilla in 2012. It was only recently approved as an open standard by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) in 2015. Uber's apps are available on iOS, Android, and the web, which means that they need to be written three times and usually by different developers. This requires time and careful testing. Uber's mobile teams used to communicate with each other about what features were being worked on, what had been implemented, and which bugs had been fixed, but this process wasn't ideal. The web team, for example, has to ask the iOS and Android teams for a status update, and they have to rely on the mobile teams' responses to determine their own workloads. Uber Engineering needed a system for the web team to obtain information on iOS and Android feature progress, and this is where JIRA and JIRA Agile came in. JIRA Agile is a tool for managing agile development efforts, and it's a component of JIRA Core. Uber Engineering used JIRA Agile to add web-only features, as well as to modify the existing iOS and Android stories in JIRA Core, which meant that the web team could access the same stories as the mobile teams. JIRA Agile has two-way sync with JIRA Core, so the mobile teams were still able to view the original iOS and Android stories, even if they were modified in JIRA Agile. Uber Engineering chose to use JIRA Agile boards in Confluence, which meant that the web team could easily access stories in JIRA Agile without having to sign into JIRA. They could also view the epics for each feature, and they could see dependencies between stories and epics. Using JIRA and JIRA Agile to coordinate feature development has led to a more efficient and streamlined process. The web team no longer has to ask the mobile teams for status updates, and they have more control over their workloads. The mobile teams also benefit because the web team can modify stories in JIRA Agile without having to ask the mobile teams for changes.

One approach to solving this problem is cross-platform development, which involves writing the code once and then deploying it to multiple platforms. This can significantly reduce the time and effort required to create high-quality apps for multiple platforms. There are several cross-platform development tools available, such as React Native, Xamarin, and Flutter. These tools allow developers to write code using familiar web technologies like HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, and then use them to create native iOS and Android apps. Another benefit of cross-platform development is the ability to share code across multiple platforms. This can be useful when building complex apps that require similar functionality across platforms. Overall, cross-platform development can make app development faster, more efficient, and cost-effective, which can be especially beneficial for companies like Uber that need to develop apps for multiple platforms.

Nine years after hundreds of thousands of people fled the area, nature has started to reclaim the space around Fukushima in Japan. In recent years, many evacuation orders have lifted and evacuees are returning home with their families. But one group that remains apart is those who were left behind by tsunami waters in 2011. They continue without electricity or running water due to poor recovery efforts following the nuclear disaster - a situation they call'sanctuary'. The radioactivity from Fukushima's melted fuel rods contaminated neighbouring seas and rivers throughout northeast Asia for decades. To mark its tenth anniversary and while no government ruler calls on Tokyo to return them there, activist groups stage protests calling for Japanese authorities to take responsibility. There was an earthquake near Fukushima in March 2013 but as yet, official investigations into what caused it remain inconclusive. Inquiries had been launched at least three times since 2005 - once under former prime minister Junichiro Koizumi, twice during current PM Shinzo Abe - but nothing conclusive emerged despite experts saying more than 80 per cent could be blamed on natural factors such as fault lines or magma movements beneath the ocean floor. Activist Toshihiro Matsuzaki says he feels lucky not to live anywhere else but in his hometown where the land claim process against Fukushima's nuclear plant operator, TEPCO, continues "The radiation level inside my house still exceeds 100 becquerel [per liter] which is high enough to permit me to stay here because that's the limit set in terms of housing standards," said Mr Matsuzaki, 51. "I feel very fortunate I don't live somewhere else except this place ... I've always wanted to come back home so I'd like to move if we can do something about this problem now, before it's too late."
