Whereas a human worker would have to stop and start, the robot can run non-stop, completing a home in 24 hours." The printer is currently in the early stages of testing. The technology has been around since 2004 but this is the first time a project like this has been undertaken. Building Materials From Moon Dust There are other projects around the world that are using 3D printing to build homes. Researchers from the European Space Agency (ESA) are working to build a lunar base on the moon using 3D printing. The first step is to 3D print a lunar base using simulated lunar material. The researchers used a mixture of iron oxide simulant, which is a byproduct of metallurgy and is already used in 3D printing. In 2013, the ESA began a project called the 3D Printing of Lunar Regolith (3DPL) project. The project is working to build a lunar base using materials found on the moon. The ESA is also working to see if 3D printing can produce materials and structures using moon dust. The ESA's 3D Printing of Lunar Regolith project is being run in conjunction with the European Union's Future and Emerging Technologies arm, known as the FET. A spokesman for ESA said, "As a practice run, a one-third scale version of a lunar habitat is being created using a 3D printer." They are also testing 3D printing methods in vacuum chambers to make sure it will work in the moon's airless environment. The ESA is planning to create a 3D printed habitat on the moon. The base will be designed to take advantage of the moon's low gravity and be built from the moon's natural material. It will be a large dome that is 2.6 meters high
A 33-foot-long 3D printer can build new homes in 24 hours. It is currently building a neighborhood in a rural area on the outskirts of a town in Southern Mexico. (Courtesy CIC Industrial)

Most smartphones sold today have large displays and this presents new challenges and opportunities for app makers and designers. The first iPhone was designed for comfortable one-handed operation, but larger displays have made that difficult to achieve. As a result, app makers have had to adapt their designs to work with larger screens, and designers have had to come up with new ways to make their apps look good on big screens. This has led to a number of new trends in mobile app design, including the use of more white space, larger icons, and more interactive elements. App makers have also had to rethink their use of navigation, as the traditional bottom bar is no longer as effective on large screens. As a result, we're seeing more apps use side menus or other navigation methods. The rise of large-screen smartphones has also had a significant impact on the way we use our phones. We're now more likely to use our phones for tasks that require a larger screen, such as watching videos, reading articles, and playing games. This has led to a growth in the number of apps that are designed for these tasks, and it has also changed the way we interact with our phones. As large-screen smartphones continue to grow in popularity, we're likely to see even more changes in mobile app design. Designers will need to find new ways to make their apps look good on big screens, and app makers will need to adapt their apps to work with these new designs.

Most smartphones sold today have large displays and this presents new challenges and opportunities for app makers and designers. The first iPhone was designed for comfortable one-handed operation, but larger displays require that designers add functionality in multiple touch points. To design apps that work well with larger displays, we need to design for both the small and the large. Responsive design is the process of designing and developing an app that can adjust to a wide range of screen sizes and orientations. This approach allows you to focus on the functionality and interactions that your users care about, and then scale the UI to different devices. In this talk, we'll discuss the basics of responsive design and how to use the techniques and patterns to create apps that look great on any device. How to use the browser's zoom function and zoom features in other apps to adjust the layout to different screen sizes. Using CSS3 media queries to create different UIs for different screen sizes. CSS3 animations to add life to your app's UI. Responsive design and its impact on apps that run on the Web, desktop and mobile devices. What is WebVR? What is it good for? How does it work? What is it good for? WebVR is a new web standard that enables the creation of immersive virtual reality experiences using web technologies. WebVR provides a set of APIs that let you create VR content that runs in a browser. WebVR allows developers to create interactive 3D experiences that can be viewed from any angle and played in a browser on desktop or mobile devices. WebVR uses the existing web platform to provide users with immersive experiences, rather than using a standalone VR device or operating system. This talk will provide an overview of WebVR, including an overview of how WebVR works and what it is good for. I will also cover some of the technical aspects of WebVR, including how it is implemented in browsers, the API design and some common use cases. Architectures - A State of the Unionhttp:blogs.oracle.comkamesh201505app-architectures-a-state-of-the-union 23 May 2015 08:54:05 0000http:blogs.oracle.comkamesh?p50691One of the biggest questions in mobile app development is "How should I architect my app?" This question is particularly important because mobile app development is a moving target. New technologies are coming out on a weekly basis. So, the question is how to keep up with all these changes and be a good architect. One of the biggest questions in mobile app development is "How should I architect my app?" This question is particularly important because mobile app development is a moving target. New technologies are coming out on a weekly basis. So, the question is how to keep up with all these changes and be a good architect. I am not going to try to answer this question here. I have a few posts on the topic on my blog, and you can find those posts here. Instead, I would like to present a state of the union on app architectures in mobile apps. There are two main types of mobile app architectures. The first one is platform-based and the second one is app-based. The platform-based architecture is one in which the app is tightly coupled with a particular platform. You use native APIs and frameworks to develop your app. The app architecture depends on the platform it is built for. You might use an app-based architecture if you want to be more independent from the platform. You use web technologies and APIs to build your app. There are many different ways of implementing an app-based architecture. I have a few posts on the topic on my blog, and you can find those posts here. I will try to cover some of the different approaches and their pros and cons. So, what are the main reasons to choose an app-based architecture?

Most smartphones sold today have large displays and this presents new challenges and opportunities for app makers and designers. The first iPhone was designed for comfortable one-handed operation, but larger phones have made this more difficult, especially for users with smaller hands. For app makers, this means they need to consider the ergonomics of their design and make sure important buttons and features are accessible with one hand. However, larger phone displays also offer more space for creative designs and innovative features. App makers can take advantage of this by incorporating larger images, videos, and more complex layout options. They can also create split-screen modes that allow users to multitask, such as having a video call while browsing the internet. Overall, the key is to strike a balance between usability and creativity. App makers need to create designs that are both aesthetically pleasing and easy to use, regardless of screen size.

Overall, Scan is a useful tool for quickly accessing information and interacting with the world around you.

Astro Robot Astro is a little robot that can clean your house. It's a sort of Roomba with wheels and a screen for eyes. You can ask it questions, but it can't really talk to you. The screen will display the answers to your questions, and it will show you your calendar and the weather. You'll also be able to use it to watch movies, check out photos, and make video calls. Astro will cost 699.99, and it will be available in the US by the end of 2019. Echo Frames and Astro aren't the only products Amazon announced today. It also revealed a new Echo Show that you can tilt. The new Echo Show is smaller and rounder than the old one. It's also only 89.99, which makes it Amazon's cheapest smart screen yet. The new Echo Show is available for pre-order now and will ship starting on October 16. Amazon also unveiled the Echo Dot with Clock. It's just like the Echo Dot, except it has a digital clock on the front. And there's an Echo Dot for your car now. It's basically an Echo Dot that plugs into your cigarette lighter. It also comes with a little mount that attaches to the dashboard. If you're more into smart rings than smart sunglasses, Amazon has something for you. It announced a new Echo Loop that you can wear on your finger. It has two microphones and a small speaker. You can press a button on the ring to summon Alexa, and you can use it to make phone calls, send messages, and listen to music. It's available for pre-order starting today. Amazon also unveiled a new Echo Glow that kids can use to make music. It's basically a smart version of the light-up balls kids play with. Last but not least, Amazon revealed a new Echo Flex. It's a tiny smart speaker that you can plug into a wall socket, which makes it the most versatile Echo yet. It has a built-in night light, and you can ask it to do the same things you can ask the other Echo devices to do. The Echo Flex is 24.99 and is available for pre-order today. Amazon just announced a bunch of new gadgets ahead of the busy holiday shopping season. They include the Astro home robot, a smart thermostat, an Amazon Echo Show that can be used as a speaker and more. How many times have you heard this phrase? It's part of your title in life: "business owner" or "professional partner." Yet we still struggle with it - even though we know what it's meant to mean. We've got some words for you: As one of our partners put it: "I see entrepreneurship as being about creating something from nothing. I'm not sure I'd ever call [that] business ownership...I'd say my company is owned by me. If I sold the idea itself then maybe that's ownership but if I own all aspects at every level then really there's zero focus on anything other than having money earned for myself through working hard ... You're essentially running a solo show here trying to find ways to make yourself happy doing work you're passionate about. That doesn't address the problems created when people run their businesses like they are running a show rather than focusing on growing their actual biz. Without passion and purpose behind what you do, you're going nowhere fast. And unless you give up your power over others to serve them well endlessly, you're basically never enjoying your stuff very much. It takes a lot of energy to keep pushing forward without knowing whether any goal will actually come true or fail miserably along the way...The pressure always seems unbearable because success wasn't promised on investment day but failure didn't seem possible either. But most importantly, both didn't happen! So now you're running in circles wondering where things could get better before taking another look into getting out again and hoping everything turns around. The only thing guaranteed in 'entrepreneurial' terms is change ... Change is scary so we avoid it like crazy. All the best intentions lead us back to square one."

This repository contains a PyTorch implementation of "Multi-Level Pixel-Aligned Implicit Function for High-Resolution 3D Human Digitization." The code can create high-resolution 3D models of humans from a single image. A similar approach was used in [1]. However, the model is trained on images with two cameras attached to each foot. This improves accuracy over methods that use only one camera. The Python versions I have been using are 3.6 and 4.7.4 (on Ubuntu Linux 16.04 LTS). All libraries installed include numpy 1.18.0, scipy 0.14.1, tensorflow-gpu 2.2.3, keras 2.5.5, pytorch 7.1.0, matplotlib 1.2.1, pandas 0.13.2, scikit-image 0.17.0, PIL (Python Image Library) 8. Training In order to train this network we need an appropriate set-up. Our training data consists of human body samples which were obtained by scanning them at high resolution (approx. 300x300 px per pixel). We also obtain realistic environment images (without any objects or people), which are required as input during testing due to their inaccurate camera calibration parameters. In our case they are taken from real environments where there are no people present. They can be either natural scenes such as grasslands, forests etc., urban areas like skyscrapers, buildings or even indoor rooms filled with office furniture. Since our goal is creating precise digitized models, not just low quality approximations, neither precise object pose estimation nor accurate face detection is necessary; hence we do not apply these techniques but rather perform manual labeling manually or through automatic segmentation algorithms [28, 19]. Network Architecture As shown in Figure 6, the main components of the proposed architecture are: Preprocessing module During pre processing several operations are applied: sub-sampling, cropping, background estimation and foreground extraction [6]. Sub sampling -It transforms original image into smaller ones preserving its shape while decreasing its dimensions. For example, if input image has size 500 800 pixels then it will first resize down to 100 150 ... 200 400 pixels depending on maximum allowed heightwidth ratio. Then again it'll drop next layer above in proportion till reaching desired dimensions. Cropping: To achieve better scan matching later on we'll crop out some parts of the image containing little information about the scanned object. We choose rectangle-shaped regions in different scales and locations around the black silhouette extracted earlier. Background estimation: The purpose here is to get rid of unwanted elements inside the scene causing false detections e.g. shadows created by nearby surfaces and bright spots caused by sunlight reflected on windows. It does so by estimating color distribution within region-of-interest and modeling it using Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM). Foreground extractor: As illustrated in figure 5 (a), after performing background removal operation by GMM and applying thresholds it's possible to locate the whole human body area visually. But during actual registration process we can't rely entirely on visual inspection since it results in a very rough estimate of the position of both feet thus making the system less precise. Therefore we try to improve those estimates via machine learning approaches. Intuitively background removed object should appear brighter than surrounding areas. Hence one could expect classification error rates regarding certain partssilhouettes to decrease remarkably when providing more image examples from same class with given features. In other words, multiple instances of foreground samples provide additional context allowing us to obtain more reliable object location estimates compared to single instance scenario. Data Augmentation is particularly important in deep neural networks because simple data augmentation helps prevent overfitting. Since 2D images don't contain enough spatial information to give good predictions, sometimes adding random jitter to all coordinates causes large improvements [26]. Pixels' values are randomly scaled between -0.05 and 0.05. Rotating the entire image: x y z rand 1,..., 1) (this performs random rotation without changing scale factor) Rotating individual views: x y z abs (rand 1,..., 1 (this simulates pure translation along x-axis and second time orthogonal transformation of coordinate system) Image Resizing Predictions After training datasets become available we run inference phase to generate test outputs. During prediction Core-VGG-16 [16] model generates bounding boxes corresponding to detected faces starting from lower left corner upto upper right corner. Labeled points are placed near centers of those boxes. On top of detected persons, foreground blobs are computed based upon RGB channel output and added back to generated point cloud figures in order to make final complete scan representations. Estimated positions of the head and hands represent center of gravity points of respective armshands. These are labeled accurately at least in terms of relative distances among various joints. Inference procedure allows obtaining dense output clouds with highly detailed geometries. Even though most of the segments come close to ground truth labels, errors still occur due to occlusions and missing limbs. An advantage of having deep convolutional networks instead of simpler regression-based solutions relies on ability to: predict exact poses directly and take full advantage of intermediate layers capabilities, unlike hand-crafted appearance descriptors. While predicting skeleton's bones, fusing complementary depth channels makes it much easier to deal with partial perspectives

This repository contains a PyTorch implementation of "Multi-Level Pixel-Aligned Implicit Function for High-Resolution 3D Human Digitization." The code can create high-resolution 3D models of humans from a single image. A trained neural network takes an image and outputs a high-resolution 3D mesh in a canonical pose. This is achieved with a combination of pixel-aligned implicit representations with a multi-level network architecture, which allows high-resolution output while keeping the number of parameters in the network manageable. The results are comparable or superior to state-of-the-art methods at a fraction of the computational cost. The neural network is trained using the same dataset and code as SMPLify. The implementation comes with three pretrained models. Download the model weights for the aforementioned models. The weights are in the weights directory. The weights can be loaded using the following code. In order to predict a high-resolution mesh from a single image, you can use the following code. The code is heavily based on the SMPLify code, and as such, the interfaces are compatible. The code is tested on Ubuntu 18.04. Following the popularity of MoviePass, which peaked at 3.2 million subscribers earlier this summer, AMC rolled out its own subscription service, a 19.95 pass to watch up to 3 movies per month for 19month (after you return your first movie). Following the popularity of MoviePass, which peaked at 3.2 million subscribers earlier this summer, AMC rolled out its own subscription service, a 19.95 pass to watch up to 3 movies a month. For AMC, the idea is to get people to return to the theater. As of November 2018, AMC has more than 1,100 theaters, compared to 1,054 for Regal and 700 for IMAX. The theater chain's strategy is to lure more customers to its cinemas, then turn them into AMC fans and moviegoers.

Following the popularity of MoviePass, which peaked at 3.2 million subscribers earlier this summer, AMC rolled out its own subscription service, a 19.95 pass to watch up to 3 movies a week. AMC's A-List service, which launched on August 15, allows customers to see up to three movies per week, in one or more AMC theaters, for the same price as a single movie ticket. A-List also offers discounts on concessions, and members can reserve their seats in advance. AMC's service is more expensive than MoviePass, which charges $9.95 per month for unlimited movies, but it offers more flexibility and does not require users to see a movie every day. As of August 29, A-List had attracted more than 200,000 subscribers.

Following the popularity of MoviePass, which peaked at 3.2 million subscribers earlier this summer, AMC rolled out its own subscription service, a 19.95 pass to watch up to 3 movies per week called AMC Stubs A-List. AMC's offering has grown to 260,000 members in just a matter of weeks, and it has become a better deal on a per movie basis than MoviePass, as MoviePass has begun limiting its users to 3 movies per month. The problem with MoviePass is that it doesn't control the cost of its inputs, while AMC does, making the latter's offering much more sustainable.

Following the popularity of MoviePass, which peaked at 3.2 million subscribers earlier this summer, AMC rolled out its own subscription service, a 19.95 pass to watch up to 3 movies a week. The AMC service, which unlike MoviePass, isn't restricted to certain theaters, launched in June, but the chain isn't satisfied with just the theater experience, as Variety reports, AMC is now considering getting into the streaming business. AMC CEO Adam Aron said the theater chain is "giving thought" to launching a subscription streaming service, which would offer movies in the home theatrical release window, about 90 days after they hit theaters. He said AMC is "evaluating the merits of an at-home product that would be in tandem with, and not replace, theatrical release windows." "We know that there are a lot of people that are not going to come to the movie theater, so we want to participate in that," Aron said in the call, adding, "We have to make a careful decision and our goal would be to do it in a way that does not jeopardize the existing ecosystem that is producing those terrific movies." Aron said the chain would explore the possibility of creating such a service if the studios could provide an exclusive license to offer the films. He said the service would be "complementary" to the current theatrical-release windows, and not "competitive" with them. TAGSAMCtheaters

However, some experts have expressed concerns that it may not be sustainable for the company in the long run.

Singapore currently produces about 10 percent of its food. Due to climate change and population growth, it aims to produce 30 percent of its food by 2030. In order to achieve this goal, the island nation plans to build more farms, especially on waste land. However, the island nation is facing a dilemma. It has to provide its people with a balanced diet, but it cannot continue to rely on imports for this. Thus, the solution is to use waste to produce more food. One of the major components of waste is rice. While Singapore has one of the highest rates of rice consumption in the world, its rice supply is not sufficient to meet demand. The country imports more than 90 percent of its rice, and is likely to be dependent on imports for the next 30 years. The island nation is now looking to create a new source of food from rice waste. By transforming rice waste into biofuel, Singapore hopes to become self-sufficient in rice production by 2025. The Circular Rice Initiative In order to achieve this goal, Singapore is taking a two-pronged approach. First, it is exploring the feasibility of a closed-loop system that produces energy from rice waste. It is using the city-state's own rice waste to fuel electric cars. The initiative is called the Circular Rice Initiative. Second, the government is planning to build a large-scale rice production facility that will utilize waste. The facility is expected to generate enough rice for 1.5 million people. In addition to rice, it will produce other crops, such as sugarcane, and possibly palm oil. The facility is expected to be completed by 2022. While the initiative will be a major investment for the government, it is expected to save Singapore 1.5 billion in food costs. The government has stated that it hopes to reduce its food imports by 50 percent by 2030. Investing in the Future of Food A successful venture in the circular rice initiative will be a major step toward Singapore's goal of becoming self-sufficient in rice production. This will not only reduce the island nation's reliance on imports, but also contribute to the overall goal of reducing its food imports by 50 percent by 2030. With Singapore's population expected to reach 4 million by 2030, the initiative is an important investment for the future of food.

Vertical farming: Singapore is promoting the use of vertical farming to maximise the use of limited land resources. Vertical farms take up less space while yielding more crops per unit of land compared to traditional farming methods. 2. Rooftop farming: Rooftop farming is a new trend that is gaining popularity in cities around the world, and Singapore is no exception. Rooftop farms are built on top of buildings, using previously unused space to grow crops. 3. Indoor farming: With the use of hydroponics and LED lighting, indoor farming can grow crops year-round, regardless of weather conditions, and with significantly less water than traditional farming methods. 4. Aquaponics: Aquaponics is a combination of aquaculture (the farming of fish) and hydroponics (growing plants in water). The waste produced by fish is used to fertilise plants, while the plants help to clean the water for the fish. This method requires less water than traditional farming methods. 5. Education and support: The government is also putting in efforts to educate and support individuals and organisations who want to participate in local food production. This includes providing grants, training and technical support. All of these initiatives show Singapore's commitment to increasing its food production capabilities and becoming more self-sufficient.

Docker-OSX automates the installation of OSX-KVM inside a docker container. It is possible to customize the size and version of the VM using build arguments. Configurations can easily be modified, upgraded or removed without restarting containers. At this time there has not been much interest in installing Docker on Linux so we don't have an official way for it yet but I would highly recommend trying out one of these methods as they are almost foolproof. Bitcoin is already decentralized by design - which means it's open source software that's anyone can download, run on their computers, modify without permission and reuse freely if they wish to do so. The whole concept behind Bitcoin was originally inspired by "The Matrix" movie series (for those who don't know). As explained there, our online identity isn't really defined by anything outside ourselves, but instead we are always being controlled by someone else somewhere. This is why one day you may wake up with no memory of your own existence, just because you're programmed into thinking otherwise. In this respect, Bitcoin sounds like the ultimate solution to this problem; it will allow us all to literally be whoever we want. Additionally, money itself wasn't created until quite recently (around 1694), when economist Adam Smith played around with ideas about how people could trade goods and services. At first he concentrated mostly on creating something similar to gold coins, known later on as silver dollars. However, he quickly realized that currency alone couldn't solve any problems, considering that most countries were still running on feudal systems where property rights didn't exist at all. It became obvious right away that only paper money would work, meaning bank notes printed automatically upon demand. Because nobody has control over its creation process, using fiat money requires trust between individuals, guaranteeing everyone's access to cash - even though nobody actually keeps their assets safe under lock and key. Nowadays, crypto currencies have become quite popular, especially after governments started regulating crypto markets more strictly due to their growing popularity among ordinary citizens throughout the world. Some of these regulations include taxation, laws against illegal activities and other issues related to financial safety.

Google Wallet is returning and may take over Google Pay. Wallet will likely become a place for digital cards, while Pay will remain the primary service for paying for things. Yes, that is correct. Google has announced that it will be bringing back its Google Wallet service, which was originally launched in 2011 and eventually merged into Google Pay. The new Google Wallet will reportedly focus on providing users with a central hub for storing and managing their digital payment cards, loyalty cards, gift cards, and other payment-related information. Meanwhile, Google Pay will continue to be the main payment service for making transactions both online and offline. It remains to be seen how exactly the new Google Wallet will integrate with Google Pay, but it's likely that they will work seamlessly together to provide users with a more streamlined and comprehensive payment experience.

GPS systems are unable to work underwater as water breaks down the radio waves GPS relies on to function. MIT scientists have developed a device called an underwater backscatter localization system (UBLS) which uses sound to accurately locate underwater objects. Using a sonar device, an underwater UBLS device can be sent into the water and determine the location of a fish, or other object, that is in contact with the device. The UBLS system uses sound waves to transmit data to the fish or other object, and the sound waves bounce off the object and back to the device, providing the location of the object. The UBLS device can be fitted with a GPS to provide accurate location information. By using sound waves to send data to the fish or other object, the UBLS system does not require power, as radio waves used by GPS systems require power to work. MIT's UBLS device can be used to send data to a fish and determine the location of a fish in the water. GPS systems are unable to work underwater as water breaks down the radio waves GPS relies on to function. MIT scientists have developed a device called an underwater backscatter localization system, which uses acoustic signals to determine the position of a vehicle or object underwater. The system is comprised of a transmitter and receiver that send and receive acoustic signals to and from a transponder. The transponder is attached to the object to be located and transmits a unique acoustic signal. The receiver detects the signal and uses it to determine the distance and direction to the transponder. The transmitter then transmits a second signal, which is received by the transponder and reflected back to the receiver. The receiver uses the reflected signal to calculate the object's position. The system is accurate to within a few meters and can be used in both fresh and saltwater.

Apple is facing an antitrust investigation after Spotify filed a complaint with the European Commission for Apple's anti-competitive business strategies. Spotify is frustrated with Apple's 30 percent take of subscription fees and they claim that Apple unfairly used their iOS platform to launch a music subscription service that otherwise would not have been successful. Companies leveraging their platforms for their own benefit is common practice in the US, but the EU believes that regulators must protect consumers against such practices as they may harm innovation and limit customer choice.

Apple is facing an antitrust investigation after Spotify filed a complaint with the European Commission for Apple's anti-competitive business strategies. Spotify is frustrated with Apple's 30 percent take of subscription revenue and the restrictions that the App Store puts on third-party apps. Announced in an official Spotify blog post, the music streaming service explains how Apple has given itself "an unfair advantage at every turn." Apple requires that Spotify and other digital services pay a 30 tax on purchases made through Apple's payment system, including upgrading from our Free to our Premium service. If we pay this tax, it would force us to artificially inflate the price of our Premium membership well above the price of Apple Music. And to keep our price competitive for our customers, that isn't something we can do. As an alternative, if we choose not to use Apple's payment system, forgoing the charge, Apple then applies a series of technical and experience-limiting restrictions on Spotify. For example, they limit our communication with our customers - including our outreach beyond the app. In some cases, we aren't even allowed to send emails to our customers who use Apple. Apple also routinely blocks our experience-enhancing upgrades. Over time, this has included locking Spotify and other competitors out of Apple services such as Siri, HomePod, and Apple Watch. Spotify also says Apple has blocked Spotify from accessing Siri and HomePod, which is a big deal because Spotify has created Siri commands and AirPlay 2 support that Apple is refusing to implement. Spotify CEO Daniel Ek in a Twitter thread explained that the goal of the complaint is not to "harm Apple," but to address Apple's anti-competitive behavior and allow "all companies to compete fairly and consumers to win." In recent years, Apple has introduced rules to the App Store that purposely limit choice and stifle innovation at the expense of the user experience - essentially acting as both a player and referee to deliberately disadvantage other app developers. After trying unsuccessfully to resolve the issues directly with Apple, we're now requesting that the EC take action to ensure fair competition. Ek says Apple has blocked Spotify's efforts to upgrade its app for years, has "routinely" blocked its experience-enhancing upgrades, and has "applied a series of technical and experience-limiting restrictions on Spotify." Apple has responded to Spotify's allegations, calling it "misleading rhetoric" and accusing the music streaming company of wanting all of the benefits of the App Store without contributing to the costs of running it. Ek took to Twitter to respond, saying that Apple's statement is "cute" but doesn't address the core issues. The Spotify complaint comes after Apple Music overtook Spotify in paid U.S. subscribers in July 2018, and the service is said to be continuing to grow rapidly. (Picture: Pixabay) Till recently seed farming had always remained dormant within farmers' investment priorities due to lack of reliable availability and affordable price tags. However, following COVID-19 pandemic impacting large sections of Indian society, increasing digitalization amongst rural households and rapid adoption of smartphones among farmers, interest in buying agricultural produce via online shopping portals has grown significantly. Globally, several countries claim exclusive rights over certain crops which means growers cannot purchase seeds outside those jurisdictions causing delays in planting seasons across different regions. While some areas have started issuing permissions allowing sellers of other brands to grow specific crop varieties under broader licenses granted by governments, others still remain non-transparent regarding licensing agreements between cropping firms and state-owned organisations. In these situations, farmers who want to invest extra money into growing fresh produce may opt to source agricultural commodities elsewhere resulting in increased food supply costs borne only by consumers thereby putting pressure on government budgets.

BepiColombo is set to take over the Mercury Orbiter, which was launched in 2008. The spacecraft will orbit Mercury every 12 hours, providing scientists with a high-resolution map of the planet's surface and analysing the composition of the planet's soil and the solar wind, which is thought to be largely responsible for the erosion of Mercury's surface. The mission will also study the planet's magnetic field and atmosphere, the structure of the surface and the planet's interior, and will explore the possibility of liquid water on the surface. Scientists hope the mission will help them understand Mercury better and, in turn, unlock secrets about the solar system and how planets form. Mercury is the innermost planet in the solar system and is often called the "canary in the coal mine" because it was the first planet to be discovered by astronomers. Scientists from the University of Oxford and robotics firm Devanthro grew cells on a robot skeleton in an experiment designed to create more flexible lab-grown cells. The researchers used the robot as a scaffolding for growing skin cells on top of, and next to, the body of the robot. In a paper published in the journal Nature, the researchers described how they used a small chip, which contained a 3D printer, to grow the cells. The robot, which is known as a "multi-arm manipulator," is a humanoid robot that can be programmed to carry out a number of tasks. The robot is made up of a number of joints, each of which is controlled by a servo motor. The robot's joints can move 100 degrees in all directions. The robot is able to move around a workspace, and the researchers used this to create a 3D cell-culture platform. "It's the first time anyone has ever grown cells on a robot," said Inderjit Dhillon, a mechanical engineer at the University of Oxford and the lead author of the study. "We hope that our platform will allow scientists to develop new types of tissue for use in drug discovery, drug delivery, regenerative medicine and other applications." The researchers began by printing a scaffold on the robot, which is made up of 25 separate layers. The cells are then placed on top of this scaffold and grown for 14 days. After this time, the researchers took the cells off the robot and placed them in a petri dish. They then analyzed the cells, and discovered that the cells were flexible, and able to move around the robot's joints. "We're really excited about this platform," said co-author, Devanthro CEO, Dilip Misra. "This is the first time we've ever printed and cultured cells on a robot. We're looking forward to collaborating with researchers and the medical industry to explore how this platform can be used in tissue engineering, regenerative medicine and drug discovery." The researchers also tested how the robot would respond to various drugs, including the chemotherapy drug doxorubicin. The robot was able to withstand the harsh chemicals and continued to function. "The main challenge with growing cells in the lab is that they tend to stick to the surfaces they're grown on," said co-author of the study, Alastair Johnson, a mechanical engineer at the University of Oxford. "We wanted to develop a platform that would allow cells to grow on a variety of different surfaces." The researchers are now working to improve the robot, and to make it a fully functioning device. They hope to use the robot to develop drug-delivery systems, and to allow for the controlled delivery of drugs to specific areas of the body. "We're very excited about this research," said co-author, Anil Vaidya, a mechanical engineer at the University of Oxford.

Scientists from the University of Oxford and robotics firm Devanthro grew cells on a robot skeleton in an experiment designed to create more flexible lab-grown cells. The researchers used the soft-robot skeleton as a platform on which to grow skeletal muscle tissue. After it grew, they disconnected the robot from its power source and then electrically stimulated it to see if it would move. The experiment wasn't about building the bionic man, though. It was about the fact that lab-grown tissue is stiff and difficult to grow around anything other than rigid plastic scaffolds. The stiffness of these scaffolds can actually lead to the lab-grown tissue being less functional. The researchers used a robot skeleton in order to create a more natural environment for the muscle tissue to grow around. They were able to remove the rigid scaffold and grow the cells directly on the robot. The hope is that the more natural environment will lead to cells that are more functional and less stiff. The team used a custom-made bioreactor to grow the cells on the robot's skeleton. The robot skeleton was made of artificial tendons and silicone air sacs, or actuators, that were designed to be similar to the ones in the human hand. The robot skeleton was also able to replicate the way the human hand moves when grabbing something. The team used neonatal rat muscle cells to grow the tissue. They attached the cells to the robot skeleton, which was then placed in the bioreactor. They used electricity to stimulate the cells in the same way they would be stimulated in a living body. The cells grew and developed into functioning muscle tissue around the robot skeleton. The researchers then removed the robot skeleton from the bioreactor and connected it to a portable battery. They were able to make the muscles contract by sending an electrical current through the robot skeleton. This experiment demonstrates that it's possible to use the robot skeleton as a scaffold and that the muscle tissue will still function after it's removed from the bioreactor. The team hopes to continue their research using human cells instead of rat cells in order to test how the muscle tissue could be used in the human body. This is just the beginning of the research, but it's an important step towards the use of lab-grown muscle tissue in the human body. The University of Oxford and Devanthro presented their research at the International Conference on Robotics and Automation.

Shortly after, they packed up and moved across the country to Seattle, where Bezos launched Amazon. "We feel incredibly lucky to have found each other and deeply grateful for every one of the years we have been married to each other," their statement read. "If we had known we would separate after 25 years, we would do it all again." MacKenzie Bezos, an author, is often cited as the inspiration for creating Amazon. "We've had such a great life together as a married couple, and we also see wonderful futures ahead, as parents, friends, partners in ventures and projects, and as individuals pursuing ventures and adventures," their statement said.
